text:
I made this account to give this movie a 1/10 This movie did not make any sense to me! It's far too violent to tell such a shallow and ultimately senseless story. I had high expectations, seeing the great actors involved and the 7.1 rating. Initially, the movie was quite interesting, as it reflects on the dystopian times of COVID, fake news, social media turning into a source of polarization, and so on. But then, somehow, it completely derails and the violence takes over. It's as if the filmmakers ran out of inspiration and used extreme violence to fill the void. Provocation for the sake of provocation.

I'm genuinely astonished that this was made into an actual movie, that the actors were willing to participate, and that someone was willing to finance this mess. If I want to see violence, I can just watch the news. The money could have been spent so much better, especially in this world of turmoil. What a waste of precious life and energy to make this film, let alone watch it.
label: literal

text:
This film is annoying From the extremely irritating characters, really bad acting that feels like stage improv, the predictable storyline, which I said to my wife "it is going to end with this happening and that happening". And sure enough, that's exactly how it happened.

Even though this same story has been made many times in more successful Christmas films, this one took the same idea and concept and spent 2 hours sitting down to write a really bad script. All the characters are very unlikeable, especially the massively over the top Harry Potter fanatic, Nigel. It's just a very bad attempt at a Christmas rom com. And so, I give it a one.
label: literal

text:
If you mixed the prime of Covid with the Black Lives Matter protests and put them in a small town and dialled it up to 100 this is the film that you would get. This was definitely a more normal film by Ari Aster's standards, though still crazy. There was a point in the film where things switched up very fast, and you could see it coming.

Joaquin Phoenix was just exceptional, it's another terrific performance added to his filmography. Pedro Pascal, Emma Stone, Austin Butler, Deidre O'Connell, Michael Ward, Luke Grimes, and William Belleau were all phenomenal as well.

The cinematography was magnificent. I especially loved the shot in the beginning of the film where the red side of the police light was slowly flashing on Joaquin Phoenix's face.

Ari Aster really knows how to tell a story, make you feel imbedded into that story, and keep you engrossed for the entire runtime (and in this case it was a 2hr 30min runtime). I loved Midsommar as well so I'll definitely be watching the rest of his filmography.

Overall, this was a terrific film and a massively enjoyable watch.

"We need to free each other's hearts."


* Joe Cross.
label: literal

text: So dumb it's good I like all the stupid plus the 90s actors. All the cringe and discomfort your looking for in a Christmas film. Adorably embraces all of the Christmas movie clichés. text:
For a story built on precision and gravity, Nuremberg feels like a glossy reenactment that forgot to bring both. *Nuremberg* should've been a slam dunk-an era soaked in moral complexity, political tension, and enough real-world drama to power ten films. Instead, it settles for being a handsomely shot history lesson that keeps tripping over its own choices. Yes, it shed light on some behind-the-scenes trial dynamics I didn't know, and the cinematography and color work are legitimately strong. But the casting derails things fast: Rami Malek, a talented actor with exactly one gear, feels wildly misaligned with his role, turning crucial scenes into accidental parody every time that trademark smirk surfaces.. The pacing barrels forward like it's trying to catch a connecting flight, suffocating moments that desperately needed room to breathe. And in the rush, accuracy gets tossed overboard, American heroism dialed up, international nuance dialed down, timelines shuffled like a deck of discount playing cards. I should have called it 2 mins in with how bad they butchered the accuracy of Goring's actual surrender to US troops.

A disappointment at **5.2/10**, made all the more frustrating because the raw material deserved better.
label: figurative

text:
If you want absolute truth, read a book or watch a documentary Premium cable network historical dramas - even those that take creative license with dates and facts, like this one - are far better than most network and basic cable series. And don't get me started on reality series: housewives, teen moms, 90 day fiancé, bachelor and bachelorette, etc.

I've forgotten a lot of world history that was taught in high school, so these historical drama series remind me of the entire long history of humans. And when I don't understand something I've just watched, I look it up online (from a reputable source).

And watching this is WAY better than watching the news.
label: literal

text: Sinners has some issues Sinners has some issues. This movie is trying so hard to be From Dusk Till Dawn, but it just comes up short in comparison. The first act involves Michael B. Jordan playing a set of twins as they set up for a party, it's slow and not very interesting. I get technology is getting better, but I don't like one actor playing two sides of a conversation. It's not the Nutty Professor, it never feels fluid, and it's probably why the two main characters spend most of the movie apart. Sinners struggles to get going but once the party starts you think you're in store for some cool vampire fight scenes, but you are mistaken. Instead, vampires dance an Irish Jig that caused the person I was watching the movie with to lean over and say to me "this is the dumbest thing I've ever seen." what it didn't have was some cool vampire fights. The action scenes are weak and for a movie that's also weak on character development and plot, you can't afford to also be lackluster with the action. This movie would probably be more fun if you went in blind and didn't know about the genre switch coming your way, but it ruins that with too much foreshadowing early on. Overall, I don't get what all the hype is about 6/10.
label: literal

text: Wonderful, intriguing story! The actors are wonderful and authentic, the script terrific. Makes you want to know everyone in it! Great depiction of the Navajo nation-very nuanced life stories and the struggles of life on the reservation. Beautiful photography, too! Fascinating to see how these mysteries were solved with 1970s technology-no cell phones, no GPS. Missed watching it when season 2 ended-wanted to know what each person was doing after the episodes concluded. Hope the producers have the wisdom to keep this going. I haven't read the Hilleman books, but presume that there are many more rich stories to tell. Can't wait for Season 3!

text: Tough to watch Monster is a series created by Ryan Murphy (American Crime Story, American Horror Story, 9-1-1, Hollywood, Pose, Feud, etc.). Everything Murphy touches is pretty much successful and this is no different. Everyone knows this story by now...he's one of the most notorious serial killers in the history of the United States. He would lure young men to his apartment and not only kill them but eat them. This is a story that's been told many times but this show takes the unique perspective of largely telling the story from the victims point of view. Evan Peters is absolutely brilliant as Jeffrey Dahmer. He's so good that he should be talked about for an Emmy nomination next year. This series is worth watching for Peters performance alone. This is very dark, disturbing story and Ryan Murphy does a great job telling it.
label: literal

text:

I loved Better Call Saul, its really interesting diving into the life of Jimmy Mcgill or as we know him Saul Goodman or even Slippin' Jimmy. I enjoyed learning more about Mike and gus it was really interesting seeing how everything started off, honestly such an experience.

Highly recommend Its a great show with just as many twists and turns as breaking bad, hold onto your seats.

text: Hasn't aged well. I first saw this a long time ago, and liked it a lot. On a recent viewing, I find that it hasn't aged as well as I thought. It was fun to see John Galecki and Juliette Lewis as children, and I had forgotten how pretty Julia Louis-Dreyfus was back then. I got one big laugh-out-loud moment from the whole movie, when the old aunt forgets that she is supposed to say the pre-meal blessing, and starts into the Pledge of Allegiance instead, and the whole family dutifully joins in. Clark Griswold is such a sad sack, and even though I know it is the point of the film, it's still a bit cloying. This is still OK as "one of the Vacation films" but if it stood alone, I think it would suffer.

text:
You've got to love Nurse Jackie... I'm rewatching this series after 15yrs. I was bored and sick and had nothing to do. Didn't expect to love it.

I liked it a lot the first time. But now I see it with older eyes. More life experience. My own couple years of addiction with prescription meds. Dr prescribed, but miserable to come off none the less... This is beautiful show. Only now that I'm 45, close to Jackie's age do I really appreciate this. They don't make anything this anymore. Not with the heart and acting talent... plus dark humor. So much to enjoy.

text:
Enjoyed it! Loved it! What I was expected was a comedy full of clichés about somebody going undercover,his crazy antics & so forth.

This great series wasn't full of cheesy laughs & corny lines,found myself actually emotional during some parts because of the way topics were handled-Like the resident with memory issues.

However it wasn't all serious that made you feel down or bored getting through episodes,it kept the series watch worthy because you wanted to see how it played out-Who did the stealing,etc.

The casting to acting was great,cinematography & locations nicely done.

I really hope they do another season & bring a great mixture of laughs,emotions,script,location plus cast like they did on Charles next detective styled adventures as they did on this one.

text: Already looking forward to next season There are a million doctor/hospital shows out there so you really need to be special to stick out and The Pitt absolutely does that. I'll be shocked if this show doesn't get nominated for a bunch of awards, especially Noah Wyle in the lead role. I've always like Wyle but this is career defining performance. He's fantastic in every scene. I'm a binged, I love to binge watch shows, so much so that even for the shows that come out weekly I wait until the entire season is over before I start it so I can binge it. This is the first show I've ever seen that I can only watch a few episodes at a time because of how intense each mood each episode is. I'll still watch a few episodes each day and binge the entire season within 5 or 6 days but it's a work out doing it. text:

Plot holes? Don't get me started! The premise is ridiculous and it just goes downhill from there.

I didn't cheer for the big guy. I didn't care about any of the characters. I didn't care what happened next. I didn't care.

text:
Not faithful to the source material... Lets start with this: this is a good movie. But like the cult classic The Running Man, this movie does not follow the book it's based on. Sure, it's closer to the book than The Running Man was, but many things in the movie were different from the book. The differences that were made for expediency, like 3 mph (movie) vs. 4 mph (book) and 50 participants (movie) vs. 100 participants (book), are understandable for expediency and easier to film. The changes like character motivations for participating in the long walk were created in the movie. The ending in the movie was nowhere near what it was in the book. The actors were older than the boys on the long walk. Cooper Hoffman is 22 years old. David Johnson is 32.

The sound, cinematography, acting, and general quality of the movie is great; but the movie should have stuck to the source material.
label: literal

text: A movie that thinks audiences are stupid Yes, thank you for showing those flashbacks a million times; how could audiences possibly remember what happened in a movie they're watching. Yes, thank you for adding extremely on-the-nose sound effects to a character's retelling of a lynching. Thank you for adding multiple unnecessary romance subplots that had no payoff, no purpose in the story. And of course, let's not forget creating characters that walk, talk and breathe like cliches of cliches, but still expecting your audiences to feel something for them. I swear, the writing for this movie is the epitome of trying to make every line of dialogue ooze "coolness" and be cinematic, to such a degree that it wraps around the other end and lands squarely in the "cringe" category. I did not like a single character, because none of them were people, just bundles of tropes I've already seen. The music wasn't even that good; I left the cinema without a single note of the soundtrack stuck in my head. Overall, wow, what a glorified baby mobile of a movie; perfect for those among us who never been to a cinema, or seen a single film in their life. The only reason I'm not giving it a lower rating is because it's clear the makers of it cared about what they were doing, even if it turned into a very subpar experience. Also the general idea for the plot was cool. What a shame it all went to waste.
label: figurative

text:
A Unique Concept, Which Is The Only Thing Uniqe About This Film I watched the movie on premiere day without having seen the trailers and only being semi-familiar with the franchise. And yet, even without having any expectations going into this film, it failed to captivate me in any meaningful way, resulting in just a generic popcorn flick.

The story revolves around Dek, an inexperienced Predator trying to prove his worth by hunting down a dangerous creature on a planet full of living death traps. However, his quest for blood takes a turn when he meets a synthetic android named Thia. As he starts forming a connection with her, Dek begins to realize there might be more to him than just being a deadly hunter.

The idea to have the main character be a lesser version of the Predator we all know and love is genius. Not only because having an alien protagonist is a rare thing to see in movies, but it would also allow the writers to explore more of the creature's mythos and give the audience a chance to see this popular figure slowly evolve into the brutal and intelligent brute he is. While we do get some lore of how the species operates, a well-paced evolution of Dek's set of skills is almost entirely absent from the movie, as he doesn't really LEARN to be better at combat or survival. Instead, he just randomly acquires the skillset to be more powerful.

The movie overall feels like a mix of elements taken from other films, which were way more succesful in their execution. For example the alien world is reminiscent of the enviroment from Avatar. Altough the landscapes are visually stunning and the alien wildlife can be very creative. It also seems to me like the movie is trying to use the Guardians of the Galaxy formula of 'misfits learning about caring for each other', but doesn't really provide a fresh take on it. It tries to imitate the Disney style of forced humor and having to have a talkative, quirky character, in the form of Thia, and a cute side character to be the protagonist's 'pet'. All of which we have already seen plenty of. The villain is also incredibly paper thin and cliché, like so many other plot points in this film.

All of these factors together form a movie experience that feels all too familiar and predictable to have any impact on you, despite the cool and interesting visuals. It's not something that you will completely regret spending your time watching, but you won't be able to recall what happened in this movie just a few hours after leaving the theaters...
label: literal

text:
When it comes to sheer entertainment value and visual beauty, 'Moana' knocks it out of the park Despite being a lifelong Disney fan, that is not to say that everything they've done is great. They've done many classics, their best revolutionary, though they had hit and miss periods in the 80s and the 2000s.

'Enchanted' and 'The Princess and the Frog' saw a return to form, while the likes of 'Tangled', 'Wreck It Ralph', 'Zootropolis' (aka 'Zootopia') and 'Frozen' were even better and there was a lot to like too about 'Big Hero 6'. Of the "2nd Renaissance"/"Disney Revival" period, 'Moana' is up there with the best of them and as one of Disney's best in about twenty years.

Maybe the momentum dips ever so slightly going into the final act, Maui's change of heart is a touch rushed and for me there was no real point to the pig character that induced more unintentional awkwardness than amusement. It was however difficult to fault 'Moana', because of how many things it did right and how brilliantly the things it did right were executed. There have been criticisms regarding a formulaic story, HeiHei the chicken being irritating and the portrayal of Maui being stereotypical, but these were criticisms that didn't bother me at all.

Firstly, the animation is phenomenal. Disney's best-looking film in a long time and one of their best-ever looking films, not just this but perhaps the most visually exquisite animated film this year in a year that also saw 'Your Name', 'Kubo' and 'Zootropolis' and even one of the year's best-looking films. The attention to detail is impossible to fault, whether it's the water, the trees or even Maui's tattoos, while the colours just pop out at you and everything is immaculately detailed with not an ounce of artificiality in the backgrounds, further boasting visually stunning sequences such as the climax, "We Know the Way", "Shiny" and with the coconut pirates.

The soundtrack has garnered a huge amount of praise, and for good reason. Love the evocative orchestration and instrumentation, with its seamless blend of South Pacific Culture, pop and Broadway. Likewise with the songs, which are along with 'Frozen' the best and most consistent set of songs from a Disney film since 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame'. "How Far I'll Go" is an "I want" sort of song that's infectious, heartfelt and inspiring. "You're Welcome" sees Dwayne Johnson showing a quite wide range of emotions through a surprisingly good singing voice. "Shiny" is deliciously kooky and like something that David Bowie would be proud of, Jemaine Clement sings the heck out of it. "We Know the Way" sends chills up the spine.

Scripting-wise, 'Moana' encompassed a wide emotional range within me. There is something for everybody, never too complicated for children and never too childish for adults, tonally it's focused throughout, and it's very witty and thought-provoking. Throughout there are many opportunities to laugh, cry and be inspired. The story is, while not exactly original, beautifully paced and enthralling.

The whole Polynesian culture, faith and seafaring traditions included and explored generously but in a way that feels part of the story rather than just thrown in, and while there are elements that reminds one of Disney past and present this feels more affectionate than Disney just running out of ideas. The coconut pirates scene may seem like filler, but instead of being incidental and dull filler it was entertaining and visually dazzling, while the musical numbers bring the storytelling forward and say much about the characters' motivations and the climax is hair-raising.

Moana is has now joined the list as one of my favourite female Disney characters, while Maui is a fun, compelling character and the chemistry between the two being a large part of the film's humour and heart. Personally found myself entertained by HeiHei and that his existence and role in the story were justified. If anybody does find him dumb or annoying, this is a rare of those not being bad things for a character clearly intended to be that way from reading up about the film. The voice acting is top notch, with Auli'i Cravalho making a startling debut (voice and singing, goodness she has pipes). Dwayne Johnson, on paper an unlikely and eyebrow-inducing choice, is also splendid, as an actor he's grown a lot, while Alan Tudyk is amusingly zesty and Jemaine Clement bringing gleefully kooky menace.

In summary, knocks it out of the park in visual beauty and sheer entertainment value, Disney does it again with their latest classic 'Moana'. 9/10 Bethany Cox
label: figurative

text:
Very Enjoyable-The lead actress is fantastic I had been looking forward to this series since it was announced, and I wasn't disappointed in the slightest. Suffice to say I binged watched it in 2 days.

The story caters, of course , to the modern audience, but it is not smothered by political correctness as most current shows are (which is a blessing). It is interesting, dark, and a blend of old and new, all wrapped in a fun Burton-esque way.

The lead actress is fantastic, she really captures the personality of Wednesday, she even nails the dead, cold but intense stare. But kudos should be given to the rest of the cast, because they do a great job as well,I loved Gwendoline Christie as the Head Mistress, she really plays ambiguous characters very well. Catherine Zeta-Jones and Luis Guzman are perfect in their roles, and the actress who portrays Enid (Emma Myers) nails the character.

Of course there are mistakes and inconsistencies (a rainy day suddenly becoming extra sunny, with no evidence of the previous rain at all, etc), but all in all, those mistakes don't negatively affect the quality of the series.

I really don't understand the viewers who compare it to the movies, and expect it to be the same. It can't be. It's been 30 years since the Addams Family movies, the world has changed, we are supposed to be moving forward and keeping up with the times. Please stop comparing old and new, "Wednesday" isn't a remake, it's a brand new series based on one of the characters, not the Addams Family as a whole. This series, pays a great homage to the original Addams Family, but it is firmly set in the present- as it should be.

Old and new can be equally worth your time, each one for its own merits.

8/10 from me, with the potential to go higher for the next season(s).
label: literal

text: Smiling Friends "Smiling Friends" is quite possibly the worst thing I've ever had the displeasure of wasting my time on. The supposed "humor" falls flat and is as predictable as the sun rising in the east. Avoid at all costs unless you want to subject yourself to 11 minutes of pure agony. text:
A Highly Unique, Original Series With so many jobs taking place in office buildings, this television series that is based on the Ricky Gervais created BBC series, takes aim at that and other aspects of the modern American workplace. Steve Carrell leads a large cast of talented actors that succeed in creating a smart, silly comedy that works.

Carrell is Michael Scott, the dim-witted boss of paper company Dunder Mifflin's Scranton, Pennsylvania branch. Rainn Wilson is Scott's odd second in command Dwight Shrute, a man who prides himself on knowledge of survival techniques and bears. Jim Krasinski is Jim Halpert, a salesman who has a crush on Pam(Jenna Schafer), the receptionist. These are only a few of the major characters in the ongoing, hilarious saga of Scranton at work.

Several story lines can take place in the course of a single episode, giving the show more chances at laughs. In one episode, for example, there are conflicts between members of the Party Planning Committee, Michael's usual antics of procrastination, and the secrets of two characters's affair. These just make the show more original than ones that have a single narrative.

Funny and intelligent, The Office is one brilliant spoof you should not miss.

text:
What did I watch. I like giving new shows a chance. There were two episodes of this on our DVR. We tried the first episode tonight.

I kept saying how good it was. That it seemed interesting. At the twenty-five- or thirty-minute mark, I said "this show is starting to get stupid." Then after some more time, I said "this is never going to make it." My mom and stepfather told me I didn't have to record any more. But I already have the second episode and don't like to give up right away.

The show just seems meaningless. I mean really, what was the point. No action. No drama. No comedy. Just mindless ramblings of words. It was useless.

There is a thing with him and a lady. I just rolled my eyes. I mean, is it going anywhere. To me, it just seems like there were a bunch of things put it to fill the time since there was no story at all.

There is no heart in it.

As I said, there is a second episode recorded and I had already set the third. But if the next is anything like the first, there is no way we are going to finish it. If the show has the rest of the season as the first was, I would be shocked it this makes it to a second or third season.

text: Solid - But No Empathy - Firstly watched with the daughter (16) and missus and they both enjoyed it more than me... reasons? Well the film is interesting premise, well acted, well shot... and dives into the walk straight away very little wiggle room. However I think where it falls down is once stuff happens... I simply didn't have any empathy with any of the characters and I';m not sure why? Pete is the strongest of them both in acting ability and character, however I found it difficult to be invested in what actually happens to 99% of the cast and that is a problem with a people film? As said in a previous review, I would also add, I think we needed to learn more about the world this was happening in DURING the walk... and things that had happened, maybe some short flashbacks just to flush this story out as right now, we barely know a thing. Now, does this really matter on this one? Possibly not, but as I wasn't invested in the people as much as I should've been, maybe knowing the heart ache and things that the lads had been through a little more and seeing it... and why we're really doing this walk would've helped. I also think, do they indeed get riches? What happens to previous winners? Os is this like the running man where they get walloped whether they win or lose? Who knows. Anyhow, solid film, missed opportunity but good performances and at least tries to do something new and refreshing in an era or poor Hollywood films.

text:
Strong potential but dull reality (so far) As a long-time fan of historical and occult mystery thriller shows (Frontier, X-Files) I was stoked for and in turn let down a bit by this one. The show itself has a ton of potential as the setting, visuals, sounds, cast and original premise are 10/10 and the first two episodes had me hooked for more (I'd give them 8/10), but then the quality of acting and writing drops severely and makes you become painfully aware of it. There is some improvement by 5th episode though which has me hoping the show can get itself back on track by the season finale.

EP1 - 2 8/10 EP3 - 4 4/10 EP5 - 6/10 EP6 - to be seen

+ Visuals, Setting, Cast, Premise


* Bad acting (antagonists, Emma), Bad writing (dull, you don't become emotionally invested), Unused potential of Navajo witches lore (much more chilling, look up r/skinwalkers subbreddit for more)


So far it's been like playing an RPG game and being able to equip your character with the most legendary set items right away yet lacking the ability to use even the most basic skills and combos to destroy your enemies. Matten and McClaron are stars-in-the-making and the premise is strong, if the show solves it's script problems it could become a hit by season 2, the potential is definitely there. In the meanwhile, I'd recommend watching S01E19 of X-Files for a proper show of paranormal crime story with a flair of societal commentary on the situation and treatment of native communities.
label: literal

many more..

There are some solid action sequences through out, but the finale left me incredibly disappointed. I've wanted to truly see Galactus on the big screen for so long and I would have been happier if I was still waiting. They absolutely butchered him as a character and that was the most disappointing part overall. There could have been so much more here, but what little there is comes across as generic and empty.

text:
An Above Average Easy Watch For the last month or so, I have been watching a new show on Disney Plus call Chad Powers and the finale was today and I have watched that so here is my review for the whole season of Chad Powers. The premise of the show sees a disgraced former quarter back aim to get back to playing football under a new identity.

Main Character Glen Powell is one of the hottest commodities in Hollywood at the moment and can pretty much pick any project he wants and he is Chad Powers. He is easily the best part of this show and his star power shines through some of the other elements of the show, he really delivers a mix between comedy and drama and really excels, especially at the surprising dramatic moments.

Supporting Characters Perry Matfield plays Ricky a female coach who takes a liking to Chad. Though there is more to her character then that, she is going through her own character arc and that works alongside the arc of Chad. The two of them have great chemistry and are a real highlight of the show.

Steve Zahn plays Coach Hudson and he is a fun character here. He is really feeling the pressure of being the coach of an American Football Team and he really sells it well. He is pretty charming but always on edge and it works for him.

Unfortunately, the rest of the cast aren't so good. Wynn Everett plays Tricia and she is super unlikeable. She sees herself above everybody else in the show but not in a charming way but in a way that made me dislike her character.

Frankie A. Rodriguez plays Danny and he is the closest friend to Chad and honestly I found him quite over the top and annoying for the most part. I just didn't really buy into their relationship and it is the one part of the show that didn't quite hit for me.

Story The story has some good character arcs that make you care about Chad and some of the people around him. The finale has some interesting turns that really subvert expectations of a show like this and I really appreciated that. However, this show is pretty predictable throughout and some of the character were pretty annoying throughout. Also, the ending of the show is disappointing and feels like it is just setting up a second season.

Script This show has some really surprising heartfelt moments that are written really well and flesh out the characters. But this show is focusing on comedy and I barely laughed throughout, the writing is weak and just not very funny which is a big shame when your show is mainly a comedy.

Style The show flies by with its pacing which is both good and bad. Certain episodes, especially when it focuses on the actual football, I really enjoyed the fast pace and way the show is shot. But at times it feels like it is rushing itself and doesn't give certain aspects of the show the time that it needs.

Overall Overall, Chad Powers is an above average show that has some potential. Some good performances and surprisingly heartfelt moments help this but it isn't funny enough or memorable enough to watch. If a second season gets announced then maybe give it a go as it is an easy and quick watch.

Rating - 6/10.
label: figurative

text:
Michael Scott meets Happy Gilmore The protagonist Ron makes me think of what you'd get if Michael Scott and Happy Gilmore had a baby. Off-color and off-target casually inappropriate office comments combined with barely controlled bouts of rage. The guy is a walking trainwreck, and I'm not sure why he was entrusted with a high-profile project. Still, it is funny at times.

The rest of Ron's co-workers are also similarly afflicted with farcical exaggerations of common maladies and also have wildly irrational reactions. "You handed me that envelope too hard."

Odd as it is to consider chair quality when watching a conspiracy show, Ron's inciting event seems very improbable. Several components of the chair seem to have failed at once. I've never seen anything even remotely close happen with even semi-modern office chairs. I have seen the reclining regulator fail on a chair once, causing the person to spill out backwards, but not several components catastrophically failing at once. Still, it was funny, and I suppose I'm over-thinking it since this is a comedy.

Ron also seems to be more than a little bipolar, and possibly an alcoholic. Two things that rarely go well together and might explain his unacceptable office behavior.

I'm at 6/10 after two episodes. The show is going to have to do something different soon to keep me watching.
label: figurative

text:
Another Hit for Taylor Sheridan When it comes to realism, most shows gloss over it while Taylor Sheridan embraces it. The oil and gas industry are not only dangerous in the field but in the board room as well. The risks are high and the rewards are too! Add in a splash of greed and a little hint of sex appeal and you have yourself a GREATLY addicting show!

Billy Bob Thornton and Jon Hamm have stellar performances as they embrace the Yin and Yang of this harsh industry. Let's not forget the ladies in the mix. They are truly the backbone of the series. Ali's character and Katy's character come from two different worlds but both eventually get a deeper glimpse behind the curtain as they step out onto the patch to see what life is truly like out there for the men in the field who risk it all.

This show gives us all a bit more appreciation for these thankless jobs done by some of the bravest people out there. It also doesn't shy away from the darker side of things either. There were so many times my heart leapt from my chest when a grand accident would occur. The aftermath of these things is often felt on so many levels including with myself as I sit here heartbroken for the characters affected.

The difference in this series versus Yellowstone is the intensity. Landman is a bit more lighthearted with Tommy's quips and his daughter's flimsy charms. The stakes are higher and on a larger scale but these characters are definitely on a more relatable scale. As a Texas gal, I can definitely say they hit the nail on the head with how they portray this life and I'm super excited to see where it all goes next!
label: literal

text:
Likable family film with plenty of amusing moments and the young cast are appealing. Tommy Smalls (Tom Guiry) is the new kid, who moved with his mother (Karen Allen) and his stepfather (Denis Leary) is a suburbans area of Salt Lake City in the summertime. When Smalls becomes curious with a group of kids (Mike Vitar, Patrick Renna, Chauncey Leopardi, Marty York, Brandon Quintin Adams, Grant Gelt, Shane Obedzinski and Victor DiMattia), who plays Baseball all day long in a old baseball field. Smalls is hoping to play with them but he knows nothing about the game. When he tries to play, he's quite bad at all. He can't even throw a ball to the catchers. When he becomes friend with the leader of the game and Smalls starting to like the game. But when his stepfather goes away for business, Smalls take a baseball from his stepfather trophy room. Which without realizing that the ball, he took from the room is actually signed by the Baseball Legend "Babe Ruth". Smalls hits his first home run, the ball went over the fence of a old house. But that old house, it has an mean-spirited junkyard dog. Which the kids called him "The Beast". Now the kids have to help Smalls to get the ball back before his stepfather comes back from the business trip.

Directed by David M. Evans (First Kid) made an likable family comedy that plenty of funny moments, a good cast and a lot of imagination. The narration of the film will certainly make you remember of the late Bob Clark film "A Christmas Story", although the narration of "The Sandlot" is sightly heavy-handed at times. This film has a surprise hit, when it was release in the spring of 1993. Fox had another fantasy film about Baseball, which it was "Rookie of the Year". James Earl Jones, Art LaFleur and a young Marley Shelton have memorable bit parts in this pleasant comedy as well.

DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (2.35:1) transfer (Also in Pan & Scan) and an good Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD also includes an featurette, trailer and TV spots. This film went on to be an modest classic over the year. All the kids have their moments, especially Renna and Leopardi have their comedic moments. The movie slows down a bit during the second act. But it's well made and this picture pleases everyone as well. It's one of the better family movies of the 1990's. Don't miss it. Co-Written by the director. Arliss Howard appears Unbilled. Followed by Two Direct to DVD's. Joe-Dunton-Camera Scope (J-D-C Scope). (****/*****).
label: figurative

text: It's a tired old space for..... I hope this isn't a spoiler but I'm sure you've seen the trailer...It's a "From Dusk till Dawn" ripoff that is looking for a new audience. There's no twists here. It's redeeming feature is it's time setting, 1930's, but once you get into the "bar" it's a genre piece with no new content. Using the same actor in "twin" roles has been done before and better. The rest of the casts' acting is solid enough but it runs out of steam well before it's 137min running time does. I saw it at the cinema and the soundscape was solid enough but that's not sufficiently engrossing to keep you anywhere near the edge of your seat. I've given it a six star rating which us possibly a bit generous, but we all love vampire movies don't we, even if there are more of them in films and series than us actually watching them these days. It's fun but it's nothing new to the genre so don't go in with high expectations, and you'll not be let down. I wasn't looking at my watch but I would have missed nothing if I left to get some popcorn. My brother gave it a 7, but he's a generous chap. It'll be streaming somewhere soon so don't rush out but if you wanna go to the movies, you could definitely do a lot worse.

text:
Uncomfortable, Unlikable and Frustrating IF I HAD LEGS ID KICK YOU I

Oh how much I wanted to like this. Rose Byrne is one of my favs.

One of the more frustrating and uncomfortable films of this year, If I Had Legs Id Kick You is an exercise in exasperation. Rose Byrne one of the finest actresses today does everything she can but the central character is incredibly unlikable that it's misguided that the film thinks there's anything sympathetic about her story. Mary Bronstein goes intense and raw but comes up with a very awkwardly miserable drama.

Why was everyone in this film so rude, crass and unlikable?

The kid was incredibly unlikeable.

Doesn't really give the therapy system a good overview does it? I mean the lead character's treatment of her patients is beyond unprofessional and mean.

The lead - where does one start - she was just mean. Having mental health issues doesn't give someone a justification to be cruel, rude and mean spirited and she is throughout the entire movie. That's the issue - there's nothing sympathetic about what she's going through.

It's irresponsible.

text:
I wanted to hate it. Every time we've been to the cinema the past few months and the Wicked trailer came on my wife got child like giddy because she loves the show and I've thought 'oh God that's one of those I have to sit through because to be fair she sits through most of mine moments'. So I've been counting the days and dreading, and when I heard the runtime I was even more distraught. I wanted to hate this movie with every bone in my body for a few reasons.

1. Not a fan of musicals (but I can grimace through them sometimes).

2. I love Wizard of Oz in its purest form and didn't want the legacy of it spoiling.

3. My wife's choices of films are more often than not 'questionable'.

4. Two hours plus in a cinema seat these days doesn't do my back any good at my age.

5. Ariana Grande.

Now being a realist my first impression of the movie might be a little offset because I went in with such low expectations as I've done this before on numerous occasions, but call me a softy in my old age (I'm 47) I absolutley loved it!!! Everything from the phenomenal soundtrack, set design, make up, costumes,comedy elements, character design etc...i could go on, you get the gist. It was brilliant, I may even go watching it again (the highest accolade I can give for a two hours plus movie) and I can't wait for part 2. A few purists have got thier complaints and gripes which there will always be on adaptations of previous pre-loved formats. But no complaints here, just a very good, well made movie. Wizard of Oz's legacy intact.

One more point...Ariana Grande steals it for me. Perfect casting!!!

The pace of the show is rushed. The acting of the main support in the cast, her atagonist, looks like he is tired of the script and doesn't believe in the character he is playing, and that comes through in his acting.

The plots are highly contrived and don't give you the sense the main character had to do much to crack them, thus making the plots lightweight and trivial. Nothing happens to give the watcher a "wow" moment.

text:
One of the best movies of the year OK, I just got back from seeing it. Overall, I loved it. I think it's one of the best movies of 2025

Firstly - I'll note that I know nothing about the book by Stephen King. Thus, I entered this movie with a blank slate about the subject matter, and I have no comparisons between the movie and book. I don't know if that detail made the movie better or worse for me.

Anyways - the premise of the movie, for me, is interesting and original; I can't say that I recall too many movies like this one (though there are elements of movies /shows like Squid Game). The general vibe is unique. It's neither a war movie or a road trip movie, yet it actually has the atmosphere of both sub-genres mixed into one, which works

The 2 lead characters - Ray and Pete - are likable; and their friendship (which forms the crux of the movie) is touching. With this premise, a major concern was that the movie might get dull after the first 30 minutes or so: how interesting can you make a long walk appear on-screen? But the movie skillfully manages to keep a good pace with the charming and well-written dialogue or banter between the various characters.

The movie occurs on a nondescript road in a nondescript area, yet there are still some scenes where the setting appears scenic and elegant. There's a lot of gore and gross scenes relating to human excrement. I could see an argument that some of those scenes are gratituitious. But I feel those scenes helped set the ominous atmosphere. Additionally, Mark Hamill is alright as the villain, though one attempt to give info about his background seems forced (it happens near the end. I don't want to spoil and say more)

The ending is ambiguous, which might not work for some. But I like it: I think the ending is open for interpretation. And it will hit your emotional strings unless you have no soul.

In terms of flaws - I have just one. As I said, the movie manages to keep a good pace in spite of the monotonous premise relating to a long walk. But still - the last 25% of the movie includes some repetitive scenes. What happens is that someone on the walk freaks out or gets close to dropping out, and the 2 lead protagonists jump in to save the day or console them. Then the character who drops out gets an emotional death. I feel they should have cut one or two of these scenes to eliminate retread

Still, one of the best movies of 2025

10/10.
label: literal

text:
unfunny sex comedy In Victorian London, Josephie Pacefoot (Joanna Pettet) leads the purity girls in demanding reform to save women from sex work. Flying enthusiast Benjamin Oakes (David Hemmings) comes to the rescue of Josephie and her fallen women. Various recollection of women 'suffering' their poor indignities perpetrated by men sometimes played by David Hemmings. He has an evil doppelganger.

It's a sex comedy and it's an odd one. The central theme is that these women are being taken advantaged by these men. In the recreations, the women are gleefully being 'taken advantaged'. It's not a funny joke. The choppy nature of the film doesn't help. It's one vignette after another and few are even mildly funny. I don't care about Josephie and Benjamin. The plot does sometimes take interesting turns, but I still don't care. It's an unfunny sex comedy.

text:
for what it is, an excellent film I'm pretty surprised that this film is rated as low on IMDb as it is--especially since this is one of Arnold's better films. I think part of the problem is that some people MIGHT be looking at the film from a superficial and purely aesthetic level, whereas I see a lot more depth in this movie than many viewers. Yes the film is violent and dopey but that's exactly the point! Just like the original (and only one worth watching) ROLLERBALL, the film was dismissed by some because of the film's violence and seeming banality whereas the film really is a great indictment about society. And, on that level, the film is great. I could actually see people in our country, especially in the near future, intoxicated by the violence of a show dedicated to watching men die. Is this really that much of a leap from Jerry Springer and the evening news? 

And, if you look at the film technically, it's well-made. Arnold is just fine with this role, the direction is great, Steven King's story is excellent and Richard Dawson just steals the show as the sleazy and creepy host of this show dedicated to making capital punishment a spectator sport! 

So, try watching this film and think to yourself--could this really make it on TV? I think YES, as our world really isn't that far removed from the Romans and their Coliseums.

UPDATE--I just saw this movie again and I think my original review was too optimistic. While I had given it a 9, now I think 6 or 7 is probably more accurate. While I agree there is some good social commentary, the film had too many holes and silly plot points when I saw it again. Still, not bad brain candy.
label: figurative

text:
The American James Bond... ...is this movie in a nutshell. It has everything: Gadgets, Cars, Women, Guns, a doomsday device and a rich villain with many soldiers for our hero to kill.

The cinematography and editing is very good, mostly for the action sequences and (still) very impressive stunts.

Also the special and visual effects are top notch for a movie from 2002.

The style however is typical...typical Rob Cohen...typical early- 2000's EXTREME-nes. The music for example is pure early 2000's rock and hasn't aged that well, but the orchestral soundtrack is not that bad.

The story is interesting and never get's dull, so that it's entertaining all the way through.

It's a fun action movie, with a very entertaining lead and some incredibly impressive stunts...

text:
Some of you missed the point SPOILERS AHEAD! Watch movie before reading.

Joe and Brian are foils for each other.

Both are seemingly emasculated by their respective love interest; have internalized conflict with their love interest's ex; both try to frame said exes because they are jealous and insecure. Brian and Joe want to be wanted, needed even, as men and dignitaries.

Both are radicalized through performative social justice posturing on the opposite sides of the pandemic: Brian- BLM/activism, Joe- Covid19 denier/police.

The ending is purely ironic; Brian gets everything that Joe had tried to get for himself: fame, fortune, family. Joe instead garners infamy for police brutality, is abandoned by his wife, and ultimately gets a life sentence of being jailed inside his paralyzed body, and despite actually becoming mayor on paper he is just a puppet for his conspiracy-theorist mother-in-law who becomes his conservator.

Besides all of that, the movie's subplot is about indigenous land rights being turned over to AI Data Centers under false pretenses. If the pandemic doesn't kill the people of Eddington now, this business deal will kill them later. And, at the end of the day, politicians are still politicians and are purely motivated by money- meaning, they have no idea what bills they are signing, they just know they're going to get paid and the people paying them will fund their campaign.

Also, a walking-talking Covid spore comes to town and not a single person quarantines him; he is the physical embodiment of the virus and everybody is too busy to consider that he is a herald of death.

Also, the acting, directing, cinematography were brilliant, as well as the writing itself. This movie is deeply unnerving, and it's visceral. Ari Aster and company once again do not waste a moment of screen time. This movie has layers between layers of nuance, symbolism, etc. One viewing may not be enough as there are lots of clues that if you blink you just might miss them.

TL;DR: White Male Inferiority Complex Heightened by the Pandemic and the Spotlight for Black Lives Matters Movement. Tech Bros and AI are Unconscionable- Preying on Isolated Communities Through False Advertisement and Political Gains. Great Movie.
label: figurative

text:
TMS As a big fan of Apple, I'm ashamed to say I've come relatively late to the party in terms of AppleTV+ and I'm really regretting that. Barring one underperforming title (Greyhound) the three shows I've watched have been varying degrees of spectacular. Mythic Quest? Great fun. Ted Lasso? Feel good winner of a comedy that I fell in love with. Now coming to The Morning Show and... Wow. MQ and Lasso bring a lot of fun but TMS is a slow burning show that knows how to hit the audience right in the feels, grab hold and not let go. By the time TMS hits its stride it is not only tremendously prescient, relevant television but it is gripping and heart-stopping. The characters are rich and developed, it's filmed beautifully, it twists and turns in ways that feel entirely earned and realistic and the ending (of season one) is just breathtaking.

I love a good slow show that takes its time building to where it wants to be, I do feel like TMS starts a little slower than I'd like, hence the not quite perfect rating, but this really is stunning once it hits its stride. I feel like, with TMS added to the growing list of great content, Apple TV+ is turning into this sleeping dragon of a streaming platform that sooner or later people are going to wake up to and realize how stunningly good it is.

All that said, this addresses the #MeToo movement and it doesn't pull punches so if you're worried about being triggered, be warned.
label: figurative

text:
A strong story with great performances that completely falls apart at the end. The trailer for Bugonia looked unique, the vibe was weird in a good way, and honestly, the second I saw Emma Stone and Jesse Plemons were in it, I was in. That alone sold me. I didn't know much else and didn't really need to.

Teddy (Jesse Plemons) is a guy who's gone way too far down the internet conspiracy hole. Not the funny meme side of it... the "connects everything to everything" side. The "none of us can talk him out of this anymore" side. And on top of that, he's also just not all there mentally. So when he decides that Michelle (Emma Stone), a powerful CEO, is secretly an alien trying to destroy Earth... he acts on it.

From there, the movie becomes a tense back-and-forth of is Teddy right, or is he completely gone?

The whole time, you're wondering how (or if) Michelle is going to escape.

It's suspenseful in a way that actually works.

And the acting? So good.

Jesse Plemons absolutely nails the "calm but deeply broken" thing.

Emma Stone plays Michelle with this perfect balance of control, fear, and "don't mess with me."

For most of the movie, I was totally locked in. Interested. Curious where it was going. The dialogue was sharp, the pacing was tight, and I really wanted to see how it would all play out.
label: figurative

text:
Hopefully just the Warm-up I love everything about IT from the book to Pennyside to the movies, so yeah I was all in, and I was satisfied with this new introduction. But this was a little bit... "inadequate" and "too much" at the same time. Just a little bit.

My main problem is with the killings. The first character that we are introduced to gets killed instantly. Okay, the writers, directors and producers want this to look brutal and serious, get it. Or they just want to "hook" the viewer, idk. But the third, fourth and fifth "main" characters also get killed, all at the same time. Fom the first episode, 4 characters, who were intoduced as if they were main characters, get killed. 4 deaths in one episode. How many characters will there be in this series, if killings continue with this frequency? It will just be impossible to follow - unless, none of them were "main" characters, except for the two girls, and this was just a warm-up. Which still doesn't add anything to the story... My second issue is with the "military". Now, military and soldiers had incredibly minor references in the book. Why is military such a huge part of the series now? It feels completely disconnected. I felt like I was watching two totally seperate shows. I know the writers will patch the two stories together at one point and make it "meaningful", but it still doesn't deliver. Don't get me wrong, the military part has its own pace and moments for itself; but it felt "unnecessary".

Oh and the baby-demon looked awfully fake, sorry. Practical effects instead of digital ones would have done a lot better job.

Still, I'm happy and hyped to see Pennywise again.
label: literal

Goes without saying the scenery benefits from 40 ears distance and vastly superior technical possibilities (probably with a bigger budget also, relatively speaking), yet the atmosphere of the place the 1975 Poldark created can be immediately rediscovered.

The cast is alright, some pluses, some minuses for the corresponding characters in the Poldark of yore (I like a lot the new Prudie!).

Looking forward for the next episodes. The new Poldark might prove to be a hit and stand up along with the formidable old one in future's references. We'll be watching.

text:
This is not a NCIS show While this show has its merits, it seems to lack some qualities that have made the NCIS franchise so beloved among fans. The sense of belonging and the theme of found family, cherished in the NCIS series, are somewhat missing here, and the overall tone feels quite dark. Many viewers appreciate the lightheartedness of the original NCIS shows, so perhaps considering a revival of NCIS: Hawaii or New Orleans could be beneficial.

Additionally, exploring more profound character development might be helpful, as some characters feel less engaging than expected. There also appear to be some inconsistencies in the timeline and various plot points that could leave viewers puzzled.

On a side note, while pagers reflect an earlier time, it might be worth reconsidering how frequently they are featured in episodes. A balanced approach could enhance the viewing experience for a wider audience.

She constantly lies to her closest friends, family.. her daughters, who are the only thing she seems to actually care about for real, for brief periods. Aside from perhaps her job, which I think is what pulls you back time & time again - her ability to care and fight for her patients. So funny she doesn't put that effort into her own life. So many great filming techniques to tie themes/scenes together. Smart TV.

The characters are lovable, and remind you of people in your own life. The jokes are funny, the lows are lows. It really puts into perspective (in sometimes campy ways) what life with an addict can be.

text: Not a Classic, The Classic This is the quintessential coming of age moving for so many including myself. text: An Utter Slogfest I'm sure this movie resonates with plenty people out there but I found it tedious, dull and pretentious. It fails to get out of first gear, and although the acting is decent, neither Lawrence nor Pattinson seemed to be in the least bit challenged. The only reason I could figure for those two signing up for this was to work with each other. To label it a dark comedy is ridiculous. There were at best 2 chuckle moments in the entirety. I kept hanging on for something to pull me in and make me the least bit interested but it never materialized. The Joy Division cover for the end credits seemed well out of place and felt pretentious in the extreme. Not sure why anyone ever thought this would make a good movie. It's not.

text:
Honestly didn't think this show would turn out this fantastic! When I first picked up on the series, I was busy as hell. I had 3 different projects I was working on and had to study for my upcoming exams the week after. Despite all that going on, this show always did manage to brighten my day. 

Now I know it may not look like it yet, but I believe that a show like One Punch Man deserves a spot in the hall of great TV shows alongside other giants in both real-life shows as well as anime and cartoons. I know I'm not the only one who thinks that the characters this show has are all undeniably and magnificently thought-out. Not to mention that their development is expertly and appropriately paced. The main character "Saitama" and his self-appointed student "Genos" including the rest of the supporting roles in the story are skillfully coordinated and the art style and animation go along so perfectly with the show's hilarious comedic elements.

I understand why about one person out of a hundred people wouldn't appreciate something like this. People have their own preferences, though I feel that most of the people that disregard One Punch Man and address it as synonymous as either Satan or watching those ten- hour long versions of music videos on Youtube are simply doing it out of spite for the mainstream or joining in the recently banded mini circle-jerk against a show that the majority of people find amazing and is clearly doing very well worldwide. There will always be that half a percent of negative Nancys I suppose.

I only wish I had more time to properly convey my thoughts of this show into the mind of the reader right now. Yes, I'm talking about you, random citizen!
label: literal

text: As good as everyone says it is This show is as good as advertised. I've never heard of the books so I had no expectations going in so I'm pleasantly surprised by how much I like this. Zahn McClarnon has been good in just about everything he's ever been in but he's finally given a chance to be a lead and he excels at it. I could actually see him getting nominated for an Emmy for his work here, he's that good. Kiowa Gordon is an unknown actor who also does an excellent job and should have plenty of opportunities and a bright career after this. The rest of the cast (Noah Emmerich, Rainn Wilson, Jessica Matten, A Martinez, Jenna Elfman, etc) all hold their own here too. There are not many shows built around Native Americans so I'm glad this one didn't flame out and disappoint.
label: literal

text:
Why "I didn't Want This" Honestly, it's not worth the hype. I understand why everyone would be so excited about this show. Adam Brody, Kristen Bell, two adults falling in love and working their way up by being honest with each other as the plot, all of these elements would make a cute rom-com. (My sole reason to watch the show is Adam Brody.) But this one disappointed me. Here's why: This is a rom-com, so there should be comedy, but almost all the time, I felt like the humorous parts in the dialogues were put there for the sake of comedy, which didn't feel natural.

I don't know much about the Jewish culture in America, but still, I don't think their portrayal in the show was appropriate, even for the purpose of comedy.

The main tagline for the promotion of this show was "two adults falling in love." The Rabbi was more like a therapist than a spiritual leader. It's Joanne character that gave me the "ick." She's between 35 and 40, yet she behaves like she's in her early 20s. Here are some questions I have: * After all those years of dating, why was Noah reluctant to marry Rebecca?

* How did he like Joanne immediately and decide to go for her right away? Which character traits of Joanne interested him?

* In what particular way did Joanne parents being separated and her Dad being gay affect Joanne relationship skills?

* Most of the time, Noah is portrayed as an empathetic person who seemed to understand what Joanne was going through and ease her out of that. But most other times, he wasn't, like when he asked her about converting.

* So what was the point or the theme? Is it "love conquers all" or "when a Jewish man loves a non-Jewish woman"? I am not sure.

Since Adam Brody and Kristen Bell got their niche characters respectively (maybe another actor to play Joanne would have been nice), Noah was more defined than Joanne. Joanne, as well as her sister Morag, lacked character depth, appearing too shallow to be clear about what they stand for in their podcast.

I am sure the show worked for the targeted audience, but I am a bit disappointed because I like both Brody and Bell from "Kid Detective" and "The Good Place" respectively. I expected a show that portrays relationships more in depth. And sadly, I didn't feel the chemistry between Noah and Joanne.

In conclusion, the script lacks authenticity due to shallow writing, predictable plot, and depthless characters. It could have been just a movie.
label: figurative

text:
Magic and Character development were lacking, but surprises entertained It is very important to realize that this movie must not be spoiled. I will not be discussing anything not shown in the trailers, and I ask you not to go looking for such secrets online, but only by watching it yourself. This movie is designed to entertain, and to a degree it does just that.

I haven't seen many of Leterrier's films, but I enjoyed this about as much as The Incredible Hulk, but more than Clash of the Titans. There were still disappointments. Magic movies have been a great interest of mine, and from the trailer I had to wonder, does Michael Caine + woman in a tank = The Prestige? Truthfully, the similarities stopped there, including magic's screen time.

Despite magic taking up most of the trailers, it was too scarce in the film itself. I wanted more magic. I know that doing so would take screen time from Ruffalo, but he wasn't the best of the bunch. In fact, they were Freeman, Caine, and Laurent, respectively.

The screen writing didn't allow for many to develop character well. The Four Horsemen were usually smooth-talking brick walls. And was that Dave Franco I saw? He had no screen time! (except for brief fancy dodging falling fighting)

These character holes would be acceptable if the movie were a large show. But as mentioned before, magic only came in smaller pieces, when at all. Some were amazing, some were old already, and some were hilarious.

It seems like I didn't appreciate the movie much, but I could only talk about what I didn't like. The rest, the secrets, I loved but can't talk about. Suffice it to say that many surprises are in store, and they're worth watching the movie for. That said, it's best to go in without guessing and predicting, because seeing the many reveals is where most of the entertainment lies. Don't spoil it for yourself.

This is a film some would be happier seeing in theatres, but if you don't think you'd spend ticket money for this, you'd probably regret it, so wait for DVD.

As a warning, there is a suggestive/inappropriate scene near the beginning that ends up going nowhere, but children's eyes should be turned aside. Also, there's a moment in a Mardi Gras parade that needs to be avoided, and minor language throughout. I'd recommend this movie for 17+, not only for these, but for the understanding of the secret material I can't bring up.
label: literal

text:
One trick pony. I watched episode one and thought it clunky, so I took a break. Came back later, switched my brain off, and suddenly it worked , like sinking into a warm bath: pleasant, undemanding, and slightly tepid.

The premise? Entertaining enough. The execution? A one-trick pony. Russ is a bad man who redeems himself through the miracle of prosthetic makeup , because nothing says "fresh start" like a new face. Each episode plays a variation of "Will his disguise fall off?" , I got stung! I got soaked! I nearly used the communal shower! , rinse and repeat until absurdity looms. ("Oh no, my face melted over a candle!" "Help, a hamster's eaten it!").

My only real gripe? It stops at episode six, just when a couple more might've tied things up properly. But I fear we're heading for a second series of "Chad and My Face Nearly Slipped." If only they'd resisted the American urge to flog the horse till it collapses. Ten solid episodes, story complete, applause all round , that's how you make something memorable.
label: figurative

text:
Satire at its finest Overall, the film was very interesting. It had great satire about the major outbreak of Covid in 2020. Not just bashing one side, but looking at the craziness happening on both side sides of the aisle. As with most a24 films was very thought-provoking and very satirical of the society surrounding the events it was covering.

The characters were great. Joaquin Phoenix is the stereotypical more conservative, leaning older person. Pedro Pascal plays a great slimy politician, who says one thing, but does another. The side characters in this film were great bringing a lot of variety and some funny moments to the film. I feel Austin Butler was under utilized.

The story was very satirical of the major outbreak of coronavirus in 2020. Initially, it started off very strong slowly becoming more and more tedious however, just as the TDM started to get annoying it goes from 0-60 in seconds. After some crazy events, it turns into an all out war with excitement around every corner.

In terms of production value, I didn't see anything that stood out. A24 is a great production company so their production value is always top-notch.
label: literal

text:
"You cried during my movie and you gave it a 7/10?" "You cried during my movie and you gave it a 7/10?"

During a livestream reacting to rapper Joey Bada$$' 2022 '2000' album, the self-proclaimed "internet's busiest music nerd" Anthony Fantano cried during the song "Survivor's Guilt". In his review, Fantano gave the album a 7/10, to which Bada$$ said in a later interview with Fantano a more musically-inclined version of the aforementioned quote. To Fantano, moments of '2000' struck hard, yet the whole body of work did not reach the same highs as "Survivor's Guilt".

That is how I feel about "The Long Walk", an adaptation of Stephen King's first written (not first published) book of the same title. I won't sugarcoat it and I will admit that I cried at several points throughout the film. The movie does a great job at making you invested into the core four characters, causing the inevitable deaths of the losers sting. The bond between Pete and Ray was especially strong. There were many moments during their walk where one of them (usually Ray) was ready to give up, but the other would pick his friend up and rally the other on. The scene where Ray confesses to Pete what his wish would be if he won was a particular highlight showing the friends' bond, as well as the one early on in their trek where they are going up the steep hill late at night. The latter is probably my nomination for the best scene in the whole movie, largely because the number of deaths there was being the highest among any other moment during the walk. The cacophony caused by the sheer number of eliminations late at night added to the quality of the scene. The ending hit on mostly all cylinders and was when I cried the hardest due largely to who the movie chose as the finalists. You can probably imagine who the finalists are by who I've discussed the most in this review, but the results are different in the book, surprisingly enough. While I have my gripes with the results, which I'll get to in a second, I applaud the screenplay for revising the ending.

To go off that point, I think the dynamics resonate on a very deep level with the audience. The performances between Cooper Hoffman's "Raymond" and David Jonsson's "Peter" really penetrate your porcelain heart and make you a sappy guy: Or maybe that was just me, I don't know. Seeing the duo work through thick and thin to protect each other's backside reminds the audience of the good in humanity, even despite how down the world might try to keep us. The story is inherently of perseverance and of human heart, and the bond between the two leads is so infectious that you want to do better yourself after walking out the theater onto your own long walk to your car.

Regarding more technical aspects of the film, I liked how the conflict between rationality and irrationally is displayed. Many of the players believe they're acting rationally in how they sacrifice themselves, but in reality their decisions just lead to the game continuing unhindered. Late into the walk, one of the final five, who had previously been collected and self-isolating to prevent creating attachments, abruptly charged at one of the officers and killed the latter with his own rifle, resulting in the player's own demise. The player may have thought his decision was rational in ending the game for him and the other survivors, but he ultimately was reckless and got himself killed in the process. It's very Kafkaesque, if I do say so myself.

I did compare my thoughts of this movie to Anthony Fantano's review of '2000', so this review, naturally, will not be all sunshine and rainbows. For starters, the movie is left with a bunch of loose ends; for instance, Hank and Arthur's requests could never be fulfilled by the other two Musketeers. Hank's wife will never be supported by the winner because of how he reacts to seeing his friend get shot in the head, and Arthur's grandmother will never get his grandson's cross necklace because, well, she can't. Other important dialogue, like Ray's feet having to walk socks-only on his blistered feet, is brushed away and never addressed later. When all the boys meet at the starting point, Pete and Ray discuss how they might have trouble lasting because of their weight, yet they're the final two. Furthermore, some weighty scenes may have been more impactful if there was more pay-off. For most of the movie, Hank has his hand slouched inside his coat. I thought his hand was hit by a stray bullet during the first night; instead, he just had his hand positioned like that for no real reason. I thought his death could have been much more severe if he stuck out a mauled, gruesome hand as he bled out.

The dynamic between Pete and Ray really carries the movie. It's so good, in fact, that it saves a flawed movie. I feel like the emotion their relationship cultivates deceives the audience with how much is wrong with the film, thus why I feel like it has such a high score. I still think a lot is right with the film and I think the score is appropriate given the emotions it elicited from me.
label: figurative

text:
Francis Lawrence pares down King's dystopia but leaves little beneath the surface The dystopian young adult genre dominated the 2010s, but like most trends, it quickly burned out. Oversaturation left audiences weary after an endless barrage of near-identical stories. While a few franchises, most notably The Hunger Games with its recent spin-offs, have tried to keep the fire alive, viewers largely moved on. Francis Lawrence, who directed every Hunger Games installment except the first, is determined to prove the subgenre still has life, returning with a new adaptation of Stephen King's The Long Walk (2025).

Set in a bleak America, the story follows a group of teenage boys conscripted through a lottery into a brutal national event: the Long Walk. The rules are merciless. Keep pace or be executed by the armed escorts led by the Major (Mark Hamill). The prize is immense wealth; the price is certain death for everyone but one. Among the walkers are Raymond (Cooper Hoffman) and Peter (David Jonsson), who forge a fragile friendship as they march toward oblivion.

The premise inevitably recalls The Hunger Games: state-sanctioned violence against youth, broadcast as national entertainment. That resemblance isn't coincidental. King's novel, written in 1979, is often cited as a major influence on Suzanne Collins' bestselling series. Both works are meditations on the expendability of young men in unpopular wars-Vietnam in The Long Walk, Iraq in The Hunger Games-and on how televised images of conflict desensitize the public. Collins sharpened her critique through reality-TV satire, while Lawrence here strips King's story to its bare essentials: walk, endure, survive.

That pared-down focus is both strength and weakness. On one hand, the simplicity prevents the film from collapsing under self-importance, and its moments of tension-an untied shoe, a stumble that threatens to be fatal-are sharp and effective. On the other, the narrative offers little depth beyond its surface. Deaths become predictable, telegraphed by who gets dialogue and who doesn't, and stretches of the film sag under the weight of its own monotony. Lawrence stages the executions with blunt cruelty, wisely avoiding glamorization, but the repetition leaves the film dragging.

What rescues The Long Walk from mediocrity are its leads. Hoffman, son of the late Philip Seymour Hoffman-whose final screen work was under Lawrence's direction-delivers a performance of quiet charisma, making Raymond a believable everyman. Jonsson, meanwhile, builds on his eclectic résumé (Rye Lane (2023), Alien: Romulus (2024)) with a portrayal brimming with warmth and unforced optimism. He commands the screen with ease and suggests an actor ready for more demanding roles. Together, the pair lend the film an emotional center it would otherwise lack.

Ultimately, The Long Walk is a lean but limited entry in the dystopian YA canon. Its premise remains compelling, but Lawrence's refusal to probe beyond the basics leaves too many unanswered questions and too much dead air between jolts of tension. Still, the central friendship-brought vividly to life by Hoffman and Jonsson-provides enough heart to carry the film further than its thin script deserves.
label: literal

The storyline was brilliantly well written and perfectly played by all the actors.

But hats off for Kelly Reilly (Beth), she was THE badass of the show from the begin to the end she was perfect, woman and men at same time.

Luke Grimes (Kayce) was my second favorite, the calmest and the brute when his family was is danger, i found funny his hair was always changing during the seasons i found that "cute" (btw, he was the cutest haha, right after his kid) Brecken Merrill (Tate) he had grown so much between seasons, the same for Finn Little (Carter) he was so different that i though another was playing Carter.

But sad, for the end i was not expected Kevin Costner (John) to died, i almost thought that is was a trap for Wes Bentley (Jamie ) but unfortunately it was not, i saw later that it was Kevin leaving the show.

But in summary, it was a mix from Succession (family problems, legacy) and Sons of Anarchy (revenges, killing the other, protect the family) and then later, i understood why = Taylor Sheridan (Travis) was the creator of the show, and from other Spin Offs 1883 and 1923.

Another show to repeat.

text: Really enjoyable, a nice break from the world I really hope this one lasts. The actors are good, and so is the writing. Of course, we're only into the 2nd episode, so it remains to be seen whether the premise can be maintained over time, but I think they have a good chance. This isn't high art, it's not going to change the landscape of television cop shows, but it will entertain you for an hour with good people trying to work together to solve crimes. There is a little push-back against having "the cleaning lady" help solve crimes, but egos get put aside for the greater good (at least so far). It's fun trying to pick up on the clues. The main character could be played a number of different ways that would be much less effective. Too upbeat, too tough, too "trampy", too arrogant,...She's just a single mom with a skill she didn't ask for, trying to do the best she can. She's just who she is, and doesn't apologize for it, but isn't pushy about it, either. She's kind but doesn't take any crap. As with a lot of these types of shows, she has a back story that motivates her to help the police. I'm so happy to see Judy Reyes again! She's great in this! I'm sorry if this is rambling -- long COVID-induced brain fog, among other things, so my writing and descriptive abilities have declined. I'm just enjoying this show so much that I felt I wanted to give it a shout out, hoping others may enjoy it, too!!
label: literal

text:
Psychological Overture Let me start by saying this is going to give you some serious deja vu to psychological thrillers like the SAW series and mind twisters like Kidnapped.

So the show starts out with a suspect being sentenced for the murder of FBI agent Emily Byrne(Stana Katic). Meanwhile you keep getting these flashes of her being tortured. So than the show fast forwards to six years later where her ex husband is remarried to her sister, and her son is living with them. Her husband gets a call telling him where to find her still alive! He of course rushes over to where the caller told him she would be and sure enough there she is, in a tub filled with water and a lock. From there the story just starts to build.

I have very rarely seen such a good performance as Stana gave in this role, it's hard enough to pull off being abused but she looks exactly how you would imagine someone would look if they were starved and tortured for 6 years. So far 10/10, supremely strong start, the acting, plot and atmosphere is right on point. And the support cast is doing a fantastic job so far.

Update: So I figured in season 1 they were done with all the twists and turns and in season 2 we could finally get on with some rebuilding, which is the nature of shows like this actually getting some light before going back dark. Nope, it just keeps getting darker and darker. And here's the problem, with a show that was already on the very edge of disturbing going even darker makes it worse, not better. Because now you're not actually rooting for anyone anymore. This is one of the things that the showrunners need to understand and they don't seem to, in the first season you have sympathy, in the second one you don't. So now it's just more of the same mind bending with no one really caring about happens. This show for me took a nose dive from a 10 to a 3 in the span of 1 season. Shame, it had potential and they squandered it.
label: literal
