text:
Cheesy, prophetic, and classic! The Running Man is often dismissed as being just another Arnie action thriller full of explosions, bad puns and gunfire, and to be fair, there is a lot of that in it. People used to look at it and compare it to the Terminator series, saying it was one of the poorer Schwarzenegger films.

But, give it 18 years, and you find yourself being able to appreciate it in a different light. Rather than just being another brainless action film, it works very well as a parody of reality TV. It is quite different to the Stephen King book, true, but I doubt whether Hollywood, with its love of upbeat endings and so-called 'ordinary guys' who turned out to have the skills of a trained commando, would have accepted it in its current form.

But, on with the review.

Ben Richards (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is a cop working in a dystopian United States where democracy is a thing of the past, and the entire country is ruled by a government/media conglomerate amalgamation. The economy is in tatters, food is scarce and the state keeps people distracted by producing sadistic gameshows for them to watch, like Jumping for Dollars, where people jump for money over a pit of rabid dogs, and the most popular one is The Running Man, a gameshow hosted by the slimy Damian Killian (played by the entertaining Richard Dawson) where supposed 'criminals' are hunted down by theatrical, pro-wresting-esquire 'stalkers'.

Some, however, try and speak up against the government. When a group of hungry people hold a protest in the town of Bakersfield, California, a helicopter piloted by Richards is sent to 'calm' (i.e. kill) the protest. When Richards refuses to fire on innocent people, he is arrested and framed for the murder of the people in the crowd. He is sentenced to a slave labour camp, but escapes with the aid of a resistance leader (Yaphet Kotto) and goes on the run.

However, his freedom does not last long, and after he kidnaps network employee Amber Mendez (Marita Conchita Alonso) in an attempt to escape those pursuing him, he finds himself taken prisoner again, but this time he is forced to appear on The Running Man.

And there, of course, the entire film kicks into standard Arnie mode. Richards is launched into the post-apocalyptic wasteland of Los Angeles (why is LA always destroyed in these dystopian worlds?) and forced to run from the 'stalkers', along with two other prisoners who escaped from the labour camp with him. Amber also becomes curious about Richards' protestations of innocence, and discovers he was framed. Guess what happens to her, then? So, as Amber, Richards and the two other guys run around trying to avoid the stalkers, we soon become aware that Richards is no ordinary cop. He's Super Arnie, the unkillable one man army who can collapse evil corporate dictatorships and fight obese men covered in Christmas lights all while being just your average American guy with an Austrian accent.

Yes, the remainder of the film becomes dumb, loud, classic 80's Arnie fun. There's a lot of exciting fight sequences, the trademark dreadful puns ('He had to split' being my favourite), and the general formulaic final confrontation and happy ending. It's a lot of fun watching Killian react to it in the typical 'wholesome' gameshow host way, as well, and some of the funniest moments in the show revolve around the contrast between his interactions with the crowd as the seemingly benevolent host (watch out for the cursing old lady!) and the cold, cyncial man he is in reality who will do anything to increase ratings.

If you expect a high-brow, intelligent film, you'll be disappointed. But if you want a great 80s flick, well, this is it. But the great thing about this film is it was quite prophetic.

If you look at the entertainment we have today, you'll have noticed the way reality TV is going nowadays - shows featuring people willing to put themselves through anything for five minutes of fame, and producers all too willing to let them humiliate themselves on TV. It's not too far a leap to imagine that some vile TV exec out there has been trying to get the right to show people be executed live on TV. We've already had that, however, with the ghoulish al-Qaida hostage beheading videos posted on the internet. It seems that in the current climate, at least some people are perfectly fine with watching real death on their television sets.

With that in mind, and coupled with the fact that everything these days appears to be a revival of the 80s, you have to be impressed by the far-sightedness of this film. Of course, we haven't reached there yet, as it's terrorists, rather than the mainstream media, who have bought us easily available programs featuring real human death, but you just have to wonder how long it is before some exec decides to see if he can find a way of pitching a show that combines people's desire for entertainment and desire to indulge their morbid curiosity...
label: literal

text:
A Very Good Thriller with an Unsatisfying Ending Whether you're talking about The Hurt Locker, Detroit, or even Point Break, there's no denying that Kathryn Bigelow is a powerhouse director. With A House of Dynamite, she brings her signature intensity to a high-stakes thriller that doesn't waste a second. The premise is deceptively simple: a missile is heading for the U. S., and the government has 19 minutes to respond. That ticking clock gives the film a relentless pace that's as gripping as anything in Bigelow's filmography.

What sets this movie apart is its unique narrative structure. The film replays the same 19 minutes three times, each from a different perspective: Military, political, and civilian. This approach reveals new information with each iteration, gradually building a full picture getting to the decision-making in a national crisis. It's a clever device that kept me hooked, though I can see how the repetition and handheld camera style might wear thin for some.

The cast is stacked. Rebecca Ferguson, Idris Elba, Jared Harris, and Greta Lee (and many more) all deliver strong performances, but the structure limits how much time we spend with each character. Just as you start to connect with someone, the film shifts perspective. Still, the sharp dialogue and compelling performances help keep the stakes high, even if no single character fully anchors the story.

Where the film falters, for me, is in its final moments. The ending is clearly meant to provoke thought and debate, which I respect, but I found it unsatisfying. It felt more like a concept than a conclusion. That said, A House of Dynamite is a tightly made, ambitious thriller with standout direction and a really good score. It's absolutely worth watching, just be ready for an ending that might leave you frustrated.
label: literal

text:
Hollywood has been Stuckmannized. Shelby Oaks (2025) is a supernatural horror mystery movie directed by YouTuber Chris Stuckmann in his feature directorial debut with a screenplay co-written by Chris and his wife Samantha Elizabeth and it follows the story of a woman's obsessive search for her missing sister leads her into a terrifying mystery at the hands of an unknown evil. This was one of my most anticipated movies of 2025 because of Chris Stuckmann, who is one of the big pioneers for movie reviewers on YouTube alongside Jeremy Jahns, so I wanted to see what he could do with this movie and root for him as a fellow YouTuber. Well, I just got done watching the movie and while it wasn't a flawless victory, this was a great directorial debut for Mr. Stuckmann.

Positives for Shelby Oaks (2025): First off, I love the fact that a YouTuber like Chris Stuckmann got the chance to make a movie and seeing what he can do behind the camera. I will say that the filmmaking here is amazing especially given this movie having a budget of under $3 million and it has no right being as good as it is. I also like the idea of having the movie utilize found-footage in a way that is important to the story, while not having it as the main gimmick for the entire runtime. I will also say that the acting from the cast is pretty good and I was shocked that Chris got Keith David and Derek Mears to be apart of this movie. There is a good bit of tension built throughout the movie that is pretty effective when it needs to be. I also like how the story plays out and how things come together by the end of the experience that felt earned for the most part. And finally, This movie gives me hope that it could open the door for other YouTubers who have ideas for good movies that Hollywood could make and lead to original ideas for the future.

Negatives for Shelby Oaks (2025): The movie does fall into some of the cliches that I've seen in other movies with a premise similar to this one. The movie is also heavily effected by the low budget where there are some things that feel like they were cut out. And finally, I wasn't a big fan of ending as it felt so random and jarring that I struggled to figure out what the point of that ending was.

Overall, Shelby Oaks (2025) is an impressive mystery horror movie and directorial debut for YouTuber Chris Stuckmann that despite its shortcomings I want to see succeed and open the door for more opportunities for other filmmakers, who want to make movies.
label: literal

text:
Stylish but hollow, didn't live up to the hype I watched both seasons of Severance after seeing all the rave reviews, but I can't say I came away impressed. Yes, the concept is original and the production is sleek, it's well shot, well acted, and clearly aiming for something ambitious. But ultimately, I found it more pretentious than profound.

The tone is relentlessly bleak, which might work if the payoff justified the mood. But instead, it feels like it's trying too hard to be deep, without actually offering much insight. I kept waiting for that moment where it would all click, where the metaphors would land or the emotional core would emerge, but it never really did. The pacing is slow, the characters are hard to connect with, and the world-building, while intriguing at first, leans into weird-for-weird's-sake territory.

Maybe I missed some deeper meaning, but to me it came off as a hyper-stylized, overthought show that doesn't quite deliver on its premise. Not terrible by any means - but not as profound or gripping as it thinks it is.
label: literal

text: This is GOLDEN! I love this show! In prior of my friend introducing me to Helluva Boss, my girlfriend introduced me to Hazbin Hotel. At first I these 2 shows were one show, but nope, they're separate, but they both take place in the same universe despite their streaming platform being different. I kind of enjoyed musicals as a kid due to Disney's movies, but I've enjoyed Hazbin's musicals a lot. Alastor & Adam also became my favorite characters! The main thing I love about this show is that usually people sees Heaven as lovely and innocent while they see Hell as torture and evil, until they realize Heaven is behind illegal exterminations towards Hell which shows they are the true evil realm. text:
What an expierience.. First off, this is the BEST Fantastic 4 movie made so far.

This is exactly how the family should have been!! And I'm so glad to see it finally be done here! It was more of a heartthrobing movie than I expected it to be. I loved the small humor here and there, with a more broad focus on the actual conflict itself-- and the emotional TURMOIL that came along with this too!

For example, that scene when Johnny reminds The Silver Surfer of the constant lives and deaths she's responsible for was one of the peaks of the movie.

I genuinley think this is one of the best Marvel movies created within the past few years.

Some cons:

As much as I loved the role the silver surfer played in the movie, I do wish she had a bigger role in the final battle... she just kinda kicked johnny away and took herself out along with galactus... a good sendoff-- but i do wish there was some scene about her that came before that.

Otherwise! Amazing job Marvel! One of the better cinemas produced by them in a while. It's good to see even after all this time, they can do something amazing like this.

text:
Tremendous acting. Fun storyline. Absolutely top tier production and acting throughout. The screenplay is clever and interesting, engaging and well-paced. Character development is pretty robust, and the players aren't simple caricatures. Again and again a character at first appears to be one-dimensional, but then the story develops and they actually are much more complex than the first blush.

My only complaint is that some of the injected "romance" storylines are so ham-fisted and out of place they are disjointed and jarring. Professional situations that suddenly devolve into "I'm just a girl, standing in front of a boy" seemingly out of nowhere. Someone decided to soap opera the show up a bit and it does not improve the result.

text:
Totally misunderstood masterpiece Reading the reviews here I can't help but notice how reviewers expect the US Rambo Wins nerrative or at least clear answers.

This movie does not aim to provide answers but rather provoke thought. It's not a thriller but rather a semi-documentary drama - so reviewer expectations of twists in the plot or clear black vs white are unjustified and thus most reviews are wrongfully biased.

This is a chilling movie, depicting a real life scenario that can happen any minute albeit being a bit melodramatic, and is worth watching just to understand how the world is at the brink of destruction each and every day - with most people not being aware of that.

Great acting, great screenplay, great plot, great angles and feels immersive.

Open your mind to a different perspective. Not every movie has to have good and bad guys or a hero....
label: figurative

text: A stand out series that works. I have never liked Billy Bob.. until I watched this... I don't know why, he just never seemed like my cup of tea... but wow, that man can act. text:
Needed some refinements but still effective! The first half of 'Eddington' evokes memories of the tumultuous period marked by medicinal masks, social distancing, the enforcement of COVID protocols, and challenges in peaceful cooperation occasionally faced by the authorities.

The storytelling serves as a poignant reminder of the tragedy that has left a significant portion of the population not just in a small town in America but all over the world scarred and furious with their governing administrations.

In addition to this stark recollection of tragic events, I appreciated how the narrative develops and nurtures the underlying animosity brewing between the Sheriff and the Mayor of the town, played competently by Joaquin and Pedro respectively and subsequently the escalation of their conflict to a higher level of intensity, which caught me off guard in all honesty.

The execution may not be as refined as Aster's previous works, the movie still presents the familiar blend of humor, horror, and societal critique that Ari Aster is known for.

However, I found myself wishing for a more impactful conclusion. Given the trajectory of the story, I anticipated a a resolution that would be more chaotic and emotionally driven, regrettably, it did not materialize!
label: literal

text:
Unsurprisingly Poor Predictably, this was worse than the previous two, which were pretentious, boring, bordering on annoying and an enormous waste of time. This one however, seemingly let an AI write a mash of the first two with the addition of sequel tropes including the trio of new gen z (ish) characters to spice things up, the reunification of the old characters, the death of the old mentor and the cartoony villain.

The names of all the characters are drawn from poor fantasy novels (Bosco, Thadeus being among a few) and the only redeeming feature of this movie is probably the impeccable Rosamund Pike who nails the accent and whose versatility really shines, as you absolutely hate her character.

The tricks are boring and predictable as is the story. Everything works out in ways that make absolutely no sense, and they explain it is by panning the camera away or using plot armor for all the characters that for some reason are also now highly skilled at martial arts.

Again, I was not disappointed as I did not expect anything at all, it was simply terrible in all the most predictable ways.

Also, did they just reuse the set from inception? Fun but stupid.

text: Quintessential Sirk As is usually the case, the book, a novel of personal reform and spiritual power , is better than movie. Jane Wyman (Helen) was a little too old for him but it added validity to the relationship she had with Joyce (B. Rush) and her first husband. The original book was better in several ways. Joyce was much less of a wannabe movie star, Tom existed for much more than legalities, and Nancy's devotion (A. Moorehead) to the family made more sense. But Helen ! I never could quite believe she loved her first husband and that is crucial to the whole story.

text:
A Stunning Nothingness "Black Phone 2" (without the article) is set four years after the events of the first film, with Finney and Gwen still dealing with the trauma of both the Grabber and their abusive father. When Gwen starts to have new, terrifying visions, her and Finney discover that the Grabber may be dead, but he's not gone.

The plot of this movie is honestly outstanding, building out the world created by Joe Hill and expanded by Scott Derrickson & C. Robert Cargill. Where the film fails though, is a complete lack of carnage, purpose, and failing to fully capitalize on the idea of a Dante's Inferno-accurate hellscape. The Grabber, still played to perfection by a terrifying Ethan Hawke, is nothing but a nuisance here. No one dies. Not a single person is killed by the now demonic(?) Grabber who is also suddenly connected to Gwen and Finney's late mother.

The movie is impeccably acted, the cinematography is incredible and the effects are gnarly, but the writing and direction is just a huge letdown because Derrickson and Cargill are absolutely capable of realizing a horrifying hell where the Grabber relentlessly eviscerated kids and adults on his revenge quest from the afterlife. Seriously, how awesome would it have been to see hell from Dante's Inferno realized in this sequel!
label: figurative

text:
Beauty & the Beast: a howlingly successful blend of monsters and martial arts in a Louis XV setting! 'Le Pacte des Loups' takes the Beast of the Gévaudan (to which over 100 deaths were attributed 1764-67) as the starting-point for a thrilling action-adventure fantasy. 'The Hound of the Baskervilles' meets a 'Crouching Tiger' for a 'Dangerous Liaison' with 'The Last of the Mohicans' in 'Sleepy Hollow'. Result: an exciting, beautifully photographed and well-acted film.

The film opens during the French Revolution: a middle-aged gentleman writes his memoirs, while a hostile mob, singing "Ça ira", gathers outside his home. Only towards the end will we know for certain which of our protagonists he is.

25 years previously, a mysterious Beast terrorises the Gévaudan. Strangers avoid the region - except for the Chevalier Grégoire de Fronsac and his Iroquois friend Mani. After rescuing peasant animal-healer Jean Chastel and his beautiful, mute daughter (ironically nicknamed 'The Gossip') from some men in drag, Grégoire and Mani stay with the Marquis d'Apcher and his grandson Thomas.

Grégoire, a naturalist from the King's Gardens, has been sent to return the Beast (preferably stuffed) to the royal collection. He is a religious sceptic and libertine, representing rationality and Enlightenment values. Mani, a medicine-man and warrior who became his blood-brother during the Seven Years' War, is attuned to the natural world: his totem animal is the wolf. Together, these embodiments of Reason and Rousseauesque proto-Romanticism make a formidable team.

Grégoire's Parisian scepticism ruffles the reactionary local clergy and nobles, including Father Henri Sardis, and the pious Geneviève, Comtesse de Morangias. Her husband the Comte warns that a Papal spy is also investigating the case. Their son, Jean-François, seems at first a potential ally. An ex-naval officer, maimed by a lion in Africa, he is courageous and witty - but has secret torments.... Why does he resent the developing attraction between his sister Marianne and Grégoire? Who is the Italian courtesan, Sylvia, who ensnares Grégoire at the brothel in Mende? Whom can Grégoire and Mani trust? While a book by the mysterious 'The Wolves of God' attacks the King and calls the Beast's predations a divine judgement on the nation, the killings continue.

Cue thrilling hunts, battles with Gypsies, treachery, murder, poisoning, madness, incest, clerical conspiracies, heresy, and trick-weaponry any 18C James Bond would covet. There is a spectacularly acrobatic climactic sword-fight in a ruined church, a happy ending for two characters, while our narrator, at last identified, 25 years later goes bravely to his doom.

The film is lavishly produced and filmed, and splendidly acted. Some have thought Samuel Le Bihan insufficiently glamorous as Grégoire: but glamour is not a trait I expect in an 18C natural historian, and I found him likable and credible. The problem is, the other two leading men are so striking and charismatic that he is overshadowed. This is no criticism of him as an actor: simply that his character is inherently less showy.

Mark Dacascos' wolf-shaman warrior Mani is engaging: serenely beautiful, thoughtful, yet dynamic in action. He is a man of few, but telling words, and powerful presence: he expresses so much with his eyes that one believes his ability to communicate with trees, birds and wolves. Emilie Dequenne (Marianne) grows in courage and maturity as the film progresses. Jérémie Renier (Thomas) is an appealing ingénu.

But real-life couple Vincent Cassel (Jean-François) and Monica Bellucci (Sylvia) steal the show. Both their characters rely, literally and metaphorically, on masks to conceal loyalties, emotions, and - in Jean-François' case - insanity: both actors convey these complexities with panache. Cassel combines extraordinary emotional range with terrific swashbuckling, and ultimately attains 'tragic villain' stature. (Having been a lion's chew-toy would, I suspect, be enough to derange most people.) He also looks strikingly handsome in 18C costume. Bellucci is superb as Sylvia the courtesan/spy - like a beautiful but deadly snake. She's glamorous, intelligent, powerful, dangerous; sexy, but no mere sex-object: one of the best heroines of any film I saw in 2001.

The most familiar face in the supporting cast is Edith Scob ('Eyes Without a Face') as Comtesse Geneviève: a mother you would *not* want making your cocoa. Jean Yanne plays her long-suffering, amiable husband. Virginie Darmon, as Chastel's mute, epileptic daughter, is a haunting, feral presence. Possibly more could have been made of her implied attraction to Mani, a fellow outsider.

The mystery of the Beast's identity is preserved by its disguise - more effective than revealing it to be "only a wolf/lion/hyena/white rabbit", & c. The Jim Henson Workshop brings it to life as a tormented creature for which, at the end, we have some pity. The live animal cast must also be mentioned with some credit: Mani's spirit-wolf is beautiful!

As with 'Sleepy Hollow', 'Pacte's genre-bending, fantastic approach immunises it against those criticisms regarding accuracy and anachronism which 'realistic' historical dramas court. But it was good to hear Occitan spoken by a child survivor in hospital, and I enjoyed the scene in the ruined church which placed the story in a longer continuum of heresy and religious violence. As Mani senses, and Marianne explains, the church had been the site of a massacre of Cathars in 13C by the Knights Templar (in turn judicially murdered on heresy charges a century later). The ruin then becomes the site of the meetings of the 'Wolves of God' and of the dramatic climax. Some viewer criticisms of Grégoire's visits to Sylvia while he is courting Marianne show ignorance of 18C social mores: since unmarried girls of good family were meant to be chaste before marriage, their lovers would turn to professionals for sex.

My main quibble is one of the final twists, when the script backs away from a romantic tragedy which would have strengthened the already poignant ending. I wonder whether a preview audience is to blame? Even so, 'Pacte' should have garnered the international plaudits and awards heaped instead on 'Le Fabuleux Destin d'Amélie Poulain' - who surely would have been Beast-food in the 1760s Gévaudan!
label: figurative

text: Grotesque In the hands of director Ron Howard and star Jim Carrey, "Dr. Seuss' How The Grinch Stole Christmas", is a loud, obnoxious, excessive, CHARMLESS bore. This very short story is expanded to 1 hour and 45 minutes of grotesque imagery that focuses on repugnant characters, who wear out their welcome within 30 seconds.  Carrey's schtick is beyond unbearable.  Easily one of the worst films I have ever seen.  NOT recommended!
label: literal

text:
Tarantino meets Rambo meets Nazis in Lapland - Sisu This was a pleasant surprise! We have Tarantino-inspired bloody action, silent and very charismatic protagonist, beautiful imaginery from actual locations in Lapland, really good soundtrack and some innovative fighting and survival scenes, and of course Finnish Sisu.

Jorma Tommila as the leading man does a phenomenal job. He has only one line in the whole movie (an instant classic), but he is acting very well just by using his face and body.

"He is not immortal, he just refuses to die."

Congratulations for the writer/director Jalmari Helander, the movie looks really good, flows forward easily and is overall very cool and original, despite the overused tropes of evil nazis and action. With just 6 million budget this looks much bigger.

Some nitpicks: the nazis speak English, even when talking with each other, which is kind of weird. But it makes sense for scenes with some Finns.

I really hope this gets much views all over the world.

Don't take the movie or events too seriously, just enjoy the ride :)
label: figurative

text: Save your money This movie seems to be scripted around stunts.  Some of the stunts are noteworthy, but otherwise the movie is very poor.  Plot, writing and acting are sub-par.  Even for a guy flick, this is pretty bad.  Rent something else.

text:
Was great and now mediocre I'm rating this a 7 because this show was once great and it's now simply mediocre so 7 is the average. Jerry Orbach, Sam Waterston, and others from the "old" cast are wonderful. The stories were interesting.

The current iteration of the show is lacking. I think Anthony Anderson does a great job and my attention perks up when Waterston appears on screen. I find the other characters not compelling at all, often awkward, and, really, kind of annoying. The storylines seem to be a second thought, with the show resting on the excitement that Law & Order is back. Nearly all the episodes thus far seem "ripped from the headlines" or very obviously inspired by real-life people and events.

I hope that future episodes will be closer to the quality of previous seasons.

text:
Excellent until season 5 This series was fantastic up until season 5. I'm not sure what went wrong-maybe they ran out of creative ideas or lost direction with the storyline. I've noticed many reviews criticize the flashbacks, but for me, they're the only thing keeping my interest alive at this point. I just wish there wasn't so much back-and-forth. A whole season dedicated to Smurf's backstory would have been amazing.

Another aspect I find off-putting is the excessive emphasis on Deran's romantic encounters. I have no issue with him being gay, but it feels overly focused at times. I get the message, but some scenes, like when he has a threesome, seem unnecessary and waste valuable screen time without contributing to the plot. It has reached a point where Deran has become less engaging as a character.

On the other hand, Shawn Hatosy shines as Andrew, delivering an outstanding performance that adds significant depth to his character. Ellen Barkin also excels in her role as Smurf. Overall, if you can overlook the excessive and often pointless scenes, this series remains a strong watch.
label: figurative

text: One to watch! It's a mini horror movie every week. Supernatural brings American urban legends into your home each episode. All those stories you told around the campfire as a child come to life in this explosive TV show. From the exceptional writing to the awesome soundtrack, this TV show is a step above the rest. I love seeing the dynamic between the brothers, Sam and Dean. It seems that no matter what has happened in the past, family is family. I imagine this show is a production nightmare. There are so many great special effects, it's like being at your local cinema. And you can't forget that car. A '67 Impala that the brothers travel the country in. With the classic rock tunes blaring on the cassette player and the roar of the engine, this car is hot! Overall, I think Supernatural is one of the best shows on TV. My only concern is them running out of good material. I mean there are only so many urban legends. However, I've heard they've got the first 3 seasons pretty much mapped out, so at least we can have a few good years, right.
label: literal

text: Finally! Great Show. Firstly, the great things. No politics, no race baiting. Just a very intriguing story of a loser that can't help spread it to everyone he touches. Come near him and you might get caught up in his tornado. That Jason Bateman would play such a loser unlikable character, is another of the best parts of this show. He really sells it with every piece of dialogue and body. Jude Law is fantastic. The two together are just brilliant TV. Hated finishing it because there are no shows like this. Raw, unlikable characters that propel the story along, that's what we are here for a great story. Very entertaining to watch. People that don't like this probably Shrinking is great entertainment.

text:
There is a God.....of TV !!! This is the best series i have ever been blessed to be entertained by in my 50 years of life.My nephew and I are glued to the screen during every episode.

Every character, every plot, every scene,(especially the ones with Craig's ass, wink), are chock full of entertainment! Never a dull moment. They're sexy, they're bad, they're good and we love the f*ck out of 'em. Most of all, they're family and these actors meld together so well that they draw you straight in to their wonderful crazy world. We get to live vicariously through the best family in the history of TV.....the Cody family!!!

TNT, you finally done something truly great! Thank you and to all the actors and production crew, thank you for making us fall in love with TV all over again!!! Can't wait for future seasons guys. Much love to you all......Steve and James <3

text: True detective with Native Americans An exciting, interesting series in a familiar setting. Little action but lots of dialogue. Unfortunately, the full potential is not exhausted and fails due to the banal story structure, the constructed problems and the already seen and predictable twists. It can't be the actors alone. Especially since the setting with Navacho Indians and constant conflict definitely has potential. Sometimes the situation seems very constructed and cliche, and doesn't demand enough of the viewer. But it's still fun to watch the series, especially because it's relatively entertaining with six episodes and presents interesting characters. Nevertheless, the whole thing doesn't go beyond the normal average, but rather he presents individual and beautiful ideas that could have resulted in something exciting. Could have been a true detective with Native Americans.
label: literal

text:
A long-drawn-out film with a good-looking As a fan of the musical, this Part 1 spent 160 minutes to show how the director made a long-drawn-out film. I don't mind adding the characters from the original book, but it is not an excuse to add many details to the side plot and drag this movie to 160 munites.

When it comes to the climax, the most disappointing thing for me is also coming. The famous song Defying Gravity was interrupted in the movie (compared with the musical). When my tears came to my eyes, they were stopped by this interruption.

It is also a good marketing movie, there are a lot of peripheral products that can be purchased and a lot of online social media events. It made this movie come with a "popular" atmosphere, which I love to see.

All in all, this movie is a good-looking musical movie, literally.

text: Gunn did it! This is THE BEST Superman movie made! I really don't understand the relatively low score and I don't get what some people/critics were expecting to be different! text:
Glass ceiling? Events conspired to keep me away from the cinema for a few weeks, so now I'm looking to try and catch up as best I can. This led to a relatively late evening showing of "Roofman" last night, a solid, if undemanding, comedy drama - based on a true story.

Jeffrey Manchester (Channing Tatum) is arrested for a series of armed robberies of fast-food restaurants, where he enters through the roof and awaits the arrival of the staff. Because of the mode of entry the media giving him the nickname 'Roofman'. Sentenced to 45 years, he escapes prison and, whilst awaiting assistance in fleeing the country, begins to hide in a Toys R Us, in a hollow space behind a bike display. To alleviate the boredom, he sets up cameras to track the actions of the staff and, as he learns more about the routines, he finds ways to leave the store, when it's not open for business.

It's obviously a lot easier to write a review of something if it inspires a passionate response in you, either negative or positive - but I'm afraid that "Roofman" for all it's qualities, doesn't really do that for me. Its performances are good - indeed Tatum's charisma alone is probably enough that it could have carried the film, without supporting roles from the always excellent LaKeith Stanfield and Peter Dinklage, and from Kirsten Dunst - let alone tiny turns from Jimmy O Yang, Tony Revolori, Juno Temple, Uzo Aduba and Ben Mendelsohn. The story is decent, even if perhaps some of it stretches the realms of plausibility, that comes with simplifying the story for the screen.

The trouble is, I can already acknowledge that I won't remember this film in a few months. It's lacking in surprise and, even though there are some sadder moments on introspection for Manchester to deal with, it's not that emotionally deep.

It's fine, if you are restricted on options for whatever reason, you won't come away regretting your time with it, but it's hard to actively recommend the film.
label: literal

text:
Not what I expected At first the only reason I watched the Sopranos was for my husband, but I did keep an open mind. Soon after renting the first season both he and I were hooked. The characters were so real. You liked to love them and you liked to hate them. It was also very convenient that they killed all the characters that I thought should have been killed. ;) The irony of the show is that most of the time we get this mob picture of a character like Pauly just having fun and acting tough. This shows you the fears and weaknesses of toughest wise guys. 

You see Tony's inner conflict (James Gandolfini is a great actor) between being a good husband and father and his reputation and duties to the mob. You also see Carmela's side with Tony always gone, but she still tries to make it work and she still loves him. I love the different characters, they really picked a great cast. 

The show just keeps your attention because you never know what will happen or how characters will react. I highly recommend it for people who don't have weak stomachs. 

P.S. For the people who don't like it, It is called ENTERTAINMENT.
label: literal

text:
Derivative, predictable and formulaic mediocrity I SO much wanted to like this series. I really did. But the pilot was just borderline, so I optimistically waited for S1E2. Unfortunately, it further confirmed my initial reaction: this is Déjà vu TV and not in a good way. So far everything has been done before--and better.

Older viewers can probably remember shows that have used this same formula: protagonist with baggage in his past works with a somewhat nerdy guy/gal who does the tech behind the scenes, and is supported by handlers that behave like office managers. The story lines have been superficial, the action sequences forced and illogical.

There's also some very amateurish editing. For example, in S1E2 at approximately 11 minutes, it's raining and his truck is wet, windows dotted with drops. The very next scene right afterwards the truck is not only dry and detailed spotless, but the passenger window is rolled down. Seconds ago it was a downpour. Really? Most scenes are not filmed contiguously, but since these shots occur sequentially, it was quite an obvious gaffe.

I know we live in a world of remakes, re-issues, re-mixes and sequels to the max. It's a sign of no originality and lack of writing talent. Yes, this show *might* survive past S1 as we've seen that quality does not correlate with success (and the opposite is also true). Intelligent shows have suffered premature deaths while drivel like could potentially live on. Perhaps Paramount will put it out of its misery sooner than later.

No, it's not the worst show on TV, but I'm going to pass on the remaining episodes.
label: literal

text:
Please don't do a Predator/Independence Day crossover..... ..... We had that Alien Easter Egg in Predator 2, and they do it here with the aliens from Independence Day. It's head slappingly awful, and then you have to contend with the rest of the film.

If you're into 3D, there is one stand out scene that is brilliant in the format, but this isn't your Mommas Predator film.

I wasn't bothered by the rating, it's a 12A here in the UK, but there is not one human character in the film, so we have white fluid, and green fluid, which constitutes for blood.

Elle Fanning is playing a game of two halves, one a very immature Synth who would look better in a Barbie sequel, and another character who would make Ian Holm proud.

My main problem with the film is that I just didn't care about a single character, not even the gleep glop that looks like the creature from Lost In Space, so I became very bored, very quickly, which shouldn't happen in a Predator film.

I never thought I'd say this, but there is a Predator film that I actually hate, and it's this.

IMs Ute I'm in the minority though, and I truly hope you enjoy it.....
label: figurative

text:
Why is the predator not big? Oh because they're doing this other thing...

Ugh... Okay, what's this other thing they're doing instead, while keeping the Predator name attached?

Okay so, from the trailers, Weyland-Yutani is here. This is immediately problematic to me. I am of the opinion that the Alien franchise already went off the rails with Aliens, before the original Predator movie had even come out. But accepting Aliens, I don't think you can plausibly do much more with the concept of Weyland-Yutani vs low tech aliens because... why? Because Weyland-Yutani has synth technology and AI in general, so if they are prepared for a fight, alien creatures aren't going to pose a real threat, whether they're xenomorphs or the beast in this movie.

So here, why the heck is Weyland-Yutani sending a bunch of human-shaped synths to hunt some huge monster? Oh and look, it's a power loader! James Cameron hydraulics, but with CGI! How nostalgic! But... why isn't that thing loaded out with all the weapons and AI?

The writers were supposed to ask these questions and fix things so that they make sense. From the trailers, from the synopsis, from the names involved, I know they didn't do that.

Dear reader, I stopped watching movies with these warning signs and I suggest others do the same.

Dear studios, hire sci-fi writers for your next sci-fi movie project. I promise it will help.
label: literal

text:
Fantastic duality The premise of a kidnapping sets the stage for relentless tension, with power dynamics bubbling up and exploding like a pressure cooker throughout the film.

What struck me most was the brilliant duality between Michelle: the wealthy, hyper-educated liberal vs Teddy: the poor, conspiracy-driven incel (along with his cousin). Their exchanges mirror the polarized conversations we so often hear today between the progressive left and the reactionary right, where both sides speak but no one truly listens.

It's an incredibly fertile setup. A sharp reflection of our times, where extreme views dominate the airwaves and common ground seems impossible, even as we all share the same fragile planet, one whose survival depends on our ability to rethink how we consume its resources.

The three lead actors deliver outstanding performances, capturing every flicker of discomfort, fear, and rage so vividly that the audience can't help but squirm in their seats.

Without spoiling the ending, I'll just say it's undeniably original, though for me, it strays from the rich ideological duel that powers the story up to that point.

Still, Bugonia is an absolute must-see. A gripping, provocative, and brilliantly acted film with Oscar-worthy performances.
label: literal

text:
Gold does NOT rust! Strangely enough, this goof describes the downfall of the series perfectly.

Season 1: 10 Stars, simply amazing, beyond expectations.

Season 2: 8 Stars. Very good with many lovely story telling.

Season 3: ... What the hell was that?

In one of the latest episodes of season 3, Yennefer says "Look at all these Gold, left here to rust".

Yennefer is a powerful sorcerer, that has lived for centuries and has extensive knowledge in alchemy. She would most definitely know that Gold does not rust. That's what makes it so special.

And that summarize the quality of the 3rd season and how once an amazing show with beautiful story, wide characters and extended knowledge has now become a total waste of time.

text:
Would love to give a better rating, but just couldn't.... I was super hyped for this film. There are some positive aspects like the old lighthearted justice loving superman is back!! He is just a straight up a good guy who wants to save each and every person and loves everyone. It's nice to get away from the dark tone of the modern day superhero films!

David Corenswet is not bad. Christopher Reeves was great as both, Brandon Routh was a great Clarke Kent but not a good superman, Henry Cavill a great superman but not a good Clarke Kent, and now Corenswet is good in both roles butnot great in either. Loved Lois Lane, very similar to the original film.

Now coming to the film itself, it's not well paced, with inconsistencies all over the place. The first half was actually pretty bad. Starting the film right away from the fight with Ultraman seemed too fast. There were no character introductions, the justice gang just came and every characters were introduced straight into the battlefield. I'd have loved if the initial scenes involved Superman saving Jarhanpur from Boravia. It would've given the film a better start, maybe making the film 2.5 hrs long by adding 20 more minutes wouldn't have been too bad.

Loved Mr. Terrific. He was the best part of the whole film, and his fight scene in the beach was the best!! The rest of the Justice gang were meh.

Lex Luthor was kinda similar to the first Superman film where he wanted to bomb the cities and rename them to his name. I'd have been okay with that, but at the end when it's revealed he jist envies Superman and cries like a baby destroys Luther's character as a whole. And how the hell does he get mutants like metamorpho imprisoned in the pocket universe! So many stuff he has done, created Superman's clone, made the Engineer, created mini universes, made a war, only because he is jealous of superman! That doesn't sound right.

So, so many plot holes. Where the hell does Luthor get a freaking kaiju, pretty convenient how he went to Superman's den to find out some leverage against him and immediately finds that he was sent to kill everyone (Goku reference), how and when hawkgirl, green lantern and metamorpho team up and save Jarhanpur, how blowing INTO a black hole pushes you away from the hole, and the second black hole doesn't even pull superman at all!! And lots more.

I loved the interactions with Jonathan and Martha Kent, the emotions felt great, the story of Jarhanpur and Boravia symbolizes the present Israel Palestine war and very positive and good messages were given, I loved it, but judging the film only, the making could've been a lot better. This Superman is just good and kinda stupid sometimes. Superman should be intelligent to some extent too apart from being good.

Anyways hopefully the next films will be better!
label: literal

text:
Thank God for Cartoons I'm overjoyed that the culmination of tumblr, electroswing, post-Cartoon Network, Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends aesthetics resulted in something this loving, musical, and expressive.

Helluva Boss has some great moments but has large swaths that don't resonate much with me, but here everything miraculously clicks. The web of backstories and plotlines are all juggled surprisingly deftly with a great balance between intimate character moments and larger scale worldbuilding (something I've always struggled with in these sorta fantasy shows but I think flows in a very engaging way here), the characterizations are all handled with real sensitivity (and with fitting nuance given the central conceit of the show), and ill go out on a limb and say all the musical segments do wonders for me (the recasting of the voice cast with seasoned musical theater veterans was an essential choice in this regard).

Ive been thinking lately about how i used to lay in the back of my parents car during road trips and close my eyes and imagine these rly vivid music videos in my head while shuffling Beatles songs on my MP3 player, usually focused on characters from MLP or Ruby Gloom, and have lamented that I haven't been able to do that in years. The other day I was chillin listening to Tricky's "Suffocated Love" and I saw this whole Hazbin Hotel lookin music video in my head so vividly jus like when I was a kid, and for that alone I'm deeply grateful for this show.

Sure it's a very easy thing to dunk on, but as a cultural object for someone who grew up watching ridiculous amounts of cartoons, this has been exactly the shot of inspiration I've needed at the start of the year.
label: literal

text: "FBI"...Are you kidding.!!! I love to read the reviews of a new series before I take the time-out to watch it and, having read quite a few negative feedbacks, I wasn't going to bother. However, I did decide to watch the first two opening episodes due to the prologue ( as I think 'Missy Peregwyn' is a really Great & Convincing actress ..as she is again on this series. Without her role as agent Bell & also her partner Zadin, this series could have hit a real blow.!!! Why does Jeremy Sistos character always have to scream and shout? Stella Ward..where is she convincing as FBI..are they really trying to tell us that "FBI" is going to be an "Outstanding Series" with overbearing actors like Stella Ward.? As well as over-acting the both of their roles, so-far, have been unconvincing and lethargic.! Ebonee Noels' character as an analyst was quite a turn-off. I don't know Ebonee Noel as an actress, but she was so awful so far in the opening two episodes...seriously.!!! Where was the passion? Why does she always seem to look up & roll her eyes when she's supposedly looking at the computer screen; her eyes are all over the place it's laughable😣. She was that annoying It kept distracting me from the scene. It continued in other scenes too, the scene where she was to disable a bomb (please) it was as though she was about to laugh; was this supposed to be tense? I had to rewind it repeatedly to be sure. An awful actress I must say 👎 The series may improve as the episodes evolve. If not for the pairing of "Missy Peregrym and Zeeko Zaki" (A Great Match by the way👌) I don't think I would have continued to watch it if I'm honest. I do not like to leave a bad review after so few an episode though unless I truly believe the series is that terrible, thst it's unwatchable.😉 It doesn't compare to the "Law & Order" franchises or "Without A Trace". I Shall give "FBI" a chance to get going, then, I shall revisit the review at the end of the last episode. Watch-out...😊

text: Awesome Action Film With Great One Liners From Arnie! This is an awesome action film with great one liners from Arnie!. It's stylishly made, with lots of tense action to keep one satisfied. The Characters were awesome, and Richard Dawson, is very menacing as the main villain. Yes it has tons of plot holes,however it's highly highly entertaining, with a great ending as well. It had a great story, too it, and Arnie and Maria Conchita Alonso had great chemistry together. The Character development was also pretty good, with, some superb performances. The Directing is great!. Paul Michael Glaser, does a very good job here, with awesome use of colors, keeping it stylish throughout, awesome camera angles, and overall keeping the film at a very fast pace! good job. There is a little bit of gore. We get a few bloody gunshot wounds, exploding head, slit throat, bloody chainsaw slices, skinless corpses, blood, and an impaling. The Acting is great!. Arnold Schwarzenegger is AMAZING as always, he is excellent in the acting department , has tons of hilarious one liners, kicks that ass, and as always is a big physical presence!, and was tons of fun to watch! (Arnie Rules!). Maria Conchita Alonso, does well here, she was really cute, and had good chemistry with Arnie!. Yaphet Kotto, is decent here, with what he has to do, which is not much. Marvin J. McIntyre, is good as the geeky type guy, he was cool!. Richard Dawson is awesome as the main villain, and was very very menacing, and he was fun to watch. Jesse Ventura,Jim Brown,Erland van Lidth,Gus Rethwisch,and Professor Toru Tanaka, all do what they have to do very well as the stalkers. Overall a MUST see! ****1/2 out of 5

text:
Terrible but somewhat interesting Movie based on Jacqueline Susann's best-selling novel. It's about Robin Stone (John Phillip Law) a ruthless TV anchorman who claws his way to the top. It details his love life concentrating on Amanda (Jodi Wexler) and Judith (Dyan Cannon). It also shows his total inability to commit to anyone and instead sleeps with any woman he can get.

The novel is no work of art (it's not even good literature) but it's a quick, silly, trashy read. However, compared to this movie, it seems like a masterpiece of fiction! This is a textbook example of how NOT to do a movie adaptation. First they condense the novel terribly. In the book Stone's inability to commit is dealt with and it's revealed why. Here it's brought up...and ignored. Characters from the book are either totally left out or changed completely. One of them (Maggie) pops up for two pointless scenes and then disappears completely! Also there's a truly revolting scene in which a woman is brutally beaten. It's in the book--but there IS a reason totally left out of the movie. And the book dealt with three women--not two. Don't even get me started on the homophobia. The movie is almost worth sitting through for a no holds barred fight at the end between Law, Cannon and David Hemmings.

Adaptation aside the acting is pretty terrible. Law is just horrendous as Stone--VERY wooden and boring--you seriously wonder why all these women are after him. To be fair to Law another actor was cast but had a very bad accident before shooting began and Law stepped in at the last minute. Wexler is terrible as Amanda; Maureen Arthur is truly astoundingly bad as Ethel Evans; Shecky Greene is unbearable as Christie Lane. Only three performances stand out: David Hemmings (having a GREAT time) camps it up as a gay photographer; Cannon is actually very good and Robert Ryan is just great. Also Dionne Warwick sings the catchy opening song ("He's Moving On"). Also Jacqueline Susann has a cameo as a newscaster.

It IS bad but I watched the whole thing and it is (in a silly sort of way) a lot of fun. I'm giving it a 3.
label: figurative

text:
Threat level midnight Michael Scott. Steve Carroll. It's hard to distinguish incredible actors in sitcoms and comedies, but this is one show that demonstrates how talented Caroll is and how wide his range also is by now. One cannot love Scott without loving Caroll who created his different version that David Brent of the BBC original.

This show is so compulsively able to be rewatched due to Michael Scott as each one of us fall in love with his character, especially with all his imperfections.

But without the ensemble, Michael Scott would lack all the historical episodes he made our guts ache. My personal favorite in the background is Stanley. How genius of a casting choice. But then Jim Halpert may be just as genuis as Steve Carroll as Jim is infamous for the perfect timing of looking at us to make the scene all the more awkward. Somenting Scott and him do the best.

I'm not sure there was a more heartwarming scene then Michael and Heidi proposal. Jim pranking Dwight, i.e. the magic lagoons or beans as Dwitght waters the four plants and then Jim replaced them with full grown trees.

Is there a more tortured character than Toby? In a scene in which Robert California listed Toby's name on the left side of the paper, "the winners". Toby announces at the table in the restaurant as they're celebrating, that he needs to excuse himself and he was never here because hes so conditioned at this point from years of Michael's abuse.

Stanley's glaring at Andy's back as he speaks to Erin at reception saying do not look at Stanley I accidentally filled in his sudoku.

What always appealed to me though, was how the show crossed the line and seemed fearless. In what consider the office as a cringe inducing show, I find it so refreshing that off colored jokes were inlcuded. It is my favorite comedy ever, and one I compare shows to capturing its atmosphere or tone. Many comedies have been born because of the #inspiration of this. The mockementary style filming is another character on it's own and a device I feel is underused in comedies today.

The office featured one of the best ensembles with comedy's following trying to feature stellar ensembles realizing after nine years of the office, it's the characters created that will give the show its run for the money. No other comedy since has been able to create a character as significant as Michael Scott to lead a show.

The office is a series much like friends is for a lot of people, that is simply part of your life as we incorporate it into our lives each year upon a rewatch knowing it will provide a warm fuzzy comfy world in which we're able to retreat from reality and escape to Dunder Mifflin.

text: Starts of well but later seasons "Woke" This is a long running Showtime series which really started off well with clever writing and life-like characters that really make you become emotionally invested in their stories. Unfortunately, after Season 6, the series started to go downhill. By Season 8. it became all about "messaging" and "education", and ultimately too political. The final straw (or nail in its coffin) came in Season 9 with the departure of Emmy Rossum. Seasons 10 and 11 are like watching a once great show as it falls into a death spiral, writhing in throes of a painful death! The series then just manages to limp to the end, literally force feeding the viewers heavy doses of political correctness in every episode. Despite this failure, it is still worth a watch because of the good acting that brings the characters to life.

text:
Smart and Entertaining I must be honest: Initially I was skeptical about yet another romance comedy from Netflix. The track record on this genre is largely badly written stories compounded by lead actors with little to no chemistry.

I was so happy that this is not the case with "Nobody Wants This". Likely a tongue-in-cheek title from the producers who recognize the generally subpar quality of this type of movies or series.

Kudos must be given to the writers, directors, and the actors - both lead and supporting cast. I totally bought into the chemistry between Kristen Bell's and Adam Brody's characters from the very beginning.

They pulled off something special here: A smartly written and entertaining romance comedy that is completely believable and engaging. There were a few brief moments where I was worried. But thankfully it didn't end up being too cliche.

I can't wait for Season 2!
label: figurative

text: Average Show Lukewarm attempt to be the Irish version of Succession, but it didn't quite get the job done. The series appeared to focus on entertaining the teenage/twenty-something demographic. The soundtrack was mostly modern Irish music that significantly distracted from the 19th Century setting of the series.

text:
Oh Ricky... what hast though done? Sorry to be just another person to slag this off but I can't help it. I'm glad for Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchants success with The Office in other countries, but surely they cant be over the moon about how this version turned out. I've read them saying they like it, but then what else can they say.

In my opinion there was no point in even basing it on the original because the main elements that make The Office so freaking good are all lost in translation. There's no subtlety and the characters don't have the dimensions that they did in the original. 

I must say I find Steve Carell pretty good, but thats down to his own comedy timing. The rest of the cast is below par, and I cant stand the Gareth equivalent. He is so annoying!!! In the original, Gareth is such a w*nker... in a hilarious way..... in the US version, he's such a w*nker..... in a freaking irritating way.

Must everything be so over the top in the US? does that make me a racist? Nah cause i LOVE Seinfeld... best sitcom ever! But on "The Office", I think you're out of your element.
label: figurative

text:
Too much suspension of disbelief The premise is good, but to believe that someone so successful and obviously smart would never catch on, is asking too much.

Beyond that, that are too many unanswered questions that just ask too much of the audience. I could point out a dozen, but bother? This "could have been great" plot is not worth it.

text:
Less is always more First season was great. The second season was very good. The third season was fine but improved. This last season is a complete disappointment. It's all over the place and it just lost its way.

Way too many actors trying to get a piece of the action and the plot was sacrificed.

The story just seems to go nowhere.

I really loved this show and even tried watching this new season because I love Steve Martin and Martin Short despite Selena Gomes's lack of acting skills and lame voice. But I just couldn't make it past episode 7.

Not even Meryl Streep can save this season. It should have stayed just the three actors with an occasional guest appearance on each season or even a few episodes but not essential to the story. I mean the show was supposed to be about the three main characters and them solving cases.

Maybe the screenwriters were changed who knows but this just seems like a completely different show and just not worth watching past the first three seasons.

text: Edgar nailed it I loved the 80's Arnie yarn. Used to watch it every day as a kid. Then read the book and realised it was totally different. When they announced the remake and it was rumoured that they'd stay true to the book I got very excited. I'm happy to say that Edgar Wright smashed it. My wife came along and usually watches action movies just to stop me looking like a lone wierdo in the cinema! She absolutely loved this movie, so that's all anyone needs to know. I dare say the low reviews will be politically motivated like the recent One Battle After Another low scores. On merit, this movie can't be scored any lower than a 7 or 8/10. If you like a good King adaptation, this will impress. No doubt about it!

text:
I don't understand the hype on this one National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation is a holiday movie that many cherish for its over-the-top humor and nostalgic charm. Chevy Chase delivers his signature blend of slapstick and sarcasm as Clark Griswold, a family man determined to create the perfect Christmas. The film captures the chaos and dysfunction of holiday gatherings in a way that feels relatable to many.

However, while there are undeniably funny moments, much of the humor relies on gags that can feel dated or excessively over-the-top. The film's pacing is uneven, with some scenes dragging while others rush through potentially meaningful moments. The supporting characters, while quirky, are often reduced to one-note caricatures, making it hard to fully invest in the story.

While Christmas Vacation has its moments of holiday magic and laugh-out-loud scenes, it doesn't consistently deliver the heart or sharp wit of the best holiday comedies. For fans of slapstick and 1980s humor, it's an enjoyable watch, but for others, it might fall a little short. A 5/10 for its mix of festive fun and missed potential.
label: figurative

text: Henry Cavill deserves 10/10 the writers barely deserve 1/10 Its honestly crazy that the writers for the later seasons wanted to make Geralt and Cerie (the child he rescues in the first season and helps raise for the next several) have a romantic relationship so Henry Cavill departed from the show. Who knows if they are going to continue with that trash storyline but it should be said this show was good enough to make my wife (who could care less about fantasy) interested for the first two seasons. The show has taken a downward turn since then though those first two seasons are quite enjoyable with a great cast and honestly great effects. The monster fights are next level and the sword fights are even better so thats why I say it deserves 10/10, plus Cavill is the man and the rest of the cast make this such a great show.

text:
It was okay Congratulations to the show for having a second season unfortunately I won't be watching.

The show has a very big problem that most other shows have: they made the crime investigation too simple and too easy. In addition to this, Karl's six sense was too strong. He could tell what was relevant and what the next step was. In reality, detectives get flows of info, too many suspects or no suspect at all. Even they have a suspect and bring to question, without solid evidence, they will deny everything. Also with so much info, they don't know where to start. Reality trains are derailed in this show.

Karl Alberg is a great cop. Hardworking, smart, experienced, pursing truth and justice. He sometimes weights his job more than his family, including his daughter and his girlfriend. He also doesn't really care about how he looks. Can you imagine he doesn't dress up and comb his hair before going to work? In his head, solving cases is everything.

The show also reflect some issues that the modern society has. For example, hybristophilia (episode 6 of season 1), and spreading false information about sth people don't know about on social media (episode 7 of season 1) due to their uncontrollable fear and uncertainty, before the truth reveals. While watching they unveil mysteries, paying attention to this unnoticeable details is also good.

Season 1 was either not too good or too bad. I hope season 2 is gonna be amazing.
label: literal

text: Excellent Excellent show. Crossover between CPD and CM is brilliant coz it made me watch them. Chicago Fire is very realistic and human. text:
It's so hard to rate even 9 to this show, because it's so unique & revolutionary. Even though the last season was horrible, I can't ignore the greatness of the Show. Writer George R. R. Martin did nearly a perfect job creating this franchise: A Song of Fire and Ice.

Also HBO adapted it beyond well. It was revolutionary. I bet you couldn't find this type of TV show at that time. It felt like Cinema. It was just revolutionary. I didn't see this type of quality in any TV Show. The closest one was Band of Brothers. Even other HBO projects can't compete with Game of Thrones that easily. After a decade later, I still believe this is the biggest revolution on TV series.

Ramin Djawadi's stunning Original Scores makes the serie two times better.

All the Costume, Makeup and Set Decorations brings too much realistic style to a Fantasy world.

Cinematography is just like painting with all colors instead of just red. As you may know, Ser Barristan Selmy uses only one color in painting. :)

Some of the underrated actors just showed their skills to the whole world since this is the most popular TV Show of all time.

The storyline is not that easy to explain. It's just amazingly detailed and full of great twists. Not all the twists are great, sadly the last season showed us that isn't the case. But besides last season, the twists were pretty great. I know Season Seven was also had so many weak sides and non logic parts. But even Season Seven was great if you're comparing with some other TV show. It's just worse than other seasons, yes I'm aware Arya and Sansa were acting to each other for no reason. These logicless parts started with Season Five actually. But they were "could be ignored" type of flaws, were'nt major flaws. I think the greatest season was Season Six with amazing battle episode and the great Bran's vision scene. Even though Season Six also had minor flaws, it's still the greatest for me. As I said these flaws didn't started in Season Seven as many people believe. The flaws started on Season Five. It just evolved to middle flaws in Season Seven. And these flaws evolved into something I've never witnessed before in Season Eight. I don't know how to describe these flaws. Sadly the last season is just unwatchable. It's enough to watch one time, I don't think anyone wants to see twice. It's was the worst way to end the show sadly, I actually believe if someone would tried to make a worse season, it'll be so hard to make a worse story.

Eventually we get the Game of Thrones shock effect. But this time wasn't the good way like in The Red Wedding. This time the twist was the horrible story writing.

So why did I rate 10/10 after the last season? Because I accepted Season Six was the peak and the show ended in there for me. It's so hard to rate even 9 to this show, because it's so unique, revolutionary and effective. I can't just ignore all those great things. I'm not saying this show doesn't deserve any criticizing. It surely does. It deserves all those negative ratings and reviews. But personally, I can't even rate 9 because as I mentioned I can't ignore all the greatness in the show. You may consider my thoughts silly, it's okay but you know what? When I was watching the show with my brother, I saw those bad endings coming from the first two episodes. People just saw that in the fifth episode of the season. This show killed three main characters in a wedding episode. Did you really expect this? In The Long Night, the most important character that die was Jorah Mormont. Still not even important as Robb Stark. All those years we've waited for these moments. The first episode of the first season called "Winter Is Coming" and this story shouldn't be about the Throne because it's about the great enemy. What did change after the events of The Long Night, that long waited winter? Nothing changed at all.

The other enormous flaw was about Jon Snow. Why did you just made him son of a Targaryen and a Stark? If he is not the rightful King, why should we care about him?

Jamie Lannister also gone after the war without any reason.

They really killed all those characters one by one. But still I can't rate 9 because I choose to forget the last season. Just like I'm ignoring The Sequel Trilogy in Star Wars, I'm also ignoring the existence of the last season of Game of Thrones.
label: figurative

text:
trying desperately hard to be more intelligent than it is Overall a showman of a film. Flashy, loud with bells and whistles and big personalities, an exciting premise... illusionists rob banks using (supposed) magic but the four horsemen are just puppets in a game, but the hype is more than the substance of the film itself.

You'd expect suspense, twists, intelligent plot misdirection and all sorts of thrilling viewing? No. This film tries to be a lot more intelligent than it actually is. Like Atlas (Eisenberg) says, "Always be the most intelligent person in the room" or something similar, this film thinks it is being intelligent but actually it's not challenging enough. It gives too much away, isn't as unpredictable as it should be (really, you couldn't see that ending coming?) and just isn't as clever as it promises. The tricks I really wanted explaining weren't... the ones that were more obvious, were explained. The ending actually isn't a denouement, as it's been laying clues all along - and anyone who's seen a lot of films can see the "twists" coming a mile away. I focus on the twists and reveal because as a heist movie, the end is the big reveal. But, unlike Oceans Eleven, for example, it has more or less handed it to you on a plate already.

The actors were good. Morgan Freeman and Woody Harrelson stealing the show, of course, with Dave Franco doing a bang up job with some incredible physical acting, stunts and so forth. I'm afraid Jesse Eisenberg didn't convince in his character and was annoying after a while, Franco rather underutilised really. Isla Fisher was good but clearly the "glamour" rather than a serious character, which was a shame as she was good.

This was supposed to be a big blockbuster film, big back drops, epic stunts and huge crowd scenes, but it failed to deliver. As heist/magic genre films go it's not that great, and The Prestige was far more cerebral and gripping. Entertaining to a point but I got a bit bored, and some of the scenes were too long - chases etc. If you are a fan of heist films or magic you'll enjoy it, or are a fan of particular actors, or will just enjoy it for what it is and don't want to be challenged intellectually, it's a great film. I think Hollywood endings are just too commonplace. 6/10 for me.
label: literal

text:
Better watch this Had heard nothing but amazing things about 'Better Call Saul' (with nothing bad), with it being one of the most highly regarded shows in recent years. Am a huge fan of 'Breaking Bad', so was really psyched in seeing its prequel 'Better Call Saul' too. My opinion of Bob Odenkirk is also very high, so there was absolutely no way this was going to be missed. Have binged on many shows in the past seven years or so and was determined for this to be one of them, very like 'Breaking Bad'.

'Better Call Saul' was every bit as amazing as reputed. Have seen many shows that started off wonderfully but declined badly in their final seasons, a few with really bad last episodes ('House of Cards', 'Game of Thrones', 'Killing Eve'), but then there are rarities like 'Breaking Bad' where every season was at least positively received and on the most part universally acclaimed. 'Better Call Saul' is another one of the rarities and is the first show seen in a long time to not have a bad episode in it, since 'Breaking Bad'. Seriously compelling and addictive stuff and exceptional in every area.

Visually, 'Better Call Saul' is one of those shows that is both stylish and beautiful, with photography and editing that are cinematic quality and put a lot of films today to shame, where there are a lot of visually beautiful ones but also some painfully amateurish looking ones. The music always has the appropriate mood, never too intrusive, never too muted.

The writing for 'Better Call Saul' is a fine example to all shows of how to have a lot of style but also to have a lot of substance. The dialogue throughout is thought-provoking and tense, although quite talky, while also have a darkly wicked sense of humour and heart-tugging pathos. The stories are texturally rich, intimate, tense and layered, with the pace of them consistently deliberate but taut. The pull no punches and gritty approach to the subject was often chilling and harrowing to watch. The direction couldn't be better.

Likewise with the acting, with Odenkirk on absolutely towering form throughout as one of television's most fascinating and meatiest leading characters, one that one is repulsed by but also one that is not hard to sympathise with in some situations. Rhea Seehorn and Michael McKean are excellent as well, McKean giving one of his best work in years. The character writing is rich and compellingly real.

Concluding, truly outstanding show. 10/10.
label: figurative

text: Hooked by ep 2 I will start by saying I have no knowledge of this real story and cannot speak to accuracy. What I will say is it is a slow burn and intriguing look at the dynamics of money, power, addiction, dysfunction and the truth behind the headlines. Yes, it is a dramatization, but it is peeling away a facade that it seems the family was trying to keep in place, even among each other. text:
Timo Tjahjanto Turns Nobody 2 Into a Perfect Blend of Grit, Laughs & Mayhem "Nobody 2" is in the perfect hands with Timo Tjahjanto at the helm, and it shows. He delivers a film that's perfectly balanced-drama that hits, comedy that lands, and action that absolutely rips.

The gore? Present in just the right amount-enough to make the action visceral without tipping into overindulgence. The highlight for me, as both a hip-hop and action film fan, was the samurai showdown between RZA and Daniel Bernhardt-a sequence that's as stylish as it is electrifying.

And of course, Bob Odenkirk anchors the chaos with another fabulous performance, blending everyman vulnerability with sheer action-hero ferocity. He turns this into an action fest with genuine emotional weight.

Timo has elevated the Nobody franchise into something sharper, bloodier, and unexpectedly heartfelt.
label: literal

text:
Slowly downhill after the first season Most of the glowing reviews here were written in the first season, which was excellent.

Without giving anything important away I'll say that the concept of the series is solid and interesting -- rejects of the British intelligence service are complex and lovable and . . . Surprise they do some things very well.

The problem with the series is that it quickly becomes formulaic: An agent is sent to the Slow Horses department where they are belittled by Gary Oldman. Something bad happens. Everyone underestimates the Slow Horses. They unexpectedly shine. Rinse and repeat over and over, with no explanation of why nobody recognizes their brilliance.

Related, as the seasons churn on we never hear anything about other MI-5 units that should presumably be working the cases. The only thing that MI-5 HQ ever does is send in "the dogs" who are the militarized grunts who break things and shoot people.

Also, Gary Oldman's character has become far too perfect. He's grumpy and doesn't care about anyone and then when everything is about to fail he shows up to bonk someone on the head. That strains realism too much for me.

This series overall is a solid 7 for me. Worth watching but with tempered expectations.
label: figurative

text:
Misses what this story is about completely There... I dissed a Ron Howard movie. Usually a Ron Howard film dictates quality and a light-hearted touch. This is just heavy handed and makes this story into something it was never meant to do.

This is a story about the spirit of Christmas. In the original story, all the Who's of Whoville are not phased by their loss of decorations, libations and gifts. They come together and through their genuine spirit of love, come together, and it is this that makes the Grinch's heart grow.

The movie gives a background to the Grinch... and to boot blames the Whovillians for the Grinch's bad attitude. So wrong and flawed.

The character of Cindy Lou Who builds on that and further impunes the citizens of Who-ville. tsk tsk tsk. That is not the innocent of the original story.

The narration while interesting completely re-writes a beautiful story...tsk tsk tsk Dr. Seuss was right not to let this story be re-told.

The odd thing is that this story could have been abstracted into something altogether different ... much like the re-telling of another Christmas classic... Scrooge.

But no... the theme was used and abused and ended up with a sad tale.
label: figurative

text:
Great show, somewhat diminished by political correctness First of all, after three seasons, I really enjoy this show. It's got Nathan Fillion and a host of other likeable actors, and a decent story. It's fun, it's light and it always leaves me wanting more, as a good show should.

That being said, the magic is constantly broken by their incessant need for female empowerment. As one character mentioned, women make up only about 12% of law enforcement and yet, in this show, they're over-represented to such an extent that one can't help but feel frustrated because they're always present, always right and always boring with their moral, intellectual and, often, physical superiority.

Regardless of this issue, I do recommend this show to anyone looking for a bit of fun and distraction. I just wish they'd tone down the socio-political agenda to make it a bit more palatable.
label: literal

text: Just what the doctor ordered! First of all, THANK YOU for creating this show! I recorded this show hoping for a win. This show is the Mega Million Lottery winner! Life itself right now is drama... currenty, reality is sad, depressing, and bleak. I'm a teacher & my kids live daily with circumstances that would crush a normal adult. Each day I vow to keep doing the right thing and keep hope alive. This TV show offers me "mind candy". More than entertainment, St Denis Medical makes me laugh. The kind of laughter that is healing. An opportunity for my spirits getting renewed, revived, and restored. NBC, I'm using my teacher voice here and I'm giving you my best teacher stare. Keep St. Denis Medical on the air. Do not make me write a note to your Mom.
