text:
Ben Mendelsohn should have been 'Roofman' This feel-good crime caper works hard to convince us that serial McDonald's bandit Jeffrey Manchester - or "Roofman" - was really just a misunderstood nice guy. Channing Tatum brings charisma and heart to the role, but the film stretches credibility when the trigger for his spree is his daughter's disappointment over a Meccano set. It's a sympathy grab that doesn't quite land.

Tatum's performance is undeniably sharp, full of warmth and charm, yet it's hard not to imagine how much darker and more layered the film could've been with Ben Mendelsohn in the lead. He plays Pastor Ron here, radiating the same quiet menace that made him unforgettable in Animal Kingdom - and in doing so, quietly steals his scenes.

Peter Dinklage is deliciously ruthless as a Toys "R" Us tycoon, while Kirsten Dunst gives the film its emotional core as the perpetually imperilled romantic interest, a role straight out of her Spider-Man era.

Still, for all its glossy pacing and rom-com energy, the ending feels like a cheat - a "genius" criminal undone by a bafflingly dumb move. The filmmakers might have been wiser to label it "Based on a true story" and let fiction take the reins.
label: literal

text:
A Relentless March into Fear and Survival The Long Walk (2025), directed by Francis Lawrence, is an unsettling blend of horror, sci-fi, and dystopian thriller that asks a haunting question: how far would you go, and is it really worth it? Adapted from Stephen King's 1979 novel written under the pseudonym Richard Bachman, the film carries forward the author's raw and uncompromising vision but introduces a few fresh angles that make it stand apart from the source material.

The story centers on a brutal contest where teenagers are forced into a life-or-death march. The rules are terrifyingly simple-keep walking, or be executed by the military escort shadowing their every move. Cooper Hoffman takes on the role of Raymond Garraty, with David Jonsson as Peter McVries, and both deliver grounded performances that capture the emotional and physical toll of this relentless ordeal. The supporting cast of young actors also does justice to their roles, though it's the intense premise that truly drives the film forward.

Interestingly, the movie does not stick entirely to King's bleak, solitary meditation on survival. Instead, it explores themes of love, sacrifice, and rebellion against oppressive authority. This shift might divide audiences-purists may miss the unrelenting despair of the book, while others may find the added emotional arcs more relatable and cinematic. One cannot ignore the eerie similarity to Suzanne Collins' The Hunger Games. In fact, this adaptation makes it even clearer that King's novel might have been a twisted inspiration behind Collins' dystopian saga.

From a technical standpoint, the film holds steady. Lawrence's direction ensures that the pacing never falters, and J. T. Mollner's screenplay balances brutality with emotion. The cinematography captures both the vast, desolate landscapes and the suffocating intensity of the march, while the editing and background score add to the film's oppressive atmosphere. Though performances are fairly good, it's really the mood and narrative weight that carry the film.

Overall, The Long Walk is gripping, gruesome, and deeply emotional. While not flawless, it succeeds in making viewers question endurance, humanity, and the cost of survival. For thriller and dystopian fans, it is worth the watch.

Rating: 7/10.
label: literal

text:
Slightly updated, partial retelling of Stephen King's massive tome It's 1988, and a group of young teens in the town of Derry, Maine are terrorized by an otherworldly clown named Pennywise (Bill Skarsgard), who can make them see their worst fears. They must band together to stop the fiend before it kills them all.

King's novel succeeded in large part due to the nostalgic immersion into Baby Boomer cultural touchstones. The filmmakers decision to update the setting to the late 1980's is understandable in the sense that the follow-up, featuring the adult versions of the characters, will now chronologically fit with modern times. The filmmakers also decide to forgo any excessive wallowing in 1980's pop iconography, with a movie poster here and a song there the only references. That boils the story down to the horror film essentials, and while there's nothing original in the mix, it is well presented, and features a handful of memorable scare moments. The special effects are also largely successful, and Skarsgard is good as the monstrous clown. The filmmakers also made the interesting decision to not explain Pennywise, perhaps leaving that for the sequel. I'd be curious what a first time viewer, with no knowledge of the source novel or the previous 1990 TV mini-series version, thought of the story.

I recently caught up with the first season of the TV series Stranger Things, which almost certainly had some impact on this film version of It, even going so far as to cast one of the show's leads in this as well. That's not a problem, though, as that kid (Wolfhard) is good in both, and the rest of the cast in this is also terrific, with Lillis, as the sole girl in the group, and the aforementioned Wolfhard, as the foul-mouthed jokester, the stand-outs.

text:
Was Taylor Sheridan Was Taylor Sheridan involved in the first season, as the difference between seasons is stark.

Season 2 smacks of classic Taylor Sheridan wooden dialogue, whereas Season 1 was much better.

Its a shame as Season 1 was genuinely good.

text:
Really Great I have never watched a show that is as consistently genuine and engaging as Breaking Bad. This is undoubtedly one of the greatest shows ever, and it consistently improves as it progresses.

The Journeys of Walter White and Jesse Pinkman are unforgettable. These are some of the best-written characters to ever come from a pen-hitting paper.

My praises for the acting and cinematography are unending. Some of the shots are intricate works of art, and I was rarely distracted by the acting. The performances are excellent to the extent that it feels improper to refer to them as performances.

Overall, Breaking Bad consistently maintains a level of engagement and technical quality seen in only the best of movies, and in terms of tone, every intense moment is executed with excellence and always achieves the impact it reaches for.

I feel like the show's plot in the early seasons lacks a certain level of complexity due to it not having a vast amount of plot threads, and the start is a bit slow-paced, but Breaking Bad is an absolute must-watch. If you have mixed feelings towards Season 1, trust me, it is only uphill from there.

If there was ever a series you could call perfect, I think this might be it.

text: Why Stella Kidd Ruins the Fun in Chicago Fire As a long-time fan of Chicago Fire, I've realized that not every character fits seamlessly into Firehouse 51, and Stella Kidd is a prime example of this mismatch. While the writers clearly intended her to be a strong leader, her portrayal often leaves the audience questioning her authority and role in the team. Her promotion to lieutenant feels rushed and unearned, as true leadership in a firehouse comes from demonstrated skill and earned respect, yet the show expects us to believe she is authoritative without showing the experiences to justify it. Somewhere in the show, her leadership role turned into a bossy kind of attitude, and the way she leads Truck 81 undermines the authority and legacy of Casey, the very firefighter who made Truck 81 the benchmark for the firehouse. The Stella Kidd character is portrayed like a Fairy Godmother, as if without her the firehouse would not survive, even though it was functioning perfectly fine long before she arrived. To be honest, my love for the show dropped a little after she became lieutenant. She exhibits a know-it-all attitude that clearly shouts ego rather than leadership, and to be fair, she hasn't endured the trials that other characters have to deserve such a spotlight. In so many places, the show sings her praises, implying her reputation precedes her - but "what reputation"? Compared to the other firefighters, she has not done enough to earn that kind of mega-star display. Watching episodes after her promotion has not been a joy ride; the show is supposed to be a source of relaxation and fun, yet her presence often brings tension instead. Unless the writers reshape her character into someone more grounded and authentic, Stella Kidd in her current form injects negativity into the show and its fanbase rather than value.

text:
A Blast to Watch, Despite Being Predictable. "Nobody 2" serves as a good sequel that doesn't rely on the first film. You can watch it as a standalone and enjoy it just as much, although understanding the lore and world the narrative exists in would be beneficial for any true movie buff, so watching the first film is always recommended.

The film's premise is a simple one: Hutch, a hired assassin working off a debt, finds that his work is starting to interfere with his home life. His wife is drifting, he has no idea what his kids are up to, and he struggles to keep up with his chores and responsibilities. He decides to take a break and take his family on a vacation to Plummerville, a small town of which he has fond childhood memories. But as usual, trouble seems to find Hutch, as he stumbles into a town involved in drugs, chemicals, and kidnapping. Hutch reluctantly goes back to work, as it is the only way to keep his family safe on their vacation.

This movie doesn't attempt to reinvent the wheel, nor does it try to copy the inspiration before it (the John Wick series). Instead, it takes the idea of a summer vacation flick and then asks, "But what if Chevy Chase had a particular set of skills?" It is a story that may be forgotten in the long run, but every time you watch it, the movie will bring a smile to your face.

Bob Odenkirk again carries the film with the look and feel of your typical "everyman". He's in good shape, but not built like a Stallone or a Schwarzenegger, and he really gives off the sense of a man in the wrong place at the wrong time. Connie Nielsen gives a great portrayal of a loving wife, and she shines when her character has to have doubts or frustrations in her significant other. Christopher Lloyd serves up some laughs as usual, especially since he is portraying an 87 year old gatling gun operator. Its nice to see some range by John Ortiz (Fast and Furious, Miami Vice), and Sharon Stone is brought back into the spotlight, only this time she is not a love interest but a crazed villain.

The production quality here is outstanding, doing a great job of capturing the magic of an American small town in the middle of summer. The arcade, waterpark, and fair are sure to serve up some nostalgia to anyone that goes to see this film. The music selection also screams classic summer. The cinematography and color palette are excellent, with lots of yellows, greens, and blues. The choice of weaponry is a blast, as the good guys use an armory that seems to be lifted straight out of WW2. I said it before with "Ballerina (2025)", but I'll restate it here: it is so nice to see action movies being treated as more than just shoot-em-ups. The camerawork and production value continue to improve, and I am here for it.

The action here is fun, and it doesn't take itself as serious as a John Wick movie. It strikes a great blend of realism and entertainment, with some kill sequences that are sure to make you laugh. They have also made some creative decisions to not show all of the action, as there are times where you only hear what is happening, rather than always seeing it. Some viewers will like this, and some will not. It is all about your taste and preference.

If I had to point out any negatives, which would definitely be nitpicking, I would say first that the final act has been done many times before. The climactic fight scenes are pulled straight out of the "Home Alone (1990)" playbook, with our heroes booby trapping the fairground like Kevin Malone did his own house. This is not the first time we have seen this borrowed, as James Bond did it in "Skyfall (2012)" and John Rambo did it in "Rambo: Last Blood (2019)". Additionally, Sharon Stone's character does not get much of an exposition, and often times comes across as over-the-top yet somewhat forgettable. And while I appreciated the corrupted Sheriff played by Colin Hanks getting what he deserved, I couldn't help but feel disappointed in how it was done.

Is it cliche? Absolutely. Is it predictable? You bet. But is it a blast to watch? 100%, from start to finish.

Final Rating: 8.4/10.

text:
A lovely ride, until the end. "Have you ever watched Gilmore Girls?" It's what my friend said when she recommended me this show while were discussing my tumultuous family relations. She said: "Give it a shot, you might find it surprising how much you can relate to these characters, their journeys and struggles." Said and done.

I have just finished watching the show and the last episode had me crying from beginning to end, and this is a statement to the most powerful asset the show has: the ability to make us relate and sympathize with the characters. This is a show about relationships: family, friends and love, plus we get to see one the main characters go through high school and college, and who can't relate to those things?! Life is tough and relationships are hard, but to still believe in your goals and dreams despite it all is what this show is all about.

The Gilmore Girls: Lorelai's character (the mom) is the soul of the entire show, her dysfunction relationship with her parents, the hard work put into building her life and independence, the love, care and trust (even if a bit idealized) she shares with her daughter is a wonder to see, she is a living and breathing compulsive joker that made me laugh out loud so many times I lost count, and all of it lets us connect with her in so many levels.

Rory's character (the daughter) is the one everyone wish they were: has good grades, likes to study, is ambitious and above it all has in her mother a best friend and a partner. As she comes of age, we get to see a lot we can relate to: first love, first time, getting to college, existential crisis (every college kid has at least one), graduation and the uncertainties that lies ahead of adulting around.

Emily's character (the grandmother) is the one that makes us understand why all of us gotta go to therapy: because our parents didn't. She is also the reason one of the most iconic parts of the show exists, the Friday night dinners with Lorelai and Rory. The dinners are almost a synthesis of the entire show where these three women, who lead absolutely different lives and want completely different things from one another, try to get together and figure out a way to be a family.

The show is pretty clever in depicting the impact family support can have on someone as well as the result family disfunction can inflict on somebody, and that's what family is all about. But don't get me wrong, sometimes the very lesson the show is trying to teach about the importance of clear communication, and the problems with misinterpretation and assumptions are sometimes used for a lack of better writing, especially concerning Lorelai and Rory's romantic interests throughout the show and are very often frustrating and out of character.

It has a lot of great side characters and the tone and dynamic between them all shifts a bit from season 4 forward. It's a nice depiction of the small-town way of life and has a rare yet kind and considerate take on relationships between generations (grandma, mother and daughter). All and all Gilmore Girls is an up lifting, feel-good and cozy show. I loved this journey and I genuinely think it made me realize and change the way I see myself and deal with my family issues (and all of it while having a good time!). Hope a lot of people give it a shot, because it's definitely worth it.

text:
Still a worthy sequel, even with weak writing Hutch Mansell is back in action, and this time creating chaos on a family vacation.

The sequel to 2022 sleeper hit, Nobody 2 follows the similar route of it's predecessor - a family life, monotonous routine and then boom there's action and drama everywhere. There's a clear picture to keep the spirit of the original alive, while establishing a place of it's own.

The writing is weak, although the action choreography remains the constant. The antagonist in the form of Sharon Stone was thinly written, though the performance was visibly good. The main danger with these types of movies is that all the fighting and shooting and snapping and stabbing and exploding will feel predictable or anonymous in a universe where action movies have become mere background noise. Despite of the weaknesses, Nobody 2 still does good due to standard formula and pretty crazy last act.

Overall, Nobody 2 is a still good sequel to watch - silly and predictable but funny enough to make you sit for 90 minutes.

My Rating : 3.5/5.

text: Melodrama prototype. Douglas Sirk is known as the melodrama man,but all his movies are not exactly what we call melodrama:"All that heaven allows" and"tarnished angels" are closer to realist stories;"A time to love and a time to die" transcends melodrama to become a tragedy.Three major movies seem to belong to the  genre:"written on the wind" "imitation of life " and of course this one."Magnificent obsession " has a plot so unlikely,so incredible that,in the hands of a lesser talent,it would have gathered nothing but horse -laugh:The beginning of the film is a succession of coincidences and combinations of circumstances so improbable you wonder whether Sirk will get away with it.Against all odds,he succeeds in this absurd task.Someone tells the hero that the one who devotes his life to others has chosen the rocky road,someone has been crucified for that.But once he has begun,this task will obsess him,and it's a magnificent obsession.So the selfish hero will undo the harm he's done . It's a double feat:Hudson's struggle is moving and Sirk ,who goes for broke,pulls off this extravaganza with panache.

text:
Overall quite good..some glaring historical inaccuracies I've been enjoying the series. Last evening (episode 3) it was represented that General Howe, during the Battle of Long Island, had left his campfires lit to deceive Washington as to his army's intentions to fall on the Patriots by surprise. I said to my wife " I didn't know that" and went onto tell her that Washington had used the same ploy to deceive Howe when he subsequently withdrew from Long Island to Manhattan. "Did Washington learn a trick from Howe I speculated". The fact that Washington's campfire deception was never mentioned in the episode left me surprised. Following the show I went to my large history library and found numerous references of Washington's campfire deception, but none of Howe's. I also noted several other inaccuracies ( mostly omissions and slants). But, this is only my editorial opinion.

I am not an amateur historian and hold several degrees in history, taught history and was a Fellow at Yale University where I developed and published curriculum for public schools under Yale's auspice. I should add that this period of history is not my specialty and in the early 80's went on to pursue a new career in vertical flight where i was named an Honorary Fellow of the Vertical Flight Society(a distinctive honor awarded to only two persons worldwide annually). I'm retired now for many years and continue to pursue my many and varied interests.

Gary P. Smith.
label: literal

text:
Running Into Reality: This Remake Is Edgier And Less Campier O Sienna Benn LIKES: New Style And Vision Funny Humor In Various Forms.

Moves Quickly Exciting At Points Great Messages Wonderful Music The Acting Is Choice Summary: Another Stephen King plot brought to life, the modern-day approach has captured the dark storytelling that the author is known for. A wonderful world that blends fantasy and fact together, the new age has crafted a much deeper and believable world that feels much like the dystopian future King's writer predicts. Flashy and futuristic, but not to the point of some fantasy, the new city feels very real, which helps add to the darkness of King's world, giving this version its own feel. The new camera work drums up more of the new feel, with a direction that gears towards three different perspectives in this game show created for the masses. Whether I was an audience member, an exec, or the player, this film coordinated its time and energy to successfully pull the movie together, unleashing a dynamic display of chaos. I think this movie was striving to show off.

What does all of this accomplish? Well, it's a spectacle that does feel very much attuned to an adventure at the movie theater...at least at the start. The Running Man remake is loaded with elements that make the theater a good place to view. The music adds those elements of intensity, a vibrant rock and roll-themed track list that accompanies the symphony work that embodies the edginess of the movie. Action scenes are fast and hectic, gun fights and close combat from the trailers, a fair assessment of the chaos to come if you choose to watch it. They hold merit, and don't defy reality too much, which helps add that excitement to the chaos at hand. Amidst the intense battles and high-speed chases, there is plenty of comedy to feast upon, delivered in various styles with a cast who knows how to mix things up. You want aggressive challenges to the higher orders via provocative gestures and excessive cursing? Powell's character has you covered. You need street-smart antics and well-researched information about the broken system? The film has that too! How about neurotic conspiracy theories? Yep, has that too. It's a nice (if slight) release of the pressure, but it was one of the movies I've laughed a lot at in recent times to the films. And somehow, it has great messages that hit hard, all these elements working to arrive at the final third of the movie, where the truth begins to ring out. A tad cheesy at times, the movie uses some cliché moments to get the words out, but with solid delivery and the right support, the messages sank deep with me to try and be better. As for the acting that makes all of it come to life, Powell is continuing to be a fun actor to watch. He blends a lot into this role, primarily the aggressive side of fighting against the network with an intensity that is present in punch, smolder, and the presentation of every word. Other times, he opens that softer and funnier side, which always felt at home and seldom felt forced in as they continued to flesh this character out. The other characters not billed in the top three accomplish much, with several other secondary and tertiary characters an awesome display of the eccentric world that the U. S. is portrayed as. And though it is scary and haunting, it was done with a precise quality I myself like to see.

DISLIKES: Character Balance Is Mundane Conveniences Are Too Much Dark/Depressing Lacks The Same Campiness A Bit Too Close To Home Language/Gestures Hyperaggressive Not As Fun As the First Summary: Where the movie starts to feel off for me is that the movie seems to be too chaotic and realistic, so I'm not getting lost in the film like the 1987 version. For one thing, the character balance is mundane. Heavy hitters like our protagonist and primary antagonist get more than enough time, but other characters feel very lost, forgotten, and disconnected. They serve their purpose, but the haphazard use of characters and rushed time with them felt somewhat disappointing given what they could have been. In addition, the movie feels a bit too convenient at times, each of them adding up with a plot armor that gets a bit too lazy for me. Throw in the realistic focus I was given, and you get to another complaint of how dark and depressing it felt. Arnold's movie had its fair share of hard-to-watch moments, but the campiness and fun factor helped to alleviate the horror. Given the current times, this film is going to hit a lot harder than the other one, and the escape from reality is far less prevalent than I would have liked, which sometimes seems to be King's plan. As that enraging energy pours from the screen, the movie's hyperaggressive language and gestures get tiring for me. Don't get me wrong, some of them are awesome, but eventually the writing grows too fixated on that for me that it loses the magic. For those who are even more sensitive to such things, I strongly advise watching this film to avoid the overwhelming amount of expletives and debauchery to come. Finally, the movie may have a lot of quality elements, but I can't say it was unique, fun, or as standout as the storytelling they did in the original version. While this may not be what everyone wants, not having such unique hunters as the American Gladiator-like seekers from before was something I missed.

The VERDICT: The Running Man is another movie that gets a boost from modern times in many ways. All the technological prowess and improvements sculpt a world that is far more believable and haunting than I anticipated it would ever become, alongside the musical scores to amplify that energy. It has a lot more excitement and stakes to it, with a bit that holds far more of King's darkness than what the previous decades could inject. And the acting continues to show how the artistic style can improve and evolve to give us the splendor to rival what the world seems to be turning into (another benefit from the current times) that pulls all of this into such a visceral piece to watch. With that being sad, I missed the campiness and fun the first film had, especially in trying to escape the reality that the media keeps us entrenched in. The Running Man has a lot more weight to it, and I found myself wishing to either get lost in some brutal fist fights/chases, or at least have some more relief. Alas, this film chooses to stick to the aggressive language, foreboding tones, and the conveniences that feel weaker to me than the unique schtick they chose back in the day. Throw in the characters feel less connected with the haphazard handoffs, limited time, but for a few, and feeling the time ratios were off compared to the potential. However, if you can stomach the darker motifs, handle the aggression, and get to the end, you'll find some inspirational messages that feel very geared toward a particular crowd. Worth the theater visit? Yes, I think so for the spectacle for this designated crowd. What are the scores? Here is what I grade The Running Man: Thriller/Comedy/Action/Dark Comedy/Sci-Fi/Adventure/Survival: 7.0-7.5 Movie Overall: 6.5-7.0.

text: Addicted: Meth or Math. Drug wars, meth, the lot. I thought no thank you. I kept hearing how good it was and I kept saying: "No thank you" Last January I got sick, one of those illnesses you can't quite figure out. Maybe it was pre and post election depression, I don't know. But I stayed in bed for almost 10 days and then it happened. I saw the first episode and I was immediately and I mean immediately, hooked. I saw the entire series in 9 days. Voraciously. Now I had time to reflect. Why I wonder. When I think about it the first thing that comes to mind is not a thing it's Bryan Cranston. I know the concept was superb as was the writing but Bryan Cranston made it all real. His performance, the creation of Walter White will be studied in the Acting classes of the future. He is the one that pulls you forward - as well as backwards and sideways - then I realized that his creation acquired the power that it acquired, in great part thanks to the extraordinary cast of supporting players. I could write a page for each one of them but I'm just going to mention Aaron Paul. I ended up loving him. I developed a visceral need to see him find a way out. Well, what can I tell you. I know that one day, maybe when my kids are old enough, I shall see "Breaking Bad" again. I can't wait.

text:
Not the best of "Superman" movies... Of course I had to check out the 2025 movie "Superman", from director James Gunn, as I did grow up with the Christopher Reeve movies, and of course have watched all subsequent "Superman" movies as well, plus a lot of the animated movies. Though, I have to admit that the superhero genre is not my go-to genre for means of entertainment.

James Gunn did deliver an entertaining enough rendering of the character that was created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster. It is a popcorn movie, visually pleasing, but not one that challenges the audience's intellect in any way. There are simply too many sub-plots in the narrative, and most of them felt they are just brushed over without director James Gunn delving deeper into the sub-plots and giving it the attention and time it needs to be explored properly and brought to the screen. And that made the movie felt rather superficial and rushed, leaving way too many things answered in subpar manners. Director James Gunn simply tried to juggle too many balls here and didn't do a particular good job at it.

Something that really impressed me about the movie was the cast ensemble. There were a lot of familiar and good talents on the cast list. I will say that I think that leading actor David Corenswet actually carried the "Superman" mantle quite well, and he performed nicely in the movie. The acting performances in the movie were good.

I think that Hawkgirl (played by Isabela Merced) was a nice addition to the movie, and Krypto was also a fun addition to the franchise. As for Guy Gardner (played by Nathan Fillion) and Mr. Terrific (played by Edi Gathegi) not so much.

The character gallery in the movie felt somewhat superficial. You don't really get to know any of the characters. Sure, Superman, Clark Kent, Lois Lane, the adoptive parents, Lex Luthor and Jimmy Olson was a given that you would know in advance. But if you never seen a "Superman" movie or animated movie or read a comic book, then writer and director James Gunn didn't do a particular thorough job of letting newcomers into the universe. In fact, a lot of the characters in the movie felt two-dimensional and seemed to be there just because they were written to be there. Many characters were lacking personalities, motivations, drives, etc.

Visually, then "Superman" was nice. The special effects were good, and it looked realistic. Well, as realistic as you would assume from a movie with a flying invincible alien person with super powers. And with "Superman" being a superhero movie, of course having believable effects is a make or break sort of thing, so thankfully the special effects and CGI team worked wonders here.

The sounds were good, and the music score was good. I really liked the return to the original superman theme, because it was nostalgic and just felt like it belonged in a "Superman" movie, even a new one.

Enjoyable for what it was, a popcorn movie. Sure, I was entertained throughout the nearly two hours that the movie ran for. I wasn't overwhelmed or in awe, nor is it a movie that I think I will ever sit down to watch a second time. I will say that when the movie ended, I sat with a sense of 'this movie had potential to be so much more.' I felt a bit disappointed with the overall outcome of the movie.

My rating of writer and director James Gunn's 2025 movie "Superman" lands on a six out of ten stars.
label: figurative

text: This show is so ridiculous Any American-based medical drama that doesn't start with a miserable person wheeling one of those insurance-information carts into a patient's room is going to take several large leaps away from reality - that's a given. And if you've ever had any illness more complicated than stitches, you know there's absolutely zero chance a crack team of physicians is burning the midnight oil in order to pin down exactly what ailment brought you to the ER. Still, no one is going to watch a show about sitting in an ER waiting room for six hours before a doctor shrugs their shoulders, so they made this instead. It's a story about a doctor who hurt other people's feelings by doing things like trying to stop other doctors from killing patients, and then she's hit by a car and loses eight years of memory. This apparently earns her a demotion, becauser in this world there are no job protections. Instead, one of the doctor's who got his feelings hurt because his actions almost had consequences gets a promotion that no one questions, freeing up amnesia-doctor to commence a nonstop apology tour. No memory of the last 8 years, but totally trusts every story she hears about her status as a not-nice person. Questions you might ask yourself while watching this include: why is everyone being so mean to the person with amnesia? Why is everyone cagey around information about her life? What did she actually do beyond speak to people in clipped tones? Why does the social worker act more like a preacher? It was already cringe, but I opted to tap out after a storyline about someone performing their own rape kit, storing it, bringing the information forward years later, and then the police arrest the guy. I've worked as an advocate for victims of sexual assault; the writer of this episode clearly didn't even read a long form article about the legal process before writing this schlock, let alone talk to a victim, a cop, a lawyer, or anyone authorized to perform a rape kit. There's soap opera medical fantasy, and then there's complete and utter drivel that fully dismisses the complexity of rape cases, and how challenging it is for a victim to even see the person she's accusing arrested, let alone charged. There's stupid, and then there's stupid and offensive. Get Scott Wolf off this train, he doesn't deserve to be sentenced to this show.
label: figurative

text:
Explosive Premiere, Cerebral Follow-Up - Both Nail It Two episodes in, The Last Frontier has already nailed the balance between explosive action and cerebral thrills that most shows spend entire seasons chasing.

Ep 1 hits like a freight train... think Con Air meets The Fugitive with a villain smart enough to make you question who you're rooting for. Jason Clarke anchors it with worn-down authenticity, while Alaska's frozen wasteland becomes the perfect pressure cooker for paranoia.

Ep 2 downshifts intelligently, trading spectacle for psychological depth. The flashbacks add moral weight, and Havlock evolves from standard antagonist to genuinely complex threat. Sure, it's slower, but the character work earns every minute.

What impresses most? The show respects your intelligence. No hand-holding, no cheap shortcuts - just taut storytelling that knows when to punch and when to breathe.

If it maintains this momentum, we're looking at the year's best thriller.
label: figurative

text:
Watson Has the Brains and Heart-But the Chemistry's DOA What gives Watson added depth-and elevates it beyond the expected-is its unique approach to Holmes. Rather than rehash the traditional detective genius, the show provides a rich, sometimes tragic backstory that re-centers the narrative through Watson's perspective. This inversion is bold and works beautifully. It adds gravitas and mystery, drawing the viewer in episode after episode.

However, where Watson stumbles is in its supporting cast. A hit show often lives or dies by its ensemble, and unfortunately, outside of Watson and Moriarty, the other characters feel flat or miscast. The chemistry between secondary characters lacks spark, and the dialogue between them rarely crackles the way it should. In a show where relationships and emotional stakes are key, this is a noticeable gap. Great shows-from House to The West Wing-work not just because of a magnetic lead, but because of the rich web of characters surrounding them. Here, that web feels frayed.

Still, Watson is a compelling, thoughtful drama with real narrative ambition. Its take on Holmes lore is one of the most intriguing in recent memory, and the lead performance alone is reason enough to watch. With sharper ensemble casting in future seasons, this could be more than just a great idea-it could be a classic. For now, it's a must-watch with the potential for something even greater.
label: literal

text:
Fascinating concept If you could suddenly relive the last 8 years, would you change anything? If you knew better would you make the same mistakes... would it go better or worse the second time around?

Superimpose that concept on a House-like medical show with interesting cases and a mysterious backstory and you have Doc.

It's devoid of any humour but the suspense and the examination of how our experiences shape our character and whether and to what extent we can reinvent ourselves has me hooked.

Plus the music is consistently on point. I'm hoping the actors develop a little more chemistry but this is still one of the best new shows of the season.

text:
Running turns into Walking The 2025 remake of The Running Man arrives with heavy expectations: to honor Stephen King's original novel while reimagining the cult 1987 Schwarzenegger film. What results, however, is a confused hybrid that struggles to find its identity, weighed down by sluggish pacing and a finale that feels more symbolic than earned.

From the outset, the film signals its ambition. The neon-soaked arenas and corporate dystopia aesthetics are striking, clearly designed to echo both King's bleak vision and the satirical flair of the original movie. Yet ambition alone cannot sustain momentum. Where the 1987 film sprinted with chaotic energy-outrageous villains, relentless action, and campy one-liners-the remake limps, bogged down by exposition and drawn-out transitions. The pacing is its greatest flaw: scenes linger too long, draining tension and leaving audiences waiting for a spark that never arrives.

The climax exemplifies this problem. Ben Richards' decision to kill CEO Dan Killian should land as a cathartic rejection of corruption. Instead, it feels abrupt, more like a narrative checkbox than an emotional crescendo. Killian's offer to corrupt Richards mirrors the novel's themes of systemic exploitation, but the film fails to build sufficient tension to make Richards' refusal resonate. The result is confusion rather than clarity, a finale that gestures toward rebellion without delivering its full weight.

Comparisons highlight the remake's shortcomings. King's novel is grim and uncompromising, ending in Richards' suicide attack against the Network. The 1987 film, by contrast, embraced spectacle, turning dystopia into a satirical bloodsport that entertained even as it critiqued. The remake tries to split the difference, aiming for seriousness while retaining blockbuster polish, but the tonal indecision leaves it hollow.

Ultimately, this Running Man feels like a guardian stripped of urgency: armored in ambition but moving too slowly to protect its own story. It lacks the tragic punch of King's novel and the chaotic fun of Schwarzenegger's film. Instead, it delivers a muddled vision that neither thrills nor devastates. For fans of the franchise, it's a disappointing race-one that stumbles before reaching the finish line.
label: literal

text:
Thank god I decided to give this a chance Let's face facts: Spin-off TV shows tend to fare poorly to the original content. I was furious when I heard about the spin-off to the amazing Break Bad. Nonetheless centering around the buffoonish clown of a character Saul Goodman?! I was livid and heartbroken. I wanted Breaking bad to end on a high note and not let this potential disaster ruin it's legacy.

Breaking Bad was an absolute masterpiece of a show, with an amazing story, script, cinematography; you name it, it's there. But the one thing that made Breaking Bad shine, and in my option, be one of the greatest series ever made was it's deep, deep burial into the characters that made us either absolutely love or loath them. It didn't rely on special effects and had no fat to it whatsoever. No other show encapsulated a slow unfurling of characters so well that it was as if we were getting to know them in our real lives.

I finally decided to give Better Call Saul a shot after hating it's first episode on release. I figured, maybe I could eventually forget about the fact that it was attached to my favorite TV show, and when everybody who watches it is telling you it's amazing, there must be something there.. right?

Boy, were they right. Better Call Saul is just as good as it's predecessor. It maintains it's very high standard to every aspect of the production, and most of all, character development, motivation and relationships are centerfold once more. It is easy to find Better Call Saul even better than Breaking Bad, although I would chalk this up to it being more current and therefore more in the forefront of our minds in the Breaking Bad universe. If you, like me, have hesitated to give this show a shot for the same reasons, stop it. Let yourself feel uncomfortable for the 1st half of the first season, and then let it get it's clutches into you.

I'm so, so very happy I finally decided to give Better Call Saul a shot again 4 years later. With no hesitation, 10/10.
label: figurative

Well Made but Terribly Difficult to Watch This is one of the most difficult reviews I've written. To start off I'd have to give credit where it is due. It was a very well produced series with excellent performances, but at the same time I was conflicted watching it. Even before they exposed the sick people who became fans of him in the later episodes I wondered why I was watching this to begin. There's something wrong with giving all of this fame and glory to this evil lunatic. Unlike many others I've read in the reviews I didn't feel sympathy for him for one second. There are many individuals in this world with sick fantasies and poor upbringings who don't go on to do what he did.

On the other hand I do think it is valuable to learn the history of these types of events as the show particularly did a good job highlighting the systemic flaws that allowed this flame to become a blazing forest fire. I did check the truth behind much of the series and it does do a good job in this respect as well.

Overall, of any series I've ever watched this is definitely one that I couldn't and would never watch again. I learned stuff I didn't know which was valuable , but I hate that these kinds of people live on infamy through productions like this.

text:
Finnish him? No chance! Who doesn't enjoy seeing evil Nazi's beaten to a pulp, torn limb from limb, and generally getting what they deserve? (Answer: other Nazis). Director Jalmari Helander dedicates Sisu to the art of killing goose-stepping fascists, pitting the despicable jack-booted German's against Aatami (Jorma Tommila), a hard-as-nails Finnish commando who doesn't know the meaning of the word 'quit'. After Aatami strikes gold in the wilds of Finland, he makes his way back to civilisation to cash in his hoard, but crosses paths with a Nazi platoon - and we all know that Nazis like to steal gold!!

However, trying to take Aatami's treasure proves to be a big mistake: no matter what the German's do to him, he simply won't give up until he has gold back and every last Nazi is dead. The fact that the Finnish soldier is so indestructible takes some swallowing, until it becomes clear that his nickname - The Immortal - is to be taken at face value: this bloke has more lives than a cat. Once you wrap your head around the fact that Aatami simply does not die, the film becomes all the more fun, as the enemy come to realise that taking an immortal's hard-earned riches is an even dumber move than nicking a leprechaun's pot of gold.

In terms of style, the film is very Tarantino-esque, split into 6 chapters, each introduced with a big bold title; the violence is graphic, with lots of blood and guts. There's even a group of female Finnish POWs who lend Aatami a hand in killing the baddies - and there's nowt more Tarantino than a gang of women unloading machine guns into a truck of Nazis. The ending takes the craziness up to eleven as the nastiest Nazi, Bruno (Aksel Hennie), makes his escape on a plane, unaware the Aatami has hitched a ride. The action ends with a bang for both Bruno and Aatami, but only one of them is immortal...

One might argue that the plot is slight, and the film derivative in terms of execution, but if you're after a bit of mindlessly violent popcorn entertainment and found John Wick 4 needlessly overblown and overlong, this one should do the trick: it clocks in at a far more reasonable ninety-one minutes.
label: figurative

text:
Disappointing I'll start off my review with some of the things that makes this at least a watchable show. To preface, I have not seen season 2 nor do I plan on it, as I have only heard negative things about it. I figured if I didn't think season 1 was all that, then I may as well not bother with season 2 as even the biggest fans of this show say it's not good.

Pros: The animation is great. Fight scenes are super cool and very well put together, however being that it came out in 2016 that is somewhat expected nowadays. Leapfrogging off of that point, the character design is amazing too. All characters are extremely different in look and it's a masterpiece in design. Saitama's look is absolutely perfect given the nature of his deadpan, I'm bored with everything personality and it provides humor throughout the show. The last pro I'll give here is that there is humorous elements throughout, and it's a nice switch up compared to other shows that are all serious. However, it's not enough to where it stands out. For example, Demon Slayer has humorous elements, but you would never say it's a funny show. I think the same can be said here. The humor provides levity but I think it's somewhat exaggerated by others.

Cons: There's virtually no plot. Every episode is essentially a different monster and another battle. There is no backstory to anything and they just kind of show up to destroy the city. Eventually Saitama comes in and gives them his "one punch", then off to the next episode. Sure, there are some enemies that last a few episodes, but no more than that. Secondly, as a whole Saitama is a very weak main character. There's virtually no backstory to him outside of him saving a child and becoming a hero after that, and there is no mention as to how he's some sort of god. I suppose we just have to come up with our own conclusions as to how he got those powers? At one point Genos asks him his secret, to which he tells him to do 100 sit-ups and push-ups everyday. Sure it's an element of humor, but it just adds to the lack of depth he has as a character. Another problem I have with the show is that every fight with Saitama is predictable. You know he's going to win because he's the strongest man in the universe. This is something great shows always avoid, because it eliminates any sense of worry or urgency to his actions. In the last episode the "ruler of the universe" or whatever gives him a beating, but he comes off unscathed and kills him. It just makes the show boring as a whole and the whole idea of a "one punch man" is something a 4th grader would come up in during English class.

Overall, this show does not deserve an IMDB 8.8. I only felt the urge to write a review because of how overrated it is. It's enjoyable for about 4 episodes until you realize the show has little to know plot. New monster, new bad guys, new hero's, next episode. That mixed in with the fact that the main character is dry and too powerful for the show to be interesting has me not wanting to watch any more. I can see why people would enjoy it, but anyone who truly values a good plot line will be disappointed. Worth the watch? In my opinion it's a skip, but not a complete waste of time if you do give it a shot.

text:
Not laugh out loud funny, but still hilarious Yes, almost all characters are extremely unlikable, but I think that's the charm of The White Lotus. You can definitely still see each of their motivations and I feel like the writers were very self aware of the stereotypes they put in each main character. The comedy for me was on point, but it might be disappointing for people who prefer punchline jokes. The music was pretty awesome and it set a very specific tone to the series.

The story is pretty good, but my main criticism is that it makes you think that all the characters' side stories would come together at some point, but I just didn't think that happened in a satisfying way. The different groups only interact with each other on a few scenes, and with very few exception, the encounters barely make any difference to the plot. Besides, some side encounters make no sense, like the quick appearance of the pregnant lady from the first episode. I'm still trying to figure out what the hell she was there for.

All things considered, I highly recommend it to people who like satirical comedy. Great main characters and pretty good storyline.

text:
Holy Smokes and Stacks 'Sinners' is a dark, stylish and genuinely fresh take on the vampire genre. Set in 1930s Mississippi, it blends the gothic with the spiritual - vampires, church, blues music, and the weight of the segregated South - into something bold and unforgettable.

Michael B. Jordan is magnetic playing twin brothers Smoke and Stack, each with their own vibe and purpose. Their chemistry anchors the film, but it's Hailee Steinfeld who steals scenes as Mary - a layered, quietly powerful performance that grounds the more surreal elements.

There's a dark humour running beneath it all, and the music is incredible - bluesy, moody, full of soul. It's a film that takes risks with tone and style, but it all comes together. Vicious, vibey, and unlike anything else in the genre.
label: literal

He's obnoxious and disgusting and deserves to be locked up and throw away the key. Jeremy Allen White as Lip is the same in THE BEAR as he is in this. text:
First and second episode only review Episode 1. So, I just watched the first episode of the new IT series, and yes, I'll keep watching because I've always been a huge IT fan.

Honestly, I get that IT is all about imagination... it's meant to be something you experience through the eyes of children, where fantasy and fear blend together. That part I respect. But the way they used CGI and fake-looking sets... nope. It completely kills the vibe. It's overdone, unrealistic, and honestly kind of ridiculous at times.

As for the child actors, they're not terrible, but it feels like déjà vu. Like we've seen this exact lineup a hundred times before. Everything feels recycled and generic.

At this point, if we're going to rely that much on CGI, we might as well let AI make the whole movie and honestly, I think I'd prefer that over this cartoonish visual style.

Anyway, that's just my take after episode one. I'll keep watching and see how it evolves but let's just say, my expectations are officially on pause for now.

Episode 2 of IT: Honestly, it just confirms what I said in my review of the first one, the CGI completely kills the atmosphere. It feels like they're trying to make up for a flat storyline with visual effects, but it only makes everything look fake and lifeless. There's no tension, no real fear, nothing unsettling about it.

And again, it's all so déjà vu. The kids are OK actors but it's the same formula we've seen a thousand times: the bullied kid, the abusive parent, the depressed mom, the family trauma. It's like they're following the Stephen King cliché checklist, updated for 2025.

As for horror? None. Not a single scene feels scary or even suspenseful. Everything is so polished and predictable that you never actually feel on edge. It's starting to feel more like a sad drama about traumatized kids than a horror series.

Honestly, I'm just waiting for Bill Skarsgård to show up, because right now, even the plot feels painfully slow and uninspired. Nothing grabs you. If they don't start bringing real horror into it soon, this might just end up being another overproduced, CGI-filled flop.
label: figurative

text: Zach Creggar is becoming a favorite Weapons is a masterclass in modern horror filmmaking. It may not aim to scare in the traditional sense, but it excels in ways that matter far more: cinematography, writing, directing, and narrative structure. Zach Cregger has crafted one of the most visually stunning and narratively intricate horror films of recent years. What makes Weapons exceptional is its anthology-like structure. The way it transitions between characters and storylines feels seamless, almost effortless, yet the precision behind it is clear. On first viewing, I was immediately hooked, and with each subsequent watch, the film revealed layers of continuity and clever detail that only enhanced my appreciation. Pacing is deliberate, and while some may find it slow at first, it is methodical rather than dragging. Each beat and character arc is carefully constructed, creating a slow burn tension that rewards attentive viewers. Unlike most horror films that lose their impact after a single watch, Weapons continues to reveal new nuances, making rewatching a joy. This is a near perfect execution of a complex narrative in the horror genre. It demonstrates a level of craft and ambition that elevates it above most contemporaries. After multiple viewings, it earns an 8.6/10, and Zach Cregger solidifies himself as a director to watch. For me, Weapons is already shaping up to be one of the standout films of 2025.
label: literal

text:
Merry Christmas to All... I have been eagerly anticipating the opening of this film for several months.  Being a huge Jim Carrey fan, I easily saw how he could morph himself into Seuss' Grinch and make the character his own.  I was not disappointed.  

This movie was pure magic.  Carrey is a master at his trade and no one could have played this role to perfection as he did.  There was plenty to enjoy for both adults and children alike and this movie is sure to become a timeless classic for all to enjoy in the years to come.  I already have visions of my young daughter sitting down year after year to watch this remake on video, and I undoubtedly will watch with her and laugh as I did the first time I saw it.

Clearly, this movie has Jim Carrey written all over it, and I do not believe that it would have come together without him.  However, the supporting cast was charming and entertaining in their own right, most notably the adorable Taylor Momsen who was the perfect foil for Carrey's antics.  The set design, musical score and costumes all lent their hands to a magical, fabulous finished product and I believe all involved can be proud. 

 It is not an easy feat to turn a 22 minute cartoon classic into a full length live action film, but Howard has succeeded with flying colours.  For those critics who disagree, perhaps it is your hearts that are 2 sizes too small.
label: literal

text:
Wastes of lot of time on unnecessary/repetitive dialogue. Most of the humor falls sooooo flat! There were some things I liked about the movie, but I will just make mention of a couple things that sucked!  Alright! We get it! Eddie is a hypochondriac! I don't understand why the movie dedicates 1/4 of it's total run time on dialogue and scenes related to Eddie being a hypochondriac.So, we already get a full dose of it while we're at Eddie's house. Now it cuts to them talking before coming up to the sewer/tunnel and the conversation is something along the lines of Eddie thinking every plant is poison ivy. The hypochondriac talk continues the entire time while they stand in the entrance and while some of the kids proceed a little ways into the tunnel (several minutes). I can't believe that they didn't catch this in the cutting room floor. Not only did they not catch it, the very next scene after they leave the tunnel cuts to them ridding their bikes and they have the balls to dub in more dialogue of Eddie being a hypocondriac. AT this point it's already soooo insanely old, but that's only the tip of the iceburgh.  What were they thinking? Did they think this was humorous? Is performing a rendition of the same joke several dozen times funny? 

Which takes me to how unfunny this director must be. The movie utilizes Richie for most of the movies so called jokes. Early on Richie has a couple chuckle worthy one liners, but after that the jokes fall so insanely flat... they bomb so hard that they're cringe worthy. It's so bad that you would think that this movie was directed by a foreigner. If you're not familiar, humor almost always does not convert well when people learn a new language, then write jokes in that language regardless of how well they know that 2nd language. That's how most of the humor plays out in this movie.
label: literal

text:
80s Teen Surrealism The teen movie genre of the 1980s had as its central premise 'finding a partner'. So this movie is no exception but where it differs is its bizarre way of hammering home the obvious messages this film contains.

 The plot for those who aren't aware concerns two 'nerds' who decide to create a woman using their computer(!).  As a young teen myself watching this for the first time I never really considered how totally out there this John Hughes film is.  Apart from the idea of creating a perfect woman who does everything you want (a horrendously sexist idea that is hardly redeemed by the weak moralising at the end), we have snow falling in someones' bedroom, a kitchen turned blue, nuclear warheads sprouting through a bedroom floor and furniture flying through chimneys.  The one part of this film that really strikes me as odd is where did Kelly Le Brock (who plays Lisa the created woman) get her powers to make all this weird stuff happen?

I was pretty disappointed when I revisited this.  Nostalgia had created this movie as a minor classic in my rose tinted eyes. In reality all I found was a plot full of holes, an unpleasant teen fantasy and a director who looked like he couldn't give a damn about any more 'nerdy teens come good'.
label: literal

text: Bedtime Detectives "NCIS" has been a champion on CBS for so many years now. It's a tried and true formula that, despite it's repetitiveness, it satisfies as a mid-evening, comfy procedural. Though the cast has changed many times, it recycles stories, though doesn't feel like a replay. To be fair, there's only so many things that can happen, but what helps immensely is the cast. Throughout the seasons, even though there's much turnover, the NCIS team is a family, a work family, and the kind you'd like to spend time with and get to know. The dramatic nature of a serious procedural can use a spruce of humor, here and there, and that certainly makes it easier to digest. Over the years, the amount of episodes that were a little more violent or gross in some minor way have been few and far between. This isn't "SVU". It's a show that seems almost quaint. You sense the characters love each other. There's playful jabs, and puns. It's definitely a safer show than similar fare. A lot of people think of this show as a show for old guys. I can see why they'd say that. CBS certainly leans that way, demographic wise, but it's easygoing for the most part, and a good way to wrap up a night.
label: literal

text:
I really wanted to love this It honestly hurts to say, but I found this movie to be quite boring. The actors all do a good job, especially David Johnson and Cooper Hoffman, but the characters were written pretty flat. They each get assigned a pretty standard stereotype and no one really changes much throughout the walk. Yes we get to know more about some of their backstories, but that's about it. However I certainly liked the friendships between the musketeers and they were sweet but also tragic to watch knowing they'll have to die.

Unfortunately I've found the film to be repetitive, as well. They walk and bond --> someone gets hurt --> they all encourage him to keep walking --> he gets shot. Over and over again.

Maybe it's just me, but I also didn't really understand what the whole point of the long walk is? How would something like this inspire the American people to get off their feet and rebuild their nation?

I do think that this is the best you can do with this material. I would have hoped for more striking visuals which bring out the apparent dystopia. We never see much of that in the scenery except for a dead animal and a burning car. Maybe I'll like it more when I rewatch it because I do think that the premise is really fascinating.

Maybe I'll like it more when I rewatch it sometime, I really hope I will.
label: figurative

text: The Marvel experience we've come to know and love has returned The first ten years of Marvel were iconic in movie history, but why? That was the Marvel experience for me.. not the fact they copied existing comic book stories to a different format, but the comics were an inspiration for the movie makers. Even fans couldn't predict the outcome of Infinity War. And all that, that's the experience I had with this movie, for me the Marvel experience I came to know and love..

text:
I should have loved this on paper - beautiful production, but a weak theme and misaligned casting. I love AHS, Scream Queens, and most things on Ryan Murphy's list, so I really should have loved this. Instead, I feel a bit meh so far.

Pros 
* The show looks stunning - beautiful cinematography, flawless styling, and a great set.



* The writing is tight with good comedic timing, even though it's not laugh-out-loud funny (nor is it meant to be).



* Sarah Paulson is fantastic, as always. She's the only reason I didn't switch off before the end of Episode 1.


Cons 1. Weak theme I'm a woman in my mid-30s, and I struggled to connect with the premise. The audience for this feels very narrow - it leans toward a "middle-aged-women-vs-men" dynamic that feels cliché and one-dimensional. The storyline often feels biased, with anything that doesn't fit the narrative brushed aside. It ends up feeling more toxic than empowering.

2. Casting issues I found myself zoning out whenever Sarah Paulson or Niecy Nash weren't on screen. Even with a stronger cast, the underlying theme would still be a problem, but better casting could elevate things at least slightly. Regarding Kim K - I think she's ok for someone that didn't grow up in acting school - but not every producer needs to be on-screen.

Overall The concept of an all-women law firm focused solely on divorce is extremely narrow, and it ends up being one of the show's biggest weaknesses. The theme doesn't have enough depth to sustain the story.

Based on how things are going, I'll finish Season 1 to see where it lands, but I'm unlikely to continue beyond that unless the direction changes significantly.
label: literal

text: Jackie Brown meets Hunt for Red October This film is tense. It's split into three, but by the end of the first third, I needed a break to breathe. It's about details a lot as the same story is retold three times. You have to suspend a little bit of disbelief to allow the story to unfold. As a viewer, you're elicited to join in the reaction to "what do you mean you don't know". The build up attempts to carry mini stories a bit like crash (the 2004 film), but I found these distracting to the point where big moments needed to be filtered out. Everything is building up to a decision which needs to be made. But it's the last third where I felt the tension let up and eased off. I wouldn't recommend this film, especially right now politically where the implications are obvious. But it's one to go out and watch and then discuss over cocktails with someone bright and switched on. I've been careful in this review to give nothing away, but it's inherent in my rating.
label: literal

text:
A Christmas cracker with genuinely funny jokes. If you're stuck for gift ideas for that special someone this Christmas, why not give them the gift of laughter with the Chevy Chase comedy classic 'National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation? Heartwarming and hilarious, this festive favourite will guarantee a very merry time.

Chase plays Clark Griswold, a well intentioned family man whose plans for the perfect Christmas go disastrously wrong: the thousands of lights that adorn his home refuse to work; his in-laws argue with his parents; the Christmas tree goes up in flames; he is trapped in the attic while hiding his gifts; a sledging incident almost costs him his life; the turkey is overdone; his embarrassing hick relatives turn up expectedly for the holidays; a wild squirrel invades the home; and worst of all, his bonus cheque seems to have gone missing in the post.

Naturally, by the time Christmas Day arrives, Clark is a complete nervous wreck, and when he discovers that his Christmas bonus is a 'year's membership to a jelly club', rather than the expected cash bonus, his temper finally snaps (of course, this being a good natured Christmas tale, everything turns out right in the end, thanks to the intervention of dumb, but well-meaning Cousin Eddie).

Written by 80s comedy genius John Hughes, Christmas Vacation's script is bristling with very funny lines of dialogue, but it is the visual gags that get the biggest laughs: Clark somehow driving the family saloon between the wheels of a huge truck; the bushy tailed rodent clinging to Clark's back; the sight of Clark careering across a freeway on a well oiled sled. Chase gives one of his most memorable performances, making Clark a thoroughly likable character that one can't help but admire, despite his failures, and he is given able support by a superb cast that includes Beverly D'Angelo as his long suffering wife Ellen, Randy Quaid as Cousin Eddie, and Juliette Lewis as his daughter Audrey.

And the best thing about the film? You can watch it time after time and it'll always put a smile on your face; it really is the gift that keeps on giving.
label: literal

text: I don't know what to think.. I appreciate acting, cinematography, music, settings, locations, lighting...the works, in films. But I just can't seem to love this. text:
It's time to pull the plug! At first, I was thrilled to have watched Law & Order with its sharp, sophisticated writing and its New York City backdrop. But it's been 18 years since its preview, I think now is the time to end the show. I can see stories repeating themselves with a different cast and a different circumstance.

Law & Order like other shows have the run its course at least 8 years ago. I am grateful that they hire some of New York City's actors and actresses along with its cast and crew. But sadly, the show's legacy is that it's been on too long. The first years were great because it was new and fresh and now we are saying goodbye to beloved cast mates. I remember fondly seeing Jerry Orbach and Benjamin Bratt on the East 35th Street in New York City in October 1997. They were warm, friendly and gracious to us onlookers. They posed for the camera and smiled at us while they were doing their job.

It's one of my favorite memories of working in New York City was seeing them even though I was fired from my job that week. Law & Order is focused on the investigation and the trial but the show does it only in 40 minutes. It's not enough time for an actual investigation.
label: literal

text: Declining series Just finished binge watching Season 14 and I have watched this show since the beginning. Maybe the producers or whomever are trying to set a record for the length of the series, but there is little other reason for this show to continue. The exit of vital characters like Ziva & DiNozzo has created a downward slide into mis-casting key roles and creating dubious plots. The one bright spot in casting is Reeves, the MI6 transplant - both the actor and the character bring a breath of fresh air to the otherwise dowdy team. The loss of Vance's wife and Ziva's father was a preposterous plot twist. The addition of Quinn and Torres to fill the gaps in the NCIS team is weak and failing. Quinn has nothing to do and Torres doesn't belong there. Neither character is interesting nor entertaining in any way. Maybe, like Reeves, the producers should have considered another foreign import, French or Swedish?, to add some dimension. Bishop is marginally effective as an analyst, but is not believable as a field agent. It would have been better to keep her married and have her be the nerdy info bank who gathers and sorts backgrounds & personality profiles, even if it were a smaller role. That kind of role would be a fair replacement for the departing Abby, and Bishop's tricky relationship with her NSA lawyer-husband would have brought new fodder to episodes. And why do we have to be subjected to Jimmy Palmer's buffoonery in every episode, said buffoon scenes becoming longer with each passing season? I'm also now very tired of Franks showing up in a delusion to drive a story. Kind of pathetic. There is lots more I could say but basically it's time for this series to go out with some dignity left. I know the show has been slated for a 16th season but I can't imagine it getting any better if it stays on the same path.
label: figurative

May as well have been a generic disney adventure film Whose idea was it to turn Predator into a beat-for-beat Disney-style adventure film? This is Predator in name only. text:
More like keeping it close is it's best needed Keeper is one of those movies where it has a good concept, atmosphere and moments, but the underdeveloped characters and the poor writing fails to impress itself and makes a dreading slow experience.

Osgood Perkins has proven to be a great director. His works on Longlegs, The Blackout's Daughter, and Gretel & Hansel are slow-burn yet unique takes on horror storytelling that I have liked. Throughout, Perkins does try to establish some interesting directing choices within the setting and tone. There are some good camerawork and colorful presentation that helps display the creepy atmosphere and vibes. Tatiana Maslany performance was very good as her performances offers some genuine scares and emotions.

Unfortunately, Perkins can't save it because the story itself, feels lacking. Many writing and developments feel predictable, and filled with horror tropes. Alongside with the dialogue being silly, the characters are poorly developed. The main two lead stars lack chemistry and it made it very difficult to believe a single word from any of them. Which makes the pacing, structure and emotional engagement and scares feel thin and boring. However, Perkins' isn't writing this movie as he usually doe, so I can't blame him for the movie being poorly done, it's mainly the writing that drags it.

At it's core, a disappointment. But I still look forward to see what Osgood does next.
label: literal

text:
A disturning attempt to romanticize women s self-sacrificce This movie was incredibly frustrating to watch. It tries to normalize and even idealize a situation that is actually deeply unfair, unhealthy, and damaging. We follow a woman who gives up her dreams, ambitions, and entire career for her family, while her husband focuses solely on his own success. Then classicaly he goes on to have a affair with a woman many years younger.

Instead of showing the injustice of this dynamic, the film portrays her endless self-sacrifice as something noble-as if her suffering is beautiful and moral. She remains loyal, untouched, and supportive and of course always available as soon as he remembers her. The movie completely ignores her emotional reality and presents this toxic arrangement as if it were love or destiny.

It was painful to watch a story where a woman's needs, dignity, and boundaries are erased, and the narrative rewards the very behaviour that hurts her. Instead of challenging harmful patterns, the film celebrates them. For me, this wasn't romantic or inspiring-it was disturbing, regressive, and disappointing.

At the end of the movie she abandons her needs again and instead of pursuing her dream job, since her kids dont need her anymore, she falls for a "romantic" bate that her almost ex husband threw her that he will follow her and abandon his career and she rushes to tell him that she changed her mind and she will continue being a housewife..... Another movie that normalises women s self sacrifice ...such a prototype!
label: literal

text: Tale of a bygone presidential assassination I know what you've been thinking ever since "Parks and Recreation" went off of the air: When will our beloved Ron Swanson (a.k.a. Nick Offerman) finally get to sink his teeth into the meaty dramatic role of Chester Arthur? Well, when the great actor Michael Shannon finally gets to portray the slain 19th century POTUS, James A. Garfield (and the great actress, Betty Gilpin, to play his wife), that's when! Duh, obviously. And this four-part limited mini-series fits this biographical bill just perfectly. text:
A great exercise on style capped by truly wonderful return to from JLaw. In your face depiction of a woman is on the verge of a breakdown, a recently pregnant woman just does not want to be in this cloistered world in rural America, alone with her daughter and a sexless marriage - she crumbles as she tries to make sense of her situation. She unravels in her own little prison in rural America where everyone wants to understand her but in return, she runs away to her own.

It really hark the great feminist film about depression and the 'societal' pressure of motherhood and all. It a story as old as time from Mrs Beudet, to film's own Grace.

This is what I expect film like mother! Or Nightbitch would do. I guess it really helped that JLaw was not pigeonholed into this selfless victim narrative or unlike both, the 'surrealism' is handled with a more natural flair. She is an active participant of the exercise and she victimizes herself because she adheres to that social contract. She wants to escape it but she feels indebted. She is in the system she hates. You can see a woman wrote this, because in the end - she is that bird in the large cage meme. The women is in theory free, but she is making the mistake 'society' expects her to make.

She has all this options and easy outs, but she and her husband (who played well by RPatz ) was in this toxic cycle of trying to make things work but neither is willing to do their own half.

Another section I really loved about the film is is the visuals - best of the year in fact. I think the only Ramsey film I had watched had been the Kevin film and this could not been further from that. The quirky choice to just shade morning scenes into night scenes, the visualization of her depression and just the choices it does in more intimate moments (the repeated framing of the depth of the homespace, the overall muted/cooler tones, Pastel and Deep Green MidWest vibes). Everything about this is beauty defined.

As noted, I really love how the film does goes for artsier and 'transcendental' filmmaking techniques to show the rather confused state of Grace. It really makes it more palatable for me. I personally prefer that over the 'spelled' approaches of already mentioned films above. It captures the insanity in a way that does not breech corniness and pseudo-hifalutin-ness.

Then JLaw. Bravo for her. She really made this film. I love how she refuses to make her likable and makes her real rough any chance she got. She really relishes the character's standoffishness to full effect. Every piqued choices is smart and delivers a definition to a very elusive character. The film never really defines her except as a mother ( who is formerly a writer) in the end. She never gets a backstory or her hidden stories are never truly revealed. Also, loved Sissy Spacek in her support role. She colors the character so well. This is a character she had played in some way but she still is able to keep it so interesting. Meh on RPatz. He is the weak point of the film. He dozes far too conveniently at times.

I do have reservation on the overall structure of the film. I was mustering why I did not really give a masterpiece it even though I have so much love for the craft of it all. I get that she is depressed and she wants something more but it clicks by minute one. It lack that certain that like clockwork complication. There is gears but its a basic ass clock. You know the story the minute it started but I really still liked it.

Highly recommended. I wonder how was this re-edited I heard the original Cannes got so muted responses , so they pushed to edit this up.
label: figurative

text:
Now if only we could have an Afghan Disney Princess.. As far as animation goes, Moana is a tremendous achievement.

As far as the Disney mass-hysteria goes, Moana breaks a few trends.

As far as anything else goes -- you know, things that make a *movie*, Moana is an average motion-picture regurgitated from clichés too numerous to list and too hastily mashed together to have any kind of coherent effect.


* A princess wants to do things differently. (Opportunity for getting a bunch of adventurous-sounding rhymes stuck in teenage girls' head: Check. Now we have 2016's "Let it Go".)



* An authority figure wants her to stick to old ways.



* Another -- warmer -- authority figure believes in the princess.


-Magic.


* The princess is thrust into situations she is definitely not prepared for. But well, her grandma *believes* in her.



* Meets a jock.



* Gets constantly in trouble and needs to be helped by the jock or (literally) by forces of nature.



* Moments of self-doubt.



* The princess' moment of self-doubt is resolved by a vision of her dead-grandma.



* The jock's moment of self-doubt is resolved by the princess.



* Bunch of evil things.



* Everything fails.



* The princess saves the day with a song.


It's very rare that I end up sounding so cynical about a movie. I liked Zootopia. I'm okay with reusing certain plot techniques in a way that makes sense. But Moana focuses too much on character design, Polynesian "authenticity" and the must-break-the-glass-ceiling bandwagon that it kind of forgets that a movie is not only made by marketing and press, but also by its own innate qualities.
label: literal
