text:
I wanted to like it... I love it when movies mix different genres and create a fresh spin on old themes. In this case however the different elements didn't mix well in my opinion: I would describe sinners as a mix between period gangster drama, musical and trashy B-movie horror. This sounds super exciting on paper, but in reality it threw me off completely. I feel like the movie tries to do everything at the same time but doesn't deliver on many of those aspects: It wants to hit the viewer on an emotional level but left me personally completely cold - I didn't care who died or who lived; The movie kinda wants to be scary but the "enemies" in the film feel like a complete joke from the first scene they are shown and it takes away all the tension; It wants to be action-packed and explosive, but the fight scenes are kinda boring and left me wanting to move on to more serious scenes again, even though those serious scenes are kind of a slow burn; The film wants to be funny and even though it made me chuckle a bit it never really took it far enough to justify sacrificing the big threat in the film for laughs.

In conclusion: This movie is too boring and slow to be an entertaining action-comedy and doesn't take the humor and fight scenes far enough to really have an impact. At the same time this movie is far too ridiculous to be a serious scary and emotional movie that reaches you on any kind of emotional level.

I would have liked it, if they would have sacrificed the humor for building a serious threat that feels genuinely scary and terrifying. The cinematography, costumes and music are fantastic but this is just not enough for me to make it a good film, when the story is not hitting. There are single parts of the movie that I absolutely loved and I would have really appreciated those scenes as standalone music videos, but it just doesn't mix well with the rest in my personal opinion.

In addition to my previous criticisms I spotted some typical clichés in the dialogue writing that made me roll my eyes and there were some moments where I found it extremely hard to believe that certain characters survived. I could go in to detail here but I want to keep my review vague to avoid spoilers.

To me watching this movie felt a bit like eating chocolate on a burger - Both elements are nice by themselves but together they don't make for a nice meal.
label: literal

text:
Die My Love tackles a difficult subject with brilliance and compassion My wife and I saw Die My Love (2025) in theaters last night. The storyline follows a young woman living with her traveling husband and their son in a small house in the middle of nowhere. As her needs go unmet and she struggles with isolation, her mental state begins to deteriorate. Can her husband and family help her, or will she spiral out of control?

This picture is directed by Lynne Ramsay (We Need to Talk About Kevin) and stars Jennifer Lawrence (The Hunger Games), Robert Pattinson (Twilight), Sissy Spacek (Carrie), and LaKeith Stanfield (Atlanta).

The writing and execution of this film are outstanding. It powerfully explores postpartum depression, the impact of isolation, and the absence of a stable support system. The film also portrays, with nuance, a husband who's trying to help but doesn't know how. Lawrence and Pattinson deliver exceptional, deeply authentic performances, and Spacek shines in a strong supporting role. As the mental health decline unfolds, you can feel how each character struggles to cope, to improve, and to hold on-even when they don't know what to do next or whether it will work. The ending serves as a perfect symbol of hopelessness.

In conclusion, Die My Love tackles a difficult subject with brilliance and compassion. I'd give it an 8/10 and strongly recommend it.
label: figurative

text:
The Gilligan's Island of Haunted Houses. Sure, the show was inspired by the British series; but after the first episode, there have been only a handful of similarities.

The ghosts are somewhat stereotypes of characters and attitudes representing the periods in which they lived and the class/genre or persons they represent. Like the characters from Gilligan's Island, they are given plots and stories allowing them to bounce off each other in a very hilarious way.

True, they lack the cruelty displayed by some of their British counterparts (a common difference between British and American comedies), but this allows the audience to like them more and to care about what they experience.

This show works. May it see many seasons!

text:
The Actors delivered My favorite genre is horror/scary. Although there are so many subcategories. There seems to be a flood of horror, scary movies in cinemas so dreams do come true, good movies in this category! Anyway, I seldom see such a stellar group of actors who are engaged in their characters as I did in Weapons. I am happy to see Garner come back as the actor I liked (Royal Hotel, One Percent More Humid to name a couple of prior movies) due to her ability to bring nuance and a wide range of depth to her characters, including Justine Gandy in Weapons.

The movie Garner was in January 2025, had Garner's character being so one-dimensional, I wondered "what the heck is going on". Although some say the director is the most vital ingredient in movies, I say no, the actors are where it resides in making or breaking a movie. A good actor can catch things (many things actually) and some actors go into direct, actually a good number. Whereas those who start directing seldom make it into acting. Good actors can understand both aspects and are the most important thing to a movie. So yes I am also saying Garner missed an opportunity with the January 2025 movie, to make sure the character delivered. A character is all within the control of the actor assigned to the role, to say otherwise is not taking ownership. In Weapons Garner delivers the goods in the role for the character, as Garner has done so much and Garner is what 30 or so, quite amazing.

Just to give them all credit (yes, there are more actors in this flick, but these are the main ones).

Josh Brolin as Archer Graff, the father of Matthew, one of the missing children.

Julia Garner as Justine Gandy, a teacher who finds that almost all her class has vanished.

Cary Christopher as Alex Lilly, the only child from Justine's class who did not disappear.

Alden Ehrenreich as Paul Morgan, a police officer who has a complicated relationship with Justine.

Austin Abrams as James, a homeless drug addict and burglar.

Benedict Wong as Andrew Marcus, the school principal.

Amy Madigan as Gladys Lilly, Alex's "great aunt" Toby Huss as Ed Locke, the police captain and Donna's father.

June Diane Raphael as Donna Morgan, Paul's wife.

Whitmer Thomas as Mr. Lilly, Alex's loving father.

Callie Schuttera as Mrs. Lilly, Alex's loving mother.

Clayton Farris as Terry Marcus, Andrew's husband.

Luke Speakman as Matthew Graff, Archer's son and one of Justine's missing students.

Scarlett Sher as the child narrator of the film.

All these actors brought their characters alive. Great job. Yet a special shout out I have to say goes to Amy Madigan as Gladys Lilly. Honestly, I had no clue about this actor while watching this movie other than to think "this is a master class in acting". I am not great at names and seldom follow actors outside what I see in their movies. Madigan, as Gladys, commanded the scenes and screen, and brought such a fantastic, forceful performance while exhibiting such a range from dramatic scenes, to humor, to lighter banter. It was impressive. To not spoil anything for those who have not seen it, watch this movie for the sake of the actors and, in particular, Madigan as Gladys. Later, after leaving the movie (had to leave a little earlier, going to watch the movie again) and pulling up the characters, I discovered Madigan's accomplished acting background: impressive, as was this performance. Great job.

Brolin as Archer impressed me, as at first I thought "don't let this be one emotional dad type full of anger", but it wasn't and Brolin as Archer handled explaining why and where the anger was coming from and why the character was coping with the issues going on.

Gosh, I could write pages about each of these actors, their scenes, the nuances, and what a great job they all did, but that is too much for here!

Sure there are things about this flick that annoyed me (to not put out spoilers), things with scenes, script, and some other things-- due to the actors, this movie is a watch, so go watch it in the theaters!
label: figurative

text:
A disturbing view of the times Much more in the style of Beau Is Afraid than Hereditary or Midsommar, it displays the same penchant for absurdism, unexpected plot escalation, and wide thematic reach from Ari Aster. It's an entertaining satire touching on everything from Covid, social media culture, corporate greed, left/right wing politics, conspiracy theories, and cults.

One point of criticism is that it's stretched so thin it doesn't really develop a sharp point of view on any of these topics. Much like Beau Is Afraid, it feels perhaps too unfocused to have anything particularly interesting to say, at least upon first viewing. It's like a collage of all the absurdities of the 2020s with the subtitle "yeah, things are pretty crazy out there". It's an amusing and disturbing reflection of current times, but doesn't offer something you don't learn by just watching the news.

Much like with Beau Is Afraid, the crudeness and heightened absurdity also makes the film occasionally seem juvenile, which undermines any underlying message. Overall, it feels more like a wild rant than insightful commentary. I find that politically and socially topical movies often repeat talking points moderate audiences are already familiar with. In keeping with that trend, Eddington doesn't really add anything new to the discussion.

Maybe you tend to make sense of confusing times after the fact, not while the storm is ongoing, and that contributes to the unfocused narrative. Maybe it's too soon to offer any kind of catharsis on Covid and to provide insight into ongoing cultural crises. None of this detracts from how enjoyable the movie is, but it betrays a certain kind of confusion and immaturity coming from the filmmakers. It's a shame because Ari has already shown himself to be a great director and writer with the more reined in Hereditary and Midsommar. Even the best filmmakers need to have their worst instincts checked, though, and hopefully there is someone in Ari's circle to do that. I will credit him for being an equal opportunity offender, though. For better of for worse, it feels like there is an element of South Park in Eddington.

For the good stuff: great acting throughout (I expected nothing less with this cast), beautiful cinematography and New Mexico scenery, some wild and unpredictable plot turns. Ari is still great at building tension and has a unique voice in cinema that I will definitely come back for.
label: literal

text:
Attending Anesthesiologist The Pitt is a fast-paced and emotionally engaging new medical drama that does a great job showing what it's really like to work in a busy emergency room. The show captures the intensity, the urgency, and the constant juggling act that comes with treating critically ill patients in a high-pressure environment.

What really stands out is how medically accurate most of the show is. The way they handle trauma cases, resuscitations, rapid decision-making, and teamwork under stress all feel very true to life. The medical terminology is used just enough to feel real without sounding forced, and the scenarios-from collapsed lungs to major trauma-are portrayed in a way that's both dramatic and believable. You can tell they've put in serious effort to get the medicine right.

That said, there are a few noticeable misses when it comes to sterile technique. In one scene, a full-on emergency thoracotomy is done without anyone wearing a face mask, which is a pretty big no-go in real-life medicine. There are also times when supposedly sterile gloves look way too clean after messy procedures, or when non-sterile blue gloves are used for things that definitely should be sterile. For anyone with a medical background, these moments break the immersion a bit.

Still, those issues aside, The Pitt is one of the more realistic and well-done medical shows out there right now. If you're into hospital dramas and want something that mostly gets it right, this one's definitely worth checking out.
label: literal

text:
Undercooked Holmes and Watson Redo This concept idea was a huge risk. First, we get another unasked for updating of the Sherlock Holmes (most recently Elementary) mythos; then we also get a fairly blatant "lift" of the premise from House.

Those two shows had two incredible leads: Johnny Lee Miller, and Hugh Laurie.

This show has neither of those strong performers.

What we receive instead is Morris Chestnut, an actor who has a long list of short run series (Rosewood), and lengthy guest roles (The Resident, Goliath, Our Kind Of People). Chestnut seems to play dozens of variations of the same character: handsome (of course), exceptionally high IQ, superior vocational talents (detective, doctor...), a self-destructive nature, and an incredibly arrogant attitude. All of that is present here.

The production values are good, the supporting actors (most of them) have pretty faces, and the camera work is actually very good. The scripts however...those are not good. Stilted dialogue, silly coincidences, hammy melodrama, and way too many tropes and stereotypes. There's the ex-wife who Watson (Chestnut) is pining for, the young, bright, overly competitive assistants, a grimy Brit with a terrible cockney accent, and a surprise villain who is already planning a huge double cross of our hero.

And while none of that is good, the casting choice of Randall Park (Ant Man, Wanda Vision) as the new version of Moriarty is ridiculously bad. In his first scene he delivers a line that practically screams "Muah-ha-ha-ha!" It plays as campy (which it's Park's bread and butter), which is doubly terrible because the rest of the episode is pure melodrama and soap (one character says to Watson, "You're so talented, you see right into people's souls).

I'd say too bad, but another Sherlock Redux after so recently saying goodbye to Elementary, is just too much.

Unfortunately there's a full 13 episode run.

Yeesh.
label: literal

text:
I expected greatness, I got mediocrity For those that have never played the game, the basic premise is that the protagonist starts in an underground fallout shelter called a vault, and through various circumstances is forced to the surface in a struggle to survive.

This show gets that part right, but it's via a poorly written story that has no coherent thought process behind it. Sure, there's a general plot that is followed in each episode. Unfortunately, the writers don't seem to want to actually tell a good story, they just want to set up individual scenes that are loosely tied together... and don't even get me started on the plethora of plot holes and inconsistencies.

On a positive note, the show does a good enough job of capturing the look and feel of the Fallout world. However, it does not seem to populate that world with all of the enemies and monsters that you would find in the game. It gives you a few ghouls and radroaches here and there, but the actual Fallout world is teeming with these, as well as an abundance of other nasties to be dealt with.

Overall, I was very disappointed with this because, as the title says, I expected greatness and I got mediocrity.

This Year's Best or Most Overhyped Series? I wonder if I might have enjoyed Pluribus more had I discovered it organically, without all the surrounding hype.

After finishing the first episode, I found the story only mildly engaging. It seemed to lean heavily on familiar plot points from other series: an alien signal, a sudden virus outbreak, a dystopia, and the "zombies" (of the kissing kind). The most interesting part, the relationship between the writer and her manager, was cut short way too quickly.

Furthermore, the humor didn't quite land for me. I also couldn't shake off the feeling that the premise might have worked better as a feature film rather than a series. I attempted to watch Episode 2, but the shift in direction didn't hold my interest.

I was genuinely hopeful that Pluribus would be something special, but the excessive use of familiar, regurgitated concepts left me disappointed.

Am I alone in feeling this way?

S3=budget feels halved, core group split up for nearly the whole season, big CGI monster that looks at home in Resident Evil 2 or The Evil Within 2 video game, contrived setups , poor consistency , cheap guard costumes and lazy jokes.

text:
A Solid Debut This film was a solid debut from Chris Stuckmann, whom I've watched since roughly 2015. And my first ever horror film, so there's probably a significant amount of inspiration Chris took in this film that I simply missed.

The story of the film is that Mia Brennan-Walker is searching for her long lost sister, Riley, who she is certain is alive despite so many people telling her otherwise. And the rabbit hole she falls down takes a sinister turn when she realizes the imaginary demon from their childhood may have been real.

The atmosphere and dread this movie builds is really well done. It's not anything groundbreaking, but it does its job well. The best sequence is the prison scene where Mia is investigating a specific cell. There are three really good jump scares there. In fact, the film has quite a few jump scares. But I would say those three in the prison are the best. The others in the film are hit or miss. Some work and some don't. I'll reiterate the prison sequence is the best sequence in the movie. The atmosphere and suspense is practically perfect.

The story itself is... okay. What works is definitely Mia and the very relatable drive to find her sister. But I can't say it's a great story in execution. There are certain problems I have like there's roughly a 10-12 year time skip between Riley's disappearance and the start of Mia's investigation. I simply find it hard to believe anybody would continue searching for that long without coming to believe the person they're searching for is dead.

Then there's the ending. The ending works for the most part, but there is a simple "why on earth would you ever do that" decision made that kinda brings it down. Mia finds her sister alive and being used to breed a demon called the Incubus. Where Mia finds Riley, she also finds a baby who was the center of a satanic ritual being executed by a woman named Norma, played by Robin Bartlett. In a shocking turn, Mia TAKES THE BABY HOME because it's established earlier in the story she wants to be a mother. Why the heck would you ever do something like that? You know there's gotta be something wrong with this baby, so why would you take it home?!

Well Riley tries to kill it and a scuffle happens with Mia, causing Riley to get thrown out a 2-story window by accident. She survives the fall, but not the demonic wolves that tear her apart. That's where I think Chris did an excellent job. The twist.

Earlier in the film, it's established that Mia saw the demon that had been haunting Riley during childhood, but dismissed it as a false memory or a dream. But then realized it was real when she saw it while beginning her search for Riley. Well the twist is that the Incubus had manipulated/controlled Mia into ultimately being the hand that caused her sister's death.

The entire cast really came to play. Camille Sullivan was the standout performance. Robin Bartlett was appropriately creepy and sent shivers down my spine with every scene she was in. As a huge fan of his, I wish we could've gotten more Keith David, but the one scene he was in was great and probably the right amount of screen time needed for the character.

Final Verdict: 7/10.
label: figurative

text:
Not worth it I rarely write reviews, but I feel compelled after this disappointing experience. I watched this movie solely because of the glowing reviews it had received online. Many people described it as a masterpiece, engaging, and even a "must-watch." Unfortunately, my experience was the complete opposite. To be honest, it felt like a total waste of both my time and money.

From the very beginning, the movie struggled to capture my attention. The storyline was flat and lacked originality. Instead of being drawn into the plot, I found myself constantly waiting for something meaningful to happen, but it never really did. The pacing was uneven, with long, drawn-out scenes that added little to the overall story. For a film that was hyped as being full of drama and emotion, it was surprisingly dull.

The characters, too, were underdeveloped and one-dimensional. I didn't feel connected to any of them, which made it difficult to care about what happened on screen. Even the performances, which some reviewers praised highly, felt uninspired and unconvincing. It seemed as though the actors themselves weren't fully invested in their roles.

Cinematography and visuals were average at best. There were a few moments where the film looked appealing, but nothing memorable or striking. The soundtrack, instead of enhancing the mood, felt generic and forgettable. For a movie that had been built up with such positive reviews, I expected a lot more creativity and impact.

Overall, I honestly don't understand how this movie received so many good reviews. It might appeal to a very specific audience, but for me, it offered little to no entertainment value. If you're considering watching it, I would recommend saving your time and money for something more worthwhile.
label: figurative

text:
Gave it a 2nd chance After the 1st episode of Ed Gein, I turned it off. After this, I came across an interview by Charlie, the actor who portrayed Ed Gein, were he explained that this was not about the things Ed Gein did, but WHY he might/ could have done them.

This changed my perspective and expectations of the journey I would led down in watching the series. With this new perspective, I found this series to be intriguing and Charlie's portrayal of Ed Gein a masterpiece.

Without seeing this interview, I would never have given the series a 2nd chance and would have missed out on this incredible series.

I challenge those who walked away to give in another chance, with the understanding it's not about the what, but the why.
label: figurative

text:
What Walt's Watching "Good Fortune" is not the first time Keanu Reeves has taken on a role that gets him involved in the realm of angels.

20 years ago in "Constantine" he was a man who could see angels and played opposite "Gabriel".

Now he is an angel, even if he only has small wings.

Unfortunately for angels size does matter.

"Good Fortune" is more fantasy, comedy than the horror of "John Constantine's" world.

In this movie Keanu's a well-meaning but rather inept angel named "Gabriel" whose first mistake is meddling in the lives of a struggling worker in the gig economy "Arj" (Aziz Ansari) and wealthy venture capitalist "Jeff" (Seth Rogen).

Aziz also directed and wrote this very funny script.

Even though the life swap and body swap genre has been done to death, most recently in "Freakier Friday" and back in 1983's "Trading Places" just for starters, this feels fresh.

Listen out for: a really good mix of hits on the soundtrack

"Good Fortune" ticks a lot of boxes for action, comedy, fantasy and romance.

Maybe trying to be all things to all people weakens this film's overall appeal.

It deals with the high cost of living and reflects the broadening gap between the haves and have nots in capitalist society today.

However, Keanu saves it with his loveable angel that falls from grace.

It's a clever directorial debut from Aziz who came to our attention last decade in "Parks and Recreation".
label: figurative

text:
Superman Soars Again I've been a die-hard DC fan for years, but let's be honest-lately they've been serving us more duds than triumphs. Superman (2025) changes that. James Gunn delivers a film that actually remembers who Superman is: not just an alien with godlike powers, but a man who's always been more human than the rest of us.

David Corenswet is the Superman I didn't know I needed. His performance channels the sincerity and warmth we haven't seen since Brandon Routh, with a presence that feels both powerful and achingly vulnerable. He doesn't brood-he cares. And somehow, that's more revolutionary than any laser-eyed battle.

But as much as this is Superman's movie, it's also Lex Luthor's. Nicholas Hoult blew me away. His Lex isn't just cartoonishly evil-he's terrifying because he's believable. Hoult plays him with an unnerving mix of cold brilliance and raw emotion, making him obscenely dynamic. One moment, you're recoiling at his cruelty; the next, you almost understand him. It's easily one of the best live-action takes on Lex we've ever gotten, and it elevates the entire film.

What really works here is the balance. Gunn's filmmaking style blends humor and sincerity without tipping too far in either direction. The comedy lands-genuinely lands-but never undercuts the weight of darker moments. The characters stay true to their cores, giving us a strange sense of nostalgia despite this being a new take. They stand shoulder to shoulder with the versions Donner gave us, making it feel like-for the first time in years-the DC Universe is finally treating its icons with respect.

Technically, the movie shines. The CGI isn't flawless, but compared to the sloppy overproduction Hollywood has been pushing out lately, it's a refreshing step up-sleek, effective, and never distracting. And thankfully, Gunn resists the current superhero trend of forcing crossovers into every frame. The story is self-contained, yet the threads it does weave (that ending with Supergirl!) had me gritting my teeth in anticipation for what's next.

The supporting cast is strong across the board, the cinematography is colorful without losing grit, and the pacing never drags. Honestly, this was one of the very few movies I didn't want to end.

Superman doesn't just revive a character. It revives an idea: that hope and kindness are just as thrilling as destruction and chaos. And after years of disappointment, that feels like a cinematic miracle.
label: figurative

text:
The Marksman Robert Lorenz is a director who has had a long association with Clint Eastwood.

I guess Eastwood was too old for The Marksman so Liam Neeson steps in.

Neeson plays Jim Hanson, a retired Marine marksman with money troubles. He spent his savings on his wife's medical bills who has since died of cancer. His ranch is at risk of foreclosing.

Jim comes across a couple of migrants crossing the border from Mexico. Rosa, a young mother dies. She asks Jim to her son Miguel to some relatives in Chicago.

On their tail are some Mexican gangsters, Miguel's father stole money from them and that seems a good motivation for Jim.

This is a slower paced action film. Melancholic in tone. Jim is gruff and at first reluctant to help Rosa and Miguel. Eventually Jim and Miguel strike up a rapport as the bad guys seem to be right behind them.

For a movie called the Marksman there is not much shooting from Jim. In that sense it misses the mark.

Just like that, Chad Powers knows its premise is absurd. It knows it shouldn't work. And instead of trying to hide from those truths, it makes fun of itself in all of the best ways. I sincerely hope we get a second season. Until then, Catfish on me!

text:
Need a Miracle? Good Fortune (2025) is a supernatural comedy movie written and directed by Aziz Ansari in his directorial debut and it follows a well-meaning but rather inept angel named Gabriel meddling in the lives of a struggling gig worker and a wealthy venture capitalist. This is a movie that I've seen tv spots for on YouTube, so I decided to give the movie a watch today and it was really good.

Positives for Good Fortune (2025): I have to give credit to Aziz Ansari for his work on this movie as it was an impressive directorial debut for him. This man manages to make a movie that can be both funny and charming, while having themes on what life is like for people in Los Angeles. A big part of that is the cast and the performances from Keanu Reeves, Aziz Ansari, Seth Rogen, Keke Palmer and Sandra Oh and they play their characters so well. I like how the movie gives us an angel who isn't nearly as good as he thinks he is and that he is a dumbass, but Keanu Reeves is so likeable as a person that you endear yourself to him as a character. The situation with these characters get into are hilarious to watch, while also feeling a bit realistic despite the supernatural elements. This is the type of comedy movie that we need more nowadays as it is a genre in film that isn't nearly as good as it used to be and this movie does give me some hope for the future. And finally, the pacing of the movie is really good and the story flows very well.

Negatives for Good Fortune (2025): While Aziz Ansari did a great job writing and directing this movie, there are a couple of mistakes being made along the way. There are moments where the comedy was a bit weak and forgettable. I also felt the movie was a bit rushed with the story as if it had nothing else to say towards the end. And finally, the ending was a bit underwhelming.

Overall, Good Fortune (2025) is a good directorial debut for Aziz Ansari with a good premise and a fun cast. I am looking forward to seeing what he does next as a filmmaker.
label: literal

text:
An enjoyable show, but you have to suspend belief often. It's like the other reviewers pointed out - the show's fun, the lead MC makes it work and there's enough happening in every episode to keep you tied up with their mysteries. I enjoyed the show but there are few things I'm gonna mention bc they kept bugging me.

1. The MC's voice fry. Why? Extremely annoying.

2. Her lips. What did she do to them? I couldn't take my eyes off them for most part of the series bc I know she's had some procedure done and it makes her look worse, but whatever. Beauty lies in the eye of the beholder.

3. And my biggest problem - why does she dress how Hollywood dresses a 20 something hot mess? Who shows up in a mini skirt at work, unless you're a stripper? Why does nobody ask her to dress more formally? More importantly, as someone with a 160+ IQ, shouldn't she have the common sense to not only NOT dress as a 20 year old, but to at least cover her legs when she's around dead bodies???? She has to constantly do things like squatting, bending, jumping and what not, and you want me to believe this highly intelligent woman CHOOSES to wear an uncomfortably short and tight mini skirt (with heels, no less) Every. Single. Time?

The remainder of the cast was pretty basic and had no depth to it, including the strong and independent but slightly annoying teenage girl who does what she wants but is a pure virgin bc for whatever reason, despite Hollywood being soooo sex positive, teenage girls having sex is still a no-go for them. It's honestly a tired trope at this point.

The ex-husband also makes no sense. He has no animosity towards the MC, he's available at every beck and call of hers, drops everything to make time for her demands....... so why are they divorced??? It's never really explained. It would have been better if that character was instead the MC's sister or gay brother.

text:
A good introduction to a hidden aspect of Japanese culture Brendan Fraser plays an American actor who has been living in Tokyo for 7 years. His career has not been a success, doing things like toothpaste commercials. A chance gig has him connected with Rental Family, a business that rents out fake family members, friends, apologetic mistresses, etc. There are roles that specifically require a white man. His 1st official task is to play bridegroom, getting married to a young woman, who then can leave her family, ostensibly to go with him to Canada, but in fact for her to be with her lesbian lover.

In between other short-term roles, a couple of several-weeks continuing roles come up. One is to be a friend to an aging actor, under cover of being a journalist who wants to write his life story. Another is to play the long-lost father of a young girl, whose mother is trying to get into a good school, but believes that a single parent will not be acceptable. In both cases, the hiring client is not the subject of the relationship, so his acting skills are called upon. However, he gets emotionally attached, and complications ensue.

I saw this film at the World Premiere series of screenings at Toronto International Film Festival, with director Q+A. It seems that rental families are a real business in Japan, especially in Tokyo, where people are lonely, and psychotherapy is not easily available and socially disdained. Some businesses specialize in particular aspects, while others (like in the film) are generalists. Also, there are shrines around Tokyo, where, for a small offering, strangers can go to pray and meditate.

The situations are heartfelt, and Fraser does a good job playing the actor who is conflicted by playing a fake role in real people's lives. Recommended for those who are interested in a glimpse of the underbelly of Japanese culture.
label: literal

text:
The Girl with the Canadian Accent Bonkers - sometimes in a good way, sometimes in a "God, this is annoying" way but overall, Seasons 1 and 2 are pretty good, even if they require suspension of disbelief.

Season 3 is where Absentia falls off a cliff, as the quality of writing takes a nose dive to the level of "nonsensically, unwatchably bad". It's truly terrible, in every way.

Each season is artificially stretched to 10 episodes, which can be frustrating to wade through at times.

The female protagonist has absurd powers of recovery, both physical and mental. In S3, she turns into a comic book superhero.

These must be the most unprofessional, poorly trained FBI agents in modern history. The character of Nick is poorly written - hard to be believe anyone is that feckless, though thinking of some former work colleagues maybe it's not so unrealistic.

The accents across all seasons can be variable - Stana is frequently blatantly Canaaadian, eh? Some of the Brits have flawless American accents, that slip only once or twice.

In S1, best to turn on the subtitles and leave them on - one character in particular is unintelligible.

Very good production values, even if the filming locations are very obviously not American.

Good cinematography - dark, moody, washed out colours. In S3, it goes overboard though and it's never daytime - just a permanent shade of brown sepia. Yet another reason to hate S3.

Watch S1 and S2, then spare yourself the agony of S3. Gets a 7 rating out of goodwill for the first two seasons.
label: literal

text:
Only The Designs Shone. The Story Was A Rushed Flop The theme of Kpop girls hunting with flashy swords is certainly appealing. Due to all the hype and praise, I watched this film with pretty high expectations.

But let's just say I was quite disappointed with how everything was executed. Downvote me all you want, but you glazers need to stop acting like this movie is the second coming of Christ.

PLOTHOLES

The details about the demons and honmoon were incredibly vague. It left me hanging and wondering why nobody in the public knew anything about demons. The people in the movie are like PLEBIANS - they do nothing but brainlessly worship the popstars. There are only three people who can fight the demons, and nobody addresses this?

How did Rumi's parents marry? Was her mother evil? Why is nothing explained about all the powers and stuff?

CHARACTERS

Rumi, Mira and Zoey get to eat whatever they want, and they get mad at Bobby for interrupting their gluttonous "snacktime". They also live in a most fancy building, and that means they're very rich for no reason.

Yep, that's the lifestyle of the three-girl band, which makes them extremely unrelatable. Zoey was downright annoying and overly quirky, and Mira just existed to make the dynamic more practical between the three. Rumi believed herself to be defined as a peice of s**t just because she had marks, and it was somewhat cringe. Like yes, characters can have struggles, but there's NO need to overdo them.

Let's talk about the villains, aka the Saja Boys. The majority of the members are just there for fanservice. They are so detached from the story, and even Jinu wasn't given proper attention. They tried to model his backstory like Demon Slayer's backstories, but again, there was not enough detail. Rumi's relationship with Jinu was rushed and forced, with things happening too fast to feel natural. I get it that this movie is only 1.5 hours long, but still! Jinu said Rumi gave him his soul "back", but there's no way this freaking random girl who doubts herself to hell can remove his remorse over abandoning his family. It makes no sense.

The song 'Golden' needed a nice story behind it, because otherwise it just feels like some self-glorifying song. It popped right up at the beginning and wasn't a meaningful product made in the middle of the film, which made it somewhat shallow.

THE ENDING

Was. Awful.

Gave me My Little Pony vibes. Any of you remember Cadence and Shining Armor's romance part? How they flew up into the air together and remade the shield, which kicked Queen Chrysalis out? Boy that was sooooo similar.

Everything at the end made no sense, and it sounded like the producers were running out of ideas. Rumi was able to kill Gwi-Ma in one stroke, and Jinu was able to save her with his body, just like that? Weird, weird!

Everything was just thrown down like that - the Saja Boys were killed, and Jinu alone was portrayed as "somewhat good". So, are demons evil, or not? The message is muddy and poorly delivered.

POSITIVE THOUGHTS

The costumes were elaborate and pretty, and "Takedown" wasn't a bad song at all. Rumi wasn't a perfect protagonist which is good, and I am happy she and Jinu didn't get the cliche, unrealistic pair-up everybody wants. Overall this film is enjoyable for kids.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

This movie should have been much longer. Th characters were not fleshed out enough, and the million-air status of the Huntrix members managed to estrange me from connecting to them. Sony tried to incorporate a lot of things into this movie, but it was too fast-paced, undetailed, and morally smudged. All hiding under the pretty image of Rumi and Jinu.

NEVER TRUST THE HYPE, GUYS! PEOPLE SHOULDN'T GLAZE IT JUST BECAUSE OTHERS ARE DOING IT.

DON'T BE LIKE SHEEP GOING OVER A CLIFF!

text: Total disappointment I am probably one of the few who actually read Stephen King's book, the one this movie was based on. text:
Compelling with outstanding performances This is a well told story of a little known part of the Nuremberg trials. It holds your attention right from the off with a well paced script and outstanding performances throughout.

Of course there is a little bit of artistic licence but if I want 100% historical accuracy I would read a book or watch a documentary. As a drama though this works very well.

Using some b&w imagery to give more of a sense of the time, in the trial scenes when actual archive footage of the holocaust is used it all adds to the sense of watching something from the time.

There is one small aspected that irked me a little bit where certain characters are given some dialogue to shoehorn some facts and timeline. It felt a little bit as though the audience weren't trusted enough to know some basic facts. That may well be true but I doubt those people wouldn't be in the audience anyway.

That aside it is a very very good film. What makes it stand apart though are the performances from Russell Crowe and Rami Malek in particular. Michael Shannon also shines and although a smaller part there is one scene in particular where Richard E Grant stands out. I would not be surprised to see award nominations coming soon.
label: figurative

text:
Not bad, but too much Marvel I will start with saying that I'm not the biggest fan of Cavill's and Snyders Superman attempt.

I heard that this portrayal would be more hopeful and comic accurate.

With that said, this was definitely not a dark take on the man of hope.

BUT it brought something to the table that we've already seen Marvel do since the first Iron man.

It was too much a goofiness mess.

If it would have come 20 years ago, this would have been awesome. Instead it brings us a movie that feels a little tiresome and uncreative.

We've been OVERFED with these movies the last 20 years....😔 It's more a "Justice Gang" movie (yes, that's what they call themselves here), than a Superman movie.

And this Justice "gang" movie reminds me more of Guardians of the galaxy than Justice League.

I like the adoption of Krypto (the dog), but it became too much.

Krypto reminded a lot of a dog version of Groot in GotG. In fact, a lot of the characters had a similar character in Guardians of the galaxy.

This felt a little lazy and uncreative.

On the other hand... As a Guardians of the galaxy movie, it was good.

Colors, lighting, angles, CGI, jokes and even music felt like it came directly from Gotg, and in that type of movie it works.

Unfortunately Superman made me miss Reeve's Superman more.

If I would take Gunn's and Snyder's Superman and throw it in a blender, the result would be awesome.

They both fell a little too far in each ditch.

Gunn's is too silly and Snyder's is too depressing.

I like this one for what it is, but I'm also wishing for a new remake.
label: literal

It starts well, gets better, but then they just try to milk out as much as possible This show was supposed to end a long time ago. Main actors started to leave and the plot doesn't really get better (or even stays the same) without them. Like, really, Fiona's actor, which was arguably the "main main character" of the show, left the show and they just kept going.

Most original characters are really well made and likable (Debbie being the one I have a bit of an issue with), but the problem with shows that have this is that, when you remove them, it loses substance. It lost its substance, I didn't feel interested on rebooting the story because the show was interesting by its story, not by its setting necessarily.

Props for the Ian & Mickey relationship though. I just love the chemistry and realness those two have together. Not even touching how important that is to be shown on television as we go into the "being gay or not is normal and everyone should accept it", which is a really good message as well.

text: Breath of fresh air! I have REALLY enjoyed watching this! Quite honestly it's a breath of fresh air against every other show that's coming out right now, in my opinion. No, it's not super serious, it's just FUN. There's some humor, fluff, ridiculousness, etc. And to me, the chaos of it really works. At the end of my incredibly full and busy days, to sit down on the couch and watch something that has a bit of mystery and surprise to it is really great. I won't give it away, but I haven't had such an authentically raw outburst of laughter in a LONG TIME... and the scene with Carol Burnett speaking to Kristin Wigg in the delacortte mansion had me snorting and I even replayed the scene. Is it cinematic gold? Perfection? NO. But honestly the intrigue of each episode and dramatic ironies at play, mixed with the 1960s backdrop and exciting wardrobe is the perfect cocktail hooking me in. Give it a try with an open mind. Without being stuffy and judgmental. I hope you too will feel refreshed as I did.

It's like promising you creamy delicious vanilla ice cream and then giving you gritty overly artificial froyo. Is Kristen Wiig good in the lead? Yes. Are the rest of the cast above average. text: what a life The award-nominated writers of SING SING, Greg Kwedar and Clint Bentley, have now upped their game even more with TRAIN DREAMS, this time with Bentley directing. It has a similar theme of the beauty and unpredictability of humanity and the world itself. Based on a novella by Denis Johnson, this is a character study of Robert Grainier (Joel Edgerton), a logger working on a railroad in 1917. He's stoic, a hard-working man with a wife (Felicity Jones) and daughter to take care of. He's a man of few words, but he's thoughtful, looking for purpose in life. Usually, having a narrator could be seen as a crutch, but it's done so well here, voiced by a smooth but powerful Will Patton. He gives us more insight into Robert and the world around him. The movie touches on discrimination during the "Great War", but its main focus is Robert and how the world changes around him. The process of building a railroad represents both destruction and progress. Chopping down trees, then making the world smaller by building railroads. It also focuses on Robert's workmates, one played by William H. Macy. His role is very small, but this might be the best he's ever been. Speaking of "best he's ever been", freakin Joel Edgerton. This man does so much, with little dialogue. It's an award-worthy performance on top of an already awesome career. Humanity's complicated relationship with nature is another theme here. Overall, this is a poetic meditation of America, about the ups and downs of one life among many. I had the privilege of seeing TRAIN DREAMS in a sold-out theatre, and I can't wait for you to see it when it comes to Netflix on November 21. I know this review is early, I just had to put something out there about it. Put it on a list, make a reminder, don't pass this one by when it finally releases!
label: literal

text: Whiny, Immature characters; every ONE OF THEM Past the first season, only because of my wife. The mother, Lorelei, looks like a deranged bunny rabbit, and she only eats pizza and chips and sweets. She pouts and runs away when things don't go as she planned. Her only daughter, Rory is just as bad. So each episode they trade the baton as to whom will be the most and biggest crybaby. They both act as if they are ten years old. Rory's grandmother is a wealthy harpie who wants everything and yet gives nothing, except to Rory. Lorelei's father is all business, well-meaning, but distant as the North Pole. This show is aggravating to watch at forty-five minutes each. Every female talks exactly the same way. The quips fly by at a blinding pace but only a few of them make any sense within the context of the story/conversation. So if you like vapid characters who are as thin as tissue paper (even though they eat only junk food every meal) then this insipid show is for you.

text:
Amputated Alien This Superman is fragile, sensitive and mutilated. Understandably, this reboot of the franchise aims to give us a superhero we can relate to, one with social and political relevance. But all those good intentions stray too far from the essence of what makes Superman iconic. Much of the film shows him in one battered situation after another. At first, this vulnerability is refreshing, but over time, it becomes emotionally draining, to the point of fatigue.

David Corenswet delivers a charming and earnest Superman, but the script gives him little room to explore the depth and complexity the role deserves. The visual effects, while competent, lack the creative spark needed to elevate this film above the countless superhero entries that have come before it. Storytelling is uneven and, at times, unfocused, as the film tries to juggle too many ideas at once.

Krypto is genuinely endearing but can't carry the entire film on his adorable little body.

It's perfectly fine to give us a flawed, grounded superhero brimming with quiet goodness. But this "alien" feels too amputated, to the point that we can no longer recognize the Man of Steel.
label: literal

The movie repeats some old Marvel tropes which makes the plot a bit predictable at times. I feel like Galactus could have been more menacing as well.

But still: it's the most beautifully shot Marvel film ever with a wonderful cast. Very enjoyable. 7/10.

Overall, a very decent Marvel film! I liked it!

text:
Death becomes her.. Have seen bits & pieces over the years,but finally in two days watched it all.

I did enjoy this although clichéd,not original or unique.

Feel as though topics like this,are almost romanticized in shows.. It did cover serious moments,but yet also glossed over it.

Thoughts: Why didn't Lee greet her versus random boat guy,upon opening the door after she died? Was the therapist Cathy seeing dead or in her imagination? Also hate when they switch actors playing roles,like they did with Cathy's dad.

Did anyone feel,season 4 was rushed? Like they needed to end the series,but was only given limited episodes to accomplish it?

Actors to acting was fine,cinematography & soundtrack decent.

Worth seeing if you haven't,one day might rewatch it.

It was simple- two guys manufacture meth, they need a distributor, the find a distributor,their partnership goes sour with their distributor, they find a way to kill their distributor, rinse, repeat....add in a little moral questioning, some bromance and there you have it- how to write "Breaking Bad."

text:
A hard pass! The film presents a perplexing paradox of quality, where the performances barely scrape by with passable, albeit uninspired, acting that might be generously described as B-grade. Unfortunately, this visual splendor is grievously undermined by the script, which plummets to the depths of F-grade writing. The cinematography in the film is decent, managing to deliver clear and coherent visuals that serve the narrative without much flair.

The narrative is beleaguered by scenes that strain credulity, eliciting more winces than awe with their cringe-inducing execution and frustrating lack of realism. This film falls squarely into the trap of the typical American crime drama that rides the wave of hype but ultimately fails to deliver any meaningful substance, leaving the audience yearning for what could have been.

TLDR: Mediocre acting, with decent cinematography but cringe-worthy writing. A hard pass.

text:
May we all get what we want and never what we deserve Animal Kingdom is a well-crafted story with a great cast and exceptional writing. Without a doubt, this series is the best TV series about organized crime to date, even better than The Sopranos, because let's face it, The Sopranos just looks dated when giving it a rewatch.

Ellen Barkin gives the performance of her lifetime on this hit show as Janine "Smurf" Cody, the matriarch of the Cody family. The other cast members really grow into and evolve their parts as a family of well-trained criminals, con artists, liars, thieves, and murderers. While watching the high-tech heists and the planning that goes into it is highly entertaining, this series' strength is in character development and the solid story-telling of a highly dysfunctional family that sticks together, with some exceptions along the way. One of the most interesting parts of the show is Smurf's sons complicated relationship with her. The show is set in sunny Oceanside, Californa, providing a sunny and breezy backdrop to the fast, furious, hip, hot, sexy, and dangerous vibe.

Each season keeps you captivated, and while the show seemingly hit its peak at the end of Season 4, I thought Season 6 came in strong and ended strong. As for the negative reviews about the flashbacks, I found them to be a nice addition to the show, and if you watch the show to the series finale, you will see that they were needed to support the brilliant ending.

This show is not only worth a watch from beginning to end, it's also worth a rewatch!

Update March 2024: One final note as I'm rewatching it for a third time. Is this show realistic and characters authentic and relatable? Probably not. I mean the cast is as sexy as you can get on TV so that's probably not very realistic when it comes to a show about a crime family in America today. But what this show has done is deliver the best storytelling about crime and complex family dynamics that I have seen since The Sopranos. And, those familiar with me or my other reviews would know that, above all else, I hold the story as paramount! Thus, I'm updating my rating from a 9 to a 10.
label: literal

text:
Comfort show Picking up this show may as well have been the best decision i've made in my entire life. A show i wasn't expecting anything from turned out to be everything i was looking for. Interesting plot, brilliantly written characters that are neither good nor really "bad" people, tons of hilarious moments but also a good share of ones that would have you tearing up. Characters that no matter how much you despise are indispensable to the show. The relationships between them - the dynamics, all the hardships that they go through. This show is so much about finding the silver linings. All these characters are constantly facing with poverty - and the show does an amazing job at showing how hard it is to break out from it and from your roots.

I took my sweet time watching this show. A year and a few months to finish it, which probably isn't a long time for 11 seasons... Not because i found some episodes boring, but because i wanted to savour these moments for as long as possible. I came back to it every once in a while, for me it is an extremely comforting show (maybe it's how the gallaghers function, their dynamic, everything), even though it does not lack moments that can make you cry.

I would say i wish i can forget the show so i can watch it all over again, but i'd do it anyway, remember it or not.

text:
Season 1 - Very Good; Season 2 - Not So Good Dark Winds follows a savvy Navajo police lieutenant investigating various crimes on tribal lands while also navigating a complicated home life and the clash of cultures between residents of his reservation and wider society that variously denigrates, idealizes and ignores them.

Season 1 is very good, a gritty thriller that takes diversions to explore larger ideas without getting bogged down in them. Season 2 is a letdown in comparision; it mostly constitutes a bloated and repetitive chase for an Anton Chigurh-type killer with almost superhuman abilities (until the plot needs him to forget how to aim a rifle.) Plot threads are unresolved and the finale is plagarized straight from Wind River.

Also Season 1's presentation of the clash of cultures wasn't exactly subtle, but in Season 2 the writers went all in on sanctimonious pantomime.

Here's to hoping they can right the ship for Season 3.

Definitely my most favourite show of all time I really really love this show. I started watching it in Jan 2010 when my uncle gave me a DVD of it, and boy was I hooked! The humour just flows and there is not a dull moment in a single episode.

What I really like about TBBT is that it has quite a few golden scenes that you can watch over and over again. Case in point - Sheldon and Penny singing "Soft Kitty", Sheldon with a dreamy voice, while Penny is looking at him with gritted teeth. Or when Sheldon is overcome on receiving Leonard Nimoy's DNA. Or when Penny asks,"What do you guys do for fun?", Sheldon says,"Well, some time back we tried masturbating for money". Or Leonard's fruitless pursuit of Sheldon in the ball pit. Or...I can go on :)

Also, what really made me love this show is that I can totally relate to the geeky protagonists. I am a science nerd myself, and every time I see a joke or a gag, I find myself thinking,"That could have been me!"

Bottomline - This is a great, fresh show with boundless potential for more humour, and I really hope it is on air for a sizable amount of time to come.

text:
Strangely compelling, but why? I am in only mid season 3 so far, but having seen this show thus far I felt it necessary to leave a review, especially after seeing the many inexplicable 10 ratings which mention Point Break and High Octane.

Animal Kingdom may be many things, but fast paces and high octane it is not. No, this is much more a rather slow burner of a drama with only tidbits of crime and action thrown in almost as if an afterthought. The show doesn't build around the crimes and jobs the Cody's commit and so far every single one of them has been pretty underwhelming. The viewer is show the highlights of the job, and there is very little victory or celebration to be felt even after the most successful heists because too much happens off screen. The action here is best filed under how to make robbery boring. The heists themselves are pretty ingenious, but the execution is just rather meh look we got more money. Give me the money. No we have to clean it first. Gets a little old.

Where Animal Kingdom gets it right, like other great crime-dramas of the past is that there are no heroes. Every character is shown, the good, bad, the ugly, warts and all. Character development and back story are pretty limited leaving the viewer at a loss most of the time. Even the family tree isn't fully painted to the point that there is no clear vision of who fits where or why. Even the relation between characters is not well defined. In a way, it adds more intrigue, but it can also make it hard to follow at first. The only real thing that can be said is that the Cody family are mostly made up of some pretty horrible people, all very deserving of whatever bad karma may be thrown at them next. It is difficult at times to find even a single person to root for here.

Still the show does have many positives. It is filmed in beautiful Oceanside, California and there are great scenes of the Strand, the Oceanside Pier and other locations throughout the city. As former resident, I loved how the characters talk about how real estate is ruining the beachfront because that is a war that has been raging since the mid 1980s. Some great surfing and other water sport scenes are peppered in as well, and the characters love traveling on a whim to Baja, either winding up in TJ or a bit further down south with mixed results.

At this point there have been some pretty good episodes, but also a lot of dull, slow episodes also. There is a hope that the show will reveal a little more each time, that I think is the main reason to keep watching here. Every time the Cody's do something dirty and you think you've seen their worst, you need to wait as they'll even do something more despicable later on. The reason to keep watching is the hope that this strange ride has a destination or a point somewhere.

As many times as I've been tempted to shut it off, I plan to soldier on through season 4 and hopefully 5 with the rest of you out there. Though often unlikable there is something about these Cody's that is down right addictive. If I had to compare this to anything it would not be anywhere close to Point Break. No, this has much more in common with Shameless.
label: literal

text: Season 18, episode 8. The first day I LOVE this series...been watching sine it started and if I miss an episode, I can watch it on my on demand on my computer. I rarely cry watching NCIS, but last nights episode...I just couldn't help it. The title, The first day gets the NCIS team finally caught up to the pandemic. Everyone is wearing masks and are dealing with the struggle to get over this. Then I learned Jimmy's wife died because of the pandemic. It was heart breaking. Crying in Gibbs arms...he's really the only one who understands what he is going through...he told Gibbs that the hospital wouldn't let him see his wife after she died. I've heard of that happening, and let me tell you...they'd just have to arrest me. shoot me with animal tranquilizers, whatever. At the end he read a letter to his wife he'd written, all the things he loved about her. The whole squad gathered and Jimmy spoke to a picture of his wife and himself together on the view screen. I'm a 50 year old man and I couldn't help but cry. One of the most emotional episodes I'd ever seen. I'm not usually into spoilers, but as far as I'm concerned, that is for movies only....not TV shows. So there. Peace.

text:
I didn't get Wicked Enough. For starters, I have seen the original Broadway Play of Wicked and I really like it. I love Wizard of Oz growing up and I thought it was a good interesting take of the world and setting.

As a film, I was always curious to see how it would be adapted. While I do appreciate it's faithfulness to the source, there are some good aspects but also not so good. Throughout, the costume designs, the production and the sound designs are amazing. It helps to build the world of Oz and create it's vibe. Including the musical score and singing that offers a vibrate, energized and colorful vibe.

However, as a whole, the dull presentation and it's stretched out narrative really seems to fail for me to fully engage with it's power. Writing wise, the narrative is interesting but being stretched out and added with unnecessary characters and moments makes it dried up. Causing some of the characters to be boring and not fully engaging.

The dialogue is pretty bad and there are some poor noticeable uses of CGI that kills away the magical vibe and feel of Oz. Most of the performances are just fine but they never really wowed me in anything particular. Because as a whole, I feel it's a bit overhyped.
label: literal

text:
Decent Premise, Slow Execution When Riley and her crew of Youtube paranormal investigators go missing, most of the world thinks its a hoax. Her sister Mia never gives up hope and becomes obsessed with finding her. Is the nightmare demon from their childhood real? Is it somehow involved?

This film starts off as a found footage film using internet clips and a documentary that MIa is filming. When something unexpected happens while filming it shifts its point of view to the typical narrative style. I have seen some complaints about this, I personally liked it. It's no different then using a montage of scenes to set up the main story. It stars Camille Sullivan as MIa. It took me a few minutes to figure out where i knew her from, the show Shoresy.

Unfortunately, that's about all I liked about this movie. It's the definition of meh. For first time director Chris Stuckmann, it's a good start, not a great one. It's a good enough story but pretty predictable. Biggest issue here is the pacing, it's painfully slow. There is a span of what felt like 15 minutes with MIa by herself looking for any info she can find, pretty much no words are spoken. That can be done if the actions on screen are interesting enough, but that just wasn't the case.

IMDb gives this one a 5.8/10 For me, it's a 5.0/10 Middle of the Morgue

Right or wrong, weak or strong...these are my opinions.
label: literal

text:
NO NOTES. PERFECTION In my 30 years in the medical field, I have never encountered a more accurate and emotionally resonant portrayal of life in the emergency room-or the healthcare profession as a whole-than what is depicted in this series. The raw intensity, the emotional weight, and the complexity of the doctor-patient dynamic are all portrayed with striking authenticity.

Noah Wyle delivers a career-defining performance as Dr. Robby, affectionately known by his team. He wears his heart on his sleeve, embodying the emotions every healthcare worker experiences day in and day out. From the housekeeping staff to the surgical team, every element is depicted with remarkable precision. This show surpasses any other medical drama currently on television, and the ensemble cast is, without question, the most impressive I have seen.

As someone who regularly watches medical dramas and has even served as a consultant for some, I can say without hesitation-this one needs no corrections. It is pitch-perfect.

A special mention must be made of Shawn Hatosy, affectionately known as "Hats," whose portrayal of Dr. Abbott is equally powerful. The show's opening scene, with Dr. Robby talking Dr. Abbott down from the roof, mirrored by the closing scene where the roles are reversed, is a poignant reminder of the emotional toll one shift can take on a healthcare worker. One day. Fifteen hours. A million emotions.

Kudos to the cast and crew for their exceptional work. With the series now picked up indefinitely, promising one shift a year in The Pitt, I can say with deep appreciation-Noah Wyle, we're grateful you're here.
label: literal

text:
blah A movie can be overwrought and still have decent value. The ten commandments is a pretty good example.

A movie can be convoluted and also still be pretty good standing on it's own legs. Star wars and most light sci-fi since the genre was born.

But a movie that is both overwrought and convoluted, well there your operating in the Wiseau territory. Too much of 1950s era cinema finds itself in this mold and this two hour stomach churner is no different. A series of ridiculous coincidences lead to such self serious emotional hand wringing that the movie practically begs for the MST3K treatment. But this is light prestige, therefore humorous relief will not be forthcoming. A plot this bad should be justification for a prison sentence.

text: Great 1st & 2nd Seasons, doubting the 3rd I loved the first and second season of The white lotus. The pacing was nice, the mood was beautifully set with music and mythology. text:
RUN, BEN, RUN The Running Man offers quite exciting action to follow. There are several themes that this film tries to explore, such as control, greed, resistance, and hope. This film offers an interesting and entertaining premise. Here we will see thunderous and thrilling action, with drama behind Ben Richards' character that actually feels a little bit lacking in emotion somehow. Then, this film also criticizes the entertainment media and corporations that control everything, we as viewers are successfully made to feel angry too. The characters are good but quite standard, the character development is enjoyable to watch. The pacing is almost perfect, there are a few parts that are just a bit slow. The cinematography is good and quite immersive. The editing is still Wright's signature use of fast-cuts and rhythm, but it feels like something is missing. The visual effects and CGI are very neat. The production design is extraordinary, making the dystopian atmosphere more pronounced. The sound design makes the action even more exciting, and sometimes made rhythmic with the catchy music too. The cast is very well performed, Glen Powell here is quite impressive. Overall, the film still has the feel of Edgar Wright, but not like his other films.

I give this 8.5/10.
label: literal

text:
A Heartfelt Mystery Full of Humor and Humanity Ted Danson's enduring charisma shines in A Man on the Inside, a heartwarming blend of comedy and mystery from The Good Place creator Michael Schur. The series introduces Charles (Danson), a lonely, retired widower who reinvigorates his monotonous life by taking on a private investigator role in a posh retirement community. Tasked with solving a jewelry theft, Charles finds himself fumbling through undercover work, ultimately discovering unexpected connections with the quirky residents around him. The show deftly balances humor and poignancy, using Danson's impeccable timing and an ensemble of veteran actors like Sally Struthers and Stephen McKinley Henderson to create a vibrant, multilayered narrative. It's a celebration of second chances and human connection, gently addressing themes like aging, grief, and reinvention without losing its comedic charm.

Based on the Oscar-nominated documentary The Mole Agent, Schur's latest venture mirrors the philosophical warmth of his previous works while carving its own identity. The series delights with its intricate whodunit, but its real treasure lies in the relationships that unfold. From Charles' evolving bond with his daughter Emily (Mary Elizabeth Ellis) to his reluctant friendships with fellow residents, the characters are endearing and nuanced. While it lacks the surreal humor of The Good Place, A Man on the Inside captivates with its sincerity, offering both laughter and heartfelt moments. Danson's effortless portrayal of Charles anchors the series, making it a must-watch for anyone seeking a comedic exploration of life's later stages.
label: figurative

text:
Terrifyingly brilliant. You'll float too. What persuaded me to watch this movie was the blessing bestowed upon it by the stories original creator, Stephen King, who claimed: "I wasn't prepared for how good it really was".

He's not wrong.

"IT" is quite extraordinary. The attention to detail, the subtle but effective comedic undertone and the exquisite cinematography not only do the original title proud, they make this re-imagining of the original classic even better than its predecessor. 

It's a very scary film but what impressed me was how true the film sticks to the original's tricks; it isn't filled with loud in-your-face jump scares, in fact, a lot of what makes this film scary is the slick cinematography and intricate shadow play. The use of lighting and creation of atmosphere is what makes this film so tense, which is why it's perfectly suited for those who like Horror movies but without the obnoxious gore.

Watched the pre-release as a critic - August 28th.
label: figurative

text:
I love this show! I want season 2 already! Tim Robinson's new HBO series The Chair Company is a masterclass in weaponizing awkwardness until it explodes into absurd, gut-busting hilarity, proving once again why this guy is the patron saint of cringe comedy. At its core, the show follows William Ronald Trosper (Robinson in peak everyman meltdown mode), a hapless office drone whose big promotion speech goes spectacularly sideways when his brand-new office chair buckles beneath him-leaving him sprawled in a puddle of professional humiliation. What could have been a forgettable blooper spirals into a full-blown conspiracy thriller as Ron fixates on the chair's manufacturer, convinced it's the tip of a corporate iceberg designed to undermine guys like him. Robinson's genius lies in how he turns this setup into a pressure cooker of escalating paranoia: his bug-eyed stares, those volcanic rants that start as whispers and erupt into full-throated tirades about swivel mechanisms and ergonomic sabotage, make every scene feel like a therapy session gone feral. It's like if I Think You Should Leave sketches stretched into a narrative fever dream, where the punchline isn't just the fall-it's Ron's unhinged quest to expose the "chair cabal," complete with stakeouts in parking lots and interrogations that devolve into him yelling about lumbar support like it's the Watergate tapes.

The hilarity deepens with The Chair Company's surreal blend of mundane dread and escalating lunacy, courtesy of Robinson's airtight collaboration with co-creator Zach Kanin, who knows exactly how to mine the banality of office life for cosmic-level comedy. Guest stars like Lake Bell pop in as Ron's exasperated wife, delivering deadpan reactions that amplify the chaos, while the plot veers from HR nightmares to shadowy boardroom exposés that feel ripped from a QAnon fever dream-but funnier, because it's all filtered through Robinson's unflinching gaze on male fragility. One episode's highlight has Ron piecing together "evidence" from a single customer service hold tune, building to a confrontation that's equal parts The Office pettiness and Network rage, leaving you wheezing and wincing in equal measure. It's uncomfortable viewing at its finest, the kind that sticks with you like a bad office memo, reminding us that the real conspiracies aren't out there-they're in the petty injustices we all swallow daily. If you love comedy that leaves you questioning your own sanity, this is Robinson's magnum opus, a swivel into the void that's as brilliantly unhinged as it is relatable.

text:
I can't stand this show I tried to like "The Big Bang Theory". I really tried. However, after seeing a couple of episodes from this sitcom, I ended hating everything about it.

For me, the biggest problem from "The Big Bang Theory" (Besides of the unfunny jokes and the awful cultural references) were the characters. All of them were incredibly unlikeable and annoying (even those that the viewers are supposed to sympathize) unsurprisingly, those characters are also clichés, perpetuating the stereotypical characterization of the "nerd" archetype as seen in many, many other movies and television shows, since the film "Revenge of the Nerds".

All the references made in this show are not only bland, shallow and forced, but also painfully unfunny as well. To get things worse, that stupid laugh track made all those so-called jokes even more irritating, as it were constant reminders to the viewers of what they are supposed to be laughing at.

I consider "The Big Bang Theory " to be a strongly mediocre series with overused stereotypes and flat jokes. For me, this show was like the live-action equivalent of one those lame and unfunny gaming web comics which try to be "cool" and "edgy" by including misogyny and lots of random (and also utterly pointless) nerd references.

So, in other words, "The Big Bang Theory" is the (stereotypically) nerd version of "Friends".
